column3: easily accessible platform where they can go to ask questions about Covid-19 and other health issues.PHOTO: SCREENGRAB FROM ASKDR.CO Published1 hour ago More Linkedin FB Messenger Telegram Reddit WeChat Pinterest Print Purchase Article Permalink: https://str.sg/JYY5 Copy Timothy Goh timgoh@sph.com.sg SINGAPORE - Could you have Covid-19 despite not having a fever?How does the coronavirus affect pregnant women?And should you keep your home at a higher temperature to fight the virus?These are just some of the questions that members of the public have asked on online platform AskDr.The website
column4: which was launched last month and taps volunteer doctors
column5: aims to provide the public a free
column6: easily accessible platform where they can go to ask questions about Covid-19 and other health issues.Its founder
column7: Mr Brian Toh
column9: told The Straits Times on Monday (March 30) that he had planned to launch the site around May this year
column10: but decided to push the launch date earlier in response to the escalating health crisis."

column16: 20207:48 pmIn Healthby Lawal Sherifat Kindly Share This Story: More evidence-based diagnoses are emerging about the pathophysiology of COVID-19
column17: and the right protocol for its management.The recent being intravascular coagulation (thrombosis)
column18: diagnosed via autopsies performed on patients who died of COVID-19 in Italy.Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot
column19: known as a thrombus
column20: within a blood vessel.It prevents blood from flowing normally through the circulatory system.A pulmonary embolism (PE) on the other hand is a blood clot that has traveled to the lungs.A piece of the blood clot can break off and be carried to the lungs."

column4: 2020 Consumer Concerns
column5: News 0 By Pat Dial Some time ago
column6: we had intended to do an article on Turmeric or haldi as it is also known.The onset of the Coronavirus or COVID-19 has precipitated us in doing so since we have seen on the internet a number of references to its use having some value in confronting COVID-19.Turmeric has been in use medicinally and as a food for over 5000 years and has been in the pharmacopeia of the ancient Ayurvedic System of Medicine and still remains the recommended treatment for a large number of ailments.Though Western medicine had long known of the use of turmeric
column7: it was only in the last twenty years that it was enthusiastically adopted by Western Alternative Medicine and now even by formal Western medicine and knowledge of its use and its use are growing exponentially.In Guyana
column8: turmeric and its use were long known
column9: having been brought here by Indian indentured immigrants in the 19th century
column10: but like so many herbs and foods of value in Guyana
column11: we only exploit them when foreign countries set the example."

column1: 27 2659f67a-a433-476e-8f85-7bfdab12b4bb "Turmeric is Being Touted as an Effective Herb to Keep Coronavirus at Bay | Global Indian | indiawest.com Home College Fair About Us Contact Us Advertise With Us Subscription Services Submission Forms Local Weather News Business Global Indian India Technology Entertainment Bollywood Global Interviews Movie Reviews South Indian Television Photos/Videos Sports Calendar Northern California Southern California Other States Submit event Life & Style Health/Beauty Fashion Relationships Youth/Education Food Restaurants Weddings Horoscope Classifieds Letters Blogs/Opinions INFO4U Advertise With Us Facebook Twitter LinkedIn YouTube Instagram Sign Up Log In Dashboard Logout My Account Dashboard Profile Saved items Logout Toggle navigation Search Home College Fair About Us Contact Us Advertise With Us Subscription Services Submission Forms Local Weather News Business Global Indian India Technology Entertainment Bollywood Global Interviews Movie Reviews South Indian Television Photos/Videos Sports Calendar Northern California Southern California Other States Submit event Life & Style Health/Beauty Fashion Relationships Youth/Education Food Recipes Restaurants Weddings Horoscope Classifieds Letters Blogs/Opinions INFO4U Advertise With Us featured Turmeric is Being Touted as an Effective Herb to Keep Coronavirus at Bay IANS Mar 12
column2: 2020 2 hrs ago 0 Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Turmeric
column3: or curcumin
column4: known for reducing inflammation in the body
column5: can help fight off coronavirus
column6: according to some medical experts.(pixabay.com photo) Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Save NEW DELHI – Turmeric
column7: or curcumin
column8: is being advocated by some medical experts for reducing lung inflammation amid the rising COVID-19 cases in India.The virus is especially known to attack the respiratory system.Turmeric is being touted as the only way to keep inflammation in your body low so that you have a better chance of fighting the coronavirus infection.In view of the current COVID-19 epidemic and the panic around it
column9: medical experts have a few suggestions besides washing hands
column10: not being in crowded spaces
column11: etc.
column12: on how to boost the immune system and possibly minimize the symptoms as there is no cure for the disease.Vaccines are at least two years away and there are no drugs on the horizon except Actemra
column13: which is a biological drug that Roche had developed for arthritis.Simple tricks to boost your immune system during coronavirus may help reduce the severity of the disease.One major thing that happens when you get infected is that one has a “cytokine storm” in the body.Bad cytokines/hormones
column14: especially IL-6 and TNF
column15: rise that contribute to stress and organ failure during COVID-19 infection.The pharmaceutical company Roche has dusted off an old drug
column16: Actemra
column17: which was developed for arthritis as it was shown to suppress IL-6.Tocilizumab (Actemra) is in a class of drugs called biologics.Tocilizumab is a treatment for adults with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis
column18: giant cell arthritis
column19: and polyarticular and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis.Even if this drug is approved for COVID-19
column20: it will cost at least $25
column22: 000 per patient.Nature has effective molecules for lowering IL-6 naturally: turmeric/curcumin
column23: resveratrol and lutein."

column7: COMMENTfbtfwComment0From media misreporting on Home Minister Amit Shah’s claims on using facial recognition to identify ‘rioters’
column8: to the fake news around the novel coronavirus
column9: here’s a quick round-up of all the WhatsApp forwards and fake tweets that misled the public this week.1.Shah Did Not Specifically Say Govt Used Aadhaar Data to Identify Delhi RiotersMultiple media outlets including Livemint
column10: India Today and News18
column11: reported on Wednesday
column12: 11 March
column13: that Home Minister Amit Shah had revealed that the government relied on facial recognition software to identify people who were involved in the communal violence that broke out in Delhi between 24-25 February.The media organisations went on to claim that the Home Minister had admitted the use of data from Aadhaar to identify these people.However
column14: nowhere during his speech did Shah mention that the government used the Aadhaar data to identify the rioters.Instead
column15: he said the data was taken from ‘voter ID
column16: driving license and all other government data’.“We have fed voter ID data into it
column17: we have fed driving licence and all other government data into it.More than 1
column18: 100 people have already been identified through this software
column19: ” Shah had said.You can read the full story here.Loading...2.FIT-WebQoof: Has Israel Discovered a Vaccine For Coronavirus?Several posts on social media claim that Israel has discovered a vaccine for the novel coronavirus.The message shows an image of a vial with the label that reads: ""No More Coronavirus Deaths"" with ""God bless Israelites
column20: they have discovered vaccine for coronaviruses."

column14: 2020 11:43 IST The patients who have tested positive are fed a healthy diet of idli
column15: chapati and mint rice It is a challenging task to reach Dr Sujatha Venkatesh
column16: Chief Dietician at Chennai’s Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital
column17: on the telephone.Her daily routine has gone for a toss over the past few weeks
column18: ever since the Coronavirus hit Tamil Nadu.With an increasing number of cases and special dietary requirements for every patient
column19: the pressure is on her and her team to deliver.And they have
column20: with a smile on their faces.Sujatha and her team have been working around the clock to make sure that the patients who have tested positive and all the staff working towards caring for them have been fed — with the kind of food that they believe will make recuperation easier."

column15: other viral infections ByIyanam Isangedighi -April 5
column16: 2020 A professor in the Department of Wildlife and Ecotourism Management
column17: University of Ibadan
column18: Lameed Gbolagade
column19: has advised Nigeria to look inward for a cure and vaccine against coronavirus and other forms of viral infections.In an interview with journalists in Ibadan
column20: the Oyo State capital
column21: Gbolagade
column22: said: “It is time for us to re-focus our research attention toward indigenous remedies instead of synthesised drugs from western countries.“Research institutes should also be encouraged with funding support to carry out studies on different unforeseen catastrophes of this nature.Adequate financial support should also be given to academic institutions to carry on researches.” Gbolagade

column6: Risks for Brands Brad Avery and Beth Kaiserman Mar.19
column7: 2020 at 6:28 pmTweetShareRedditShare1Email1 SharesNeed an immunity boost?While the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 continues to rise worldwide
column8: the food and beverage industry has been forced to swiftly adjust to the crisis.Just as consumers have changed their shopping habits by racing to grocery stores to stock up before indefinite periods of self-quarantine
column9: many brands and entrepreneurs have fast begun tailoring their messaging to comment on the virus.Others are seizing the moment to promote products with immunity boosting properties through social media posts
column10: press releases and eblasts.While many of these promotions simply highlight the benefits of Vitamin C
column11: turmeric
column12: and other ingredients said to help the immune system
column13: the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) have been proactive in making sure no company steps over the line into making false claims that immunity boosting products can help prevent or treat coronavirus
column14: or any other disease.In an FAQ released Tuesday
column15: the FDA said it is “actively monitoring for any firms marketing products with fraudulent COVID-19 prevention and treatment claims.” Violators
column16: the agency said
column17: will receive warning letters and could face penalties including product seizures and injunctions.An FTC spokesperson noted the importance of stopping bad actors quickly in order to help consumers understand that no products have been proven to prevent or cure COVID-19.“If you make a claim that a product can treat or cure anything it needs to be true
column18: not misleading or deceptive and supported by competent and reliable scientific evidence
column19: ” the spokesperson said.“If not
column20: don’t make the claim.”Earlier this month
column21: the FDA and FTC sent out warning letters to seven supplement and oil companies for making false claims about products treating coronavirus.In an email
column22: an FDA spokesperson said the agency is working closely with major retailers and is monitoring online marketplaces and to date has received 90 reports of products marketed with unapproved claims of aiding with COVID-19 and has found at least 50 products in online marketplaces with unproven claims.Many companies have found ways to call out COVID-19 in their messaging without making false claims."

column2: this strategy isn't difficult to do during the shutdown.Geber86Global TravelerA simple tip to boost your immunity — especially if you're on lockdownPublished Wed
column3: Apr 22 20201:25 AM EDTMonica Buchanan PitrelliIf waves of coronavirus infections ebb and flow until a vaccine arrives and if — as some have posited — we're all likely to get it at some point
column4: should we be preparing for a possible infection?The coronavirus is fatal for some
column5: while others — between 25% to 50% according to the latest estimates — have no symptoms at all.Everyone else falls somewhere in between.As the medical community seeks possible explanations for that variability — viral load (how much of the virus you have in your body) and genetic susceptibility are both being studied — we are left to wonder what amount of influence
column6: if any
column7: we have over how our bodies will react to being infected.Age
column8: gender and underlying health conditions can affect outcomes
column9: but there may be many simple things people can do to boost their immunity — and some of the world's most prominent resorts
column10: hotels and restaurants were encouraging them even before the pandemic struck.The single easiest way to boost your immunityThe internet is replete with supposed immune-boosting supplements and recipes — a situation that long predated the arrival of Covid-19 — but the answer to an improved immune system may be far less complicated."

column3: 12 March : The government has urged one and all to not go after rumour but instead verify the information relating to COVID-19 with the Health Ministry.The government made such appeal again in view of rumour created in social networking sites on various aspects of the coronavirus.The Department of Health Services  (DoHS)  has stated that wrong information creates negative impact on public psychology and said in an appeal
column4: “Misinformation creates panic.Spread of factual information is the need of hour.We provide information from time to time.But the media too need to spread authentic news.” According to DoHS proper research and test are carried out to prevent the entry of the disease."

column7: 2020 05:49 PM IST CNBC share If waves of coronavirus infections ebb and flow until a vaccine arrives and if — as some have posited — we’re all likely to get it at some point
column8: should we be preparing for a possible infection?The coronavirus is fatal for some
column9: while others — between 25% to 50% according to the latest estimates — have no symptoms at all.Everyone else falls somewhere in between.As the medical community seeks possible explanations for that variability — viral load (how much of the virus you have in your body) and genetic susceptibility are both being studied — we are left to wonder what amount of influence
column10: if any
column11: we have over how our bodies will react to being infected.Age
column12: gender and underlying health conditions can affect outcomes
column13: but there may be many simple things people can do to boost their immunity — and some of the world’s most prominent resorts
column14: hotels and restaurants were encouraging them even before the pandemic struck.The single easiest way to boost your immunity The internet is replete with supposed immune-boosting supplements and recipes — a situation that long predated the arrival of Covid-19 — but the answer to an improved immune system may be far less complicated.“In my experience
column15: the single best way people can improve their immune system is through adequate sleep
column16: ” said Dr. Steven Tucker
column17: an American oncologist and medical director of Tucker Medical
column18: a multi-specialty medical practice that focuses on the prevention and reversal of chronic diseases.""Sleep is not a pillar of health but the bedrock foundation upon which all health
column19: including immunity
column20: is built.
column21: Dr. Steven Tucker “I used to say that health was based on fitness
column22: nutrition
column23: mindfulness and sleep.I would tell patients that these are the four pillars of health.I no longer do that
column24: ” he said.“I can’t emphasize it enough if you want to improve your immunity
column25: sleep is not a pillar of health but the bedrock foundation upon which all health
column26: including immunity
column27: is built.”It’s believed people who experience a quick
column28: sudden decline in health from a coronavirus infection do so as a result of the immune system suddenly kicking into overdrive in a process known as a cytokine storm."

column1: 27 c9fdd022-91dd-4eaf-9989-3b3c178d67da "FACT CHECK: Does Inhaling Steam Infused With Certain Ingredients Cure COVID-19?12:32 PM 04/23/2020 Brad Sylvester | Fact Check Reporter share on facebook tweet this show comments A video shared on Facebook claims that boiling water with certain ingredients and inhaling the steam cures COVID-19.WATCH: Verdict: False There is no evidence this “remedy” can cure COVID-19.The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) state there is currently no cure for the disease.Fact Check: The video shows two individuals in a small kitchen: one person leaning over the stove with a blanket covering his or her head and a woman speaking to the camera.The woman said that the other person is using an “African remedy” to cure COVID-19
column2: the disease caused by the new coronavirus."

column15: 2020 01:49 IST Haryana Health Minister Anil Vij on Saturday said people should become vegetarian to avoid the threat of COVID-19-like diseases.He said in a statement that it was demand of the time that people should become vegetarian so that the threat of such diseases posed by consuming different kinds of creatures can be prevented.Earlier during the day
column16: Mr. Vij had tweeted in Hindi: “Shakahari bano tarah-tarah ke jeev jantu khakar corona jaise virus paida kar manav jaati ke liye khatra paida na karo (Become vegetarian.Don’t create corona-like virus by consuming different kinds of creatures and pose danger to the human race.)”Mr.Vij said that as a precautionary measure
column17: the State government has decided to impose a ban on public rallies.“The government has imposed a ban on all political
column18: religious or social rallies

column1: 28 5025bceb-f8c5-40e4-a3cc-cecf8da1b0c8 "Eat plant-based diet
column2: avoid dairy products to prevent asthma | Glamsham NewsMovie ReviewPicture GallerySong LyricsFashion & LifestyleDialoguesMoreBox OfficeInterviewMusic ReviewMovie PreviewFeatureBlooperssports Home › News › Eat plant-based diet
column3: avoid dairy products to prevent asthma Eat plant-based diet
column4: avoid dairy products to prevent asthma By Glamsham Editorial | 28 Mar 2020 16:22:37 IST New York
column5: March 28 (IANS) Suffering from asthma?Read this carefully.Following a plant-based diet can help prevent and manage asthma
column6: while dairy products and high-fat foods raise the risk
column7: a new study suggests.Asthma is a common chronic condition in which the airways become narrow and inflamed--sometimes leading to difficulty with breathing
column8: coughing
column9: wheezing
column10: and shortness of breath.""Asthma can make people more vulnerable in the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak and this research offers hope that dietary changes could be helpful
column11: said study researcher Hana Kahleova from Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine in the US.For the findings
column12: published in the journal Nutrition Reviews
column13: the research team examined the evidence related to diet and asthma and found that certain foods--including fruits
column14: vegetables
column15: whole grains
column16: and other high-fibre foods--can be beneficial
column17: while others--such as dairy products and foods high in saturated fat--can be harmful.The researchers highlight a study finding that when compared to a control group
column18: asthma patients who consumed a plant-based diet for eight weeks experienced a greater reduction in use of asthma medication and less severe
column19: less frequent symptoms.In another study
column20: asthma patients adopted a plant-based diet for a year and saw improvements in vital capacity--a measure of the volume of air patients can expel--and other measures.The authors suggest that a plant-based diet is beneficial because it has been shown to reduce systemic inflammation
column21: which can exacerbate asthma.Plant-based diets are also high in fibre
column22: which has been positively associated with improvements in lung function.The researchers also highlight the antioxidants and flavonoids found in plant foods
column23: which may have a protective effect.The review also found that dairy consumption can raise the risk for asthma and worsen symptoms.According to the researchers
column24: one 2015 study found that children who consumed the most dairy had higher odds of developing asthma
column25: compared with the children consuming the least.In another study
column26: children with asthma were placed in either a control group
column27: where they made no dietary changes or in an experimental group where they eliminated dairy and eggs for eight weeks
column28: the researchers said.After eliminating dairy
column29: the experimental group experienced a 22 per cent improvement in peak expiratory flow rate--a measure of how fast the children were able to exhale--while children in the control group experienced a 0.6 per cent decrease.High fat intake
column30: consumption of saturated fat
column31: and low fibre intake were also associated with airway inflammation and worsened lung function in asthma patients.""This groundbreaking research shows that filling our plates with plant-based foods--and avoiding dairy products and other high-fat foods--can be a powerful tool for preventing and managing asthma
column32: Kahleova said.--IANSbu/na Tom Hanks

column20: March 28 (IANS) Amid the fast-spreading coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic
column21: researchers have advised that heart and kidney patients should keep taking their medicines as inaccurate medical information has flooded social media and other channels.One potentially lethal example is that patients who take the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) blockers
column22: particularly angiotensin II type 1 receptor blockers (ARBs)
column23: maybe more susceptible to the virus.ARBs are prescribed for high blood pressure
column24: congestive heart failure
column25: kidney disease and other conditions.However
column26: in an article published in the journal Hypertension
column27: researchers warn there is little credible or consistent evidence to back up this concern."

column1: 30 019cb0b8-c38c-40e5-ac87-4ebafc8cdae4 "Statement Addresses Concerns About Heart Meds and COVID-19 | Physician's Weekly ×Claim Your Free Staff Education Wallboard!Email-id is invalid For latest News and updates Sign UpLog In HomeSpecialtiesAllergy & ImmunologyCardiologyCritical CareDermatologyEndocrinologyGastroenterologyInfectious DiseaseNephrologyNeurologyOBGYNOncology / HematologyOphthalmologyOrthopedicsPain ManagementPediatricsPrimary CarePsychiatryPulmonologyRheumatologySurgeryUrologyDoctor’s VoiceMeeting CoverageContinuing Education#PWChat Select Page Statement Addresses Concerns About Heart Meds and COVID-19Posted by Physicians Weekly | Mar 22
column2: 2020 Patients advised to continue ACE inhibitors/ARBs after researcher posits risk for severe COVID-19 infectionFRIDAY
column3: March 20
column4: 2020 (HealthDay News) — Patients already prescribed angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) should continue taking their medications
column5: according to a joint statement from the American Heart Association (AHA)
column6: the Heart Failure Society of America (HFSA)
column7: and the American College of Cardiology (ACC)
column8: issued in response to a research letter published online March 11 in The Lancet Respiratory Medicine.In a statement
column9: the AHA
column10: HFSA
column11: and ACC recommend that patients who have been prescribed ACE inhibitors or ARB medications for indications such as heart failure
column12: hypertension
column13: or ischemic heart disease should continue these medications.Cardiovascular disease patients who are diagnosed with COVID-19 should be fully assessed before addition or removal of medications
column14: and changes should be based on the latest scientific evidence and shared decision making.The statement comes in response to a research letter authored by Lei Fang
column15: M.D.
column16: Ph.D.
column17: from the University Hospital Basel in Switzerland
column18: and colleagues.Noting that in three studies of patients with COVID-19
column19: the most frequent comorbidities reported are often treated with ACE inhibitors and that human pathogenic coronaviruses bind to their target cells through angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2)
column20: the authors hypothesized that diabetes and hypertension treatment with ACE2-stimulating drugs may increase the risk for developing severe and fatal COVID-19.Based on this hypothesis
column21: the authors suggest that patients with cardiac diseases
column22: hypertension
column23: or diabetes
column24: treated with ACE2-increasing drugs
column25: may be at higher risk for severe COVID-19 infection and should be monitored for ACE2-modulating medications.“There are no experimental or clinical data demonstrating beneficial or adverse outcomes among COVID-19 patients using ACE inhibitor or ARB medications
column26: ” Richard J. Kovacs
column27: M.D.
column28: president of the ACC
column29: said in a statement.“These recommendations will be adjusted as needed to correspond with the latest research.”Statement Abstract/Full TextLast Updated: Mar 20

column5: particularly angiotensin II type 1 receptor blockers (ARBs)

column11: and colleagues warn there is little credible or consistent evidence to back up this concern.Equally important

column6: Scientists (Reuters) – Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body – killing many patients while barely affecting others.But some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19

column4: 2020 -- Much remains unknown about the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and the disease it causes
column5: COVID-19
column6: but there appears to be consensus within the cardiology community that patients ill with the disease need not routinely discontinue the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).In fact
column7: there seems to be a growing chorus of experts suggesting that these drugs may actually be of benefit in COVID-19.""[T]he biological plausibility of salutary effects of ACEs/ARBs in those with COVID-19 is intriguing
column8: write the authors of a viewpoint article

column1: 30 0b2ec5a7-f839-4053-8bac-3b19d8380c3b "Why heart patients need to be wary of coronavirus | Health24 advertisement Health 24 Infectious Diseases News Medical Lifestyle Experts Diet & Nutrition Medical Schemes Beyond Beauty Home  >  Medical  >  Infectious Diseases  >  Coronavirus 08 April 2020 Why heart patients need to be wary of coronavirus Are seniors with coronary heart disease or high blood pressure more susceptible to the coronavirus and at higher risk of developing severe symptoms?0 People with high blood pressure and heart disease may be vulnerable to complications from the new coronavirus
column2: heart experts say.Nearly half of Americans have high blood pressure
column3: according to the American Heart Association (AHA).Based on current knowledge
column4: seniors ""with coronary heart disease or high blood pressure may be more susceptible to the coronavirus and more likely to develop more severe symptoms.That means it's vital to follow guidance about keeping other conditions well-controlled and maintaining good health and hygiene
column5: the AHA said in a news release.Data from Wuhan
column6: China
column7: show a 10.5% death rate among people with Covid-19 who also have heart disease
column8: 7.3% among those with diabetes
column9: 6.3% among those with respiratory disease and 6% for those with high blood pressure.Keep on taking your medsSome people wonder if blood pressure or heart medications could make people with Covid-19 sicker
column10: so the AHA
column11: Heart Failure Society of America and American College of Cardiology recently issued guidelines.Don't stop taking prescribed angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB) medications for high blood pressure
column12: heart failure or heart disease
column13: the guidelines said.These medications don't increase the risk of contracting Covid-19 and are crucial in maintaining blood pressure levels to reduce the risk of heart attack
column14: stroke and worsening heart disease.Heart disease patients with Covid-19 should be evaluated by their health care provider before stopping or adding medications
column15: the guidelines added.Any changes to medication should be based on the latest scientific evidence and shared decision-making.Some over-the-counter (OTC) medicines and supplements can raise blood pressure
column16: including common non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAID) pain medicines
column17: such as naproxen (Aleve) and ibuprofen (Advil
column18: Motrin)
column19: and also decongestants.People with heart problems should avoid or limit use of these drugs
column20: especially if their blood pressure is uncontrolled.OTC drugs such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) are less likely to increase blood pressure.Ask your doctor about OTC medicines.Home remedies might not be safePeople taking prescription medications for mental health
column21: corticosteroids
column22: birth control pills
column23: immunosuppressants and some cancer medications should monitor their blood pressure to make sure it's under control
column24: the AHA advises.Too much alcohol and caffeine can boost blood pressure
column25: and people with high blood pressure should avoid or limit their intake of both.Some so-called natural supplements and home remedies might not be safe."

column5: 2020 at 1:09 pm miflippo/iStock(NEW YORK) -- One of the common symptoms of COVID-19 is fever
column6: and a drug called ibuprofen
column7: found in the leading brands Advil and Motrin
column8: is one of the most-trusted fever reducers available without a prescription.Early in the novel coronavirus epidemic
column9: people were told to stock up on over-the-counter medications including ibuprofen to help reduce mild fevers if asked to ride out a viral illness at home.But recently
column10: French Minister Olivier Veran
column11: a physician
column12: tweeted that anti-inflammatory medications like ibuprofen ""could be a factor in aggravating the infection
column13: encouraging patients to take acetaminophen
column14: which is found in Tylenol
column15: for a fever instead.His comments sparked a wave of controversy about the safety of ibuprofen for fevers associated with COVID-19
column16: with experts weighing in on both sides.Although its safety is still being studied
column17: for now
column18: the world's leading scientists at the World Health Organization have said people shouldn't shy away from using ibuprofen to help mild fevers.Drug companies that make over-the-counter painkillers told ABC News that they're monitoring the rapidly evolving situation and that patients should consult with healthcare providers about any concerns.A spokesperson for Johnson & Johnson
column19: which makes both Motrin and Tylenol
column20: said the company ""is taking all possible mea​sures to maximize product availability across our OTC medicine portfolio to ensure broad access in all markets around the world.”A spokesperson for GlaxoSmithKline
column21: which produces Advil
column22: said: ""This is an emerging and rapidly evolving situation
column23: and because consumer safety is our number one priority
column24: we are closely monitoring statements from the public health authorities and medical experts.""Concerns about ibuprofen and other fever reducers may have been kick-started by fake WhatsApp messages circulating online.While normally such claims would be ignored by medical professionals
column25: the online conspiracy fell on the heels of a hypothesis published in a prestigious scientific journal
column26: the Lancet
column27: which said there may be a scientific rationale for COVID-19 patients to avoid ibuprofen.That theory draws on molecular biology.Because the virus that causes COVID-19 is known to bind to a specific protein in the body called ACE2
column28: any medication that can increase ACE2
column29: like ibuprofen
column30: could theoretically increase the risk for a more severe COVID-19 infection.In addition to ibuprofen
column31: other medications like ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers
column32: a widely used group of blood pressure-lowering medications
column33: have been thought to potentially increase ACE2.But these are just theories.Because of the thin evidence
column34: numerous professional societies have come out against the French official's claim."

column5: many stent procedures for clogged arteries have been pushed back and infertility specialists were asked to postpone helping patients get pregnant.Doctors in virtually every field are scrambling to alter care as the new coronavirus spreads.Medical groups issued advice this week on how hospitals and doctors should adapt as beds and supplies are pinched and worries rise about exposing patients to possible infection.That includes canceling elective surgeries
column6: including many for slow-growing or early-stage cancers

column8: set for April 1 at Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia
column9: was pushed to April 29.He lost one kidney to cancer last year and was eager for this surgery to remove tumors on the sole kidney he has left."

column3: 2020 USCIt has been barely a few weeks since the coronavirus was declared a pandemic.The pace at which the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread across the globe is jolting
column4: but equally impressive is the speed at which scientists and clinicians have been fighting back.I am a pharmacotherapy specialist and have consulted on infectious disease treatments for decades.I am both exhilarated and worried as I watch the unprecedented pace and implementation of medical research currently being done.Speed is
column5: of course
column6: important when a crisis such as COVID-19 is at hand.But speed – in research
column7: the interpretation and the implementation of science – is a risky endeavor.The faster science is published and implemented
column8: the greater the chances it is unsound."

column8: 2020Orsolya MajláthLeave a Comment on EMA advises continued use of medicines for hypertension
column9: heart or kidney disease during COVID-19 pandemic EMA is aware of recent media reports and publications[1] which question whether some medicines
column10: for instance angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs
column11: or sartan medicines)
column12: could worsen coronavirus disease (COVID-19).ACE inhibitors and ARBs are most commonly used for treating patients with high blood pressure
column13: heart failure or kidney disease.It is important that patients do not interrupt their treatment with ACE inhibitors or ARBs and there is no need to switch to other medicines.There is currently no evidence from clinical or epidemiological studies that establishes a link between ACE inhibitors or ARBs and the worsening of COVID-19.Experts in the treatment of heart and blood pressure disorders
column14: including the European Society of Cardiology
column15: have already issued statements along those lines.[2]
column16: [3] To gather more evidence
column17: EMA is proactively reaching out to researchers working to generate further evidence in epidemiological studies."

column39: is not a significant risk factor for mortality when adjusted for age and other comorbid conditions - ACE and ARB anti-hypertensives are safe in this population and may be protective News provided by Hackensack Meridian Health Apr 24
column45: New Jersey's largest and most comprehensive health network
column46: conducted an observational real world study of more than 3
column47: 000 hospitalized COVID-19 patients and found that hypertension
column49: does not have a major impact on survival from the infection when adjusted for age and other comorbid conditions.The study also found that commonly prescribed medications to treat high blood pressure may potentially have a positive impact.These major findings are to be released today on medRxiv
column50: a leading Yale University-affiliated online platform for researchers to share scientific information prior to publication in peer-reviewed journals.The study was based on a ground-breaking database – the RE-COV-RY (Real world Evidence-COVid-RegistrY) – one of the largest compilations of hospital-based COVID-19 data in the U.S. to date."

column1: 30 29cb711e-4b4a-4e5f-9956-736cb2a3f61c "Ibuprofen and COVID-19 symptoms – here’s what you need to know Deeside.com HOME LATEST TWEETS WEATHER TRANSPORT LDR CONTACT US Ibuprofen and COVID-19 symptoms – here’s what you need to know Published: Saturday
column2: Mar 21st
column3: 2020 Share: There’s been some confusion recently on whether we should or shouldn’t take ibuprofen to treat symptoms of COVID-19 – especially after the World Health Organization (WHO) changed its stance.After initially recommending people avoid taking ibuprofen to treat symptoms of the new coronavirus disease
column4: as of March 19 the WHO now does not recommend avoiding ibuprofen to treat COVID-19 symptoms.The confusion began after France’s Minister of Solidarity and Health Oliver Véran announced on Twitter that taking anti-inflammatory drugs (such as ibuprofen or cortisone) could be a factor in worsening a COVID-19 infection.He recommended that paracetamol should be taken instead to treat the associated fever.At the moment
column5: the NHS only recommends taking paracetamol for COVID-19 symptoms
column6: even though it admits there is no strong evidence showing ibuprofen worsens symptoms.The BMJ also states that ibuprofen should be avoided when managing COVID-19 symptoms."

column6: 2020 at 6:19 PM MST - Updated April 6 at 6:19 PM TUCSON
column7: Ariz. (KOLD News 13) - Should I stop taking my blood pressure medication amid the coronavirus outbreak?That’s a viewer question our Fact Finders are tackling.If you take blood pressure-lowering medicine
column8: keep taking it unless your doctor says otherwise.That’s what the American Heart Association is saying.More specifically
column9: they say you should not stop taking any prescribed ACE-inhibitor or ARBs medication for high blood pressure
column10: heart failure
column11: or heart disease.They say these medications aren’t known to put you at additional risk of getting COVID-19 but they are vital to reducing your risk of heart attack and stroke."

column3: heart surgeries delayed as coronavirus alters care Protecting yourself from coronavirus By MARILYNN MARCHIONE AP Chief Medical Writer | March 18
column4: 2020 at 1:40 PM CDT - Updated March 18 at 1:40 PM (AP) - Some cancer surgeries are being delayed
column5: many stent procedures for clogged arteries have been pushed back and infertility specialists were asked to postpone helping patients get pregnant.Doctors in virtually every field are scrambling to alter care as the new coronavirus spreads.Medical groups issued advice this week on how hospitals and doctors should adapt as beds and supplies are pinched and worries rise about exposing patients to possible infection.That includes canceling elective surgeries
column6: including many for slow-growing or early-stage cancers
column7: which many people would consider not elective at all.Luciano Orsini's operation
column8: set for April 1 at Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia
column9: was pushed to April 29.He lost one kidney to cancer last year and was eager for this surgery to remove tumors on the sole kidney he has left."

column1: 30 2e47a212-1fe5-4477-b3c5-bf0875853afc "Coronavirus: People urged to continue blood pressure medication – Infosurhoy Skip to content Infosurhoy Latest Science News and Reports Main Navigation News News Summary Top Stories Technology Economy Entertainment Health Science Sports Coronavirus: People urged to continue blood pressure medication By Denis Bedoya  On March 30
column2: 2020 In News Summary Leave a comment facebook tweet google+ The Heart Foundation is urging three million Australians with high blood to continue taking their medication after research linked it to a higher coronavirus infection rate.The group’s chief medical adviser
column3: cardiologist Professor Garry Jennings
column4: has disputed a paper published in British medical journal The Lancet which found ACE drugs may change the shape of someone’s cells
column5: making them more susceptible to contracting COVID-19.‘Continue to take all your medicines
column6: including ARBs or ACE inhibitors
column7: as prescribed by your doctor
column8: ’ he said.Researchers at the University Hospital Basel
column9: in Switzerland
column10: and the University of Thessaloniki in Greece found two medications
column11: ARB (angiotensin receptor blocker) and ACE (angiotensin converting enzyme) increased the levels of the ACE2 enzyme in the body
column12: the same enzyme that the coronavirus used to infect the body.These medications are used to treat hypertension and diabetes.Despite that
column13: Professor Jennings said there were more risks if three million Australians stopped taking their anti-hypertension or blood pressure medications."

column1: 30 34353904-ece0-4b42-b8a9-b5d9ba461e54 "Doctor offers coronavirus protection advice | FOX 5 New York NewsWeatherGood Day New YorkContestsAbout UsWatch Live More Expand / Collapse search Watch Live ☰ Search site News LocalCoronavirusNationalWorldBig IdeaUnusualSeen on TVSportsGet Our AppsLew's ViewWeather ClosingsTrafficTravel NewsScienceFOX 5 NY Weather AppGood Day New York Good Day CafeHealthWatch LiveGood Day Street TalkAbout Us Meet the teamWhat's on FOXJob OpportunitiesPublic AffairsContact UsContestsEntertainment PodcastsBroadwayPets and AnimalsFood and DrinkBusiness RecallsConsumerMade on Long IslandWhat is IT?Doctor offers coronavirus protection advice Published 1 hour ago Coronavirus FOX 5 NY Facebook Twitter Print Email Doctor offers coronavirus prevention advice Dr. Leo Galland says he has useful and practical information for those concerned about the present coronavirus epidemic and also to correct some misinformation that is circulating.NEW YORK - Internist and author of medical books
column2: Leo Galland M.D.
column3: has authored this information on what he recommends at coronavirus protection options.He says he has written this to supply useful and practical information for those concerned about the present coronavirus epidemic and also to correct some misinformation that is circulating: BACKGROUND: AN EMERGING PICTURECorona viruses are a family of viruses made from RNA instead of DNA.There are many species that produce respiratory and gastrointestinal illness in humans and animals.Four strains cause the common cold."

column1: 30 365718a4-ced8-4294-9703-4a97bf61303d "Coronavirus: Blood pressure medication ‘could worsen symptoms’ – Infosurhoy Skip to content Infosurhoy Latest Science News and Reports Main Navigation News News Summary Top Stories Technology Economy Entertainment Health Science Sports Coronavirus: Blood pressure medication ‘could worsen symptoms’ By Denis Bedoya  On April 2
column2: 2020 In Health Leave a comment facebook tweet google+ People with high blood pressure and diabetes could be at higher risk of severe or fatal coronavirus symptoms because of how their medicines work
column3: scientists say.Drugs called ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may change the shape of someone’s cells in a way that makes it easier for the coronavirus to infect them and cause a more severe illness.The common medications were prescribed almost 65million times in England last year and cost the NHS more than £100m.They are given to treat diabetes or high blood pressure and around 10 per cent of people in the UK – some 6.6million – are estimated to take them regularly.A paper published in prestigious British medical journal The Lancet Respiratory Medicine studied how the coronavirus latches on to people’s cells to infect them.But a doctor has warned that patients who take the medicines must not stop doing so – they should speak to their doctor if they have concerns."

column2: instead of anti-inflammatories.Here's why.Mordechai Sones
column3: 18/03/20 11:21 IbuprofeniStock The World Health Organization has recommended that people suffering from the symptoms of the virus avoid taking ibuprofen drugs such as Advil.Instead
column4: the organization suggests taking paracetamol
column5: such as Acamol (Tylenol).They studied why the disease pathway in Italy is more serious
column6: finding that most patients took ibuprofen at home.Researchers joined the virus and ibuprofen in the laboratory and came to the conclusion that administering ibuprofen accelerates multiplication of the virus and is related to a more serious course of the disease."

column4: 2020 -- Three American professional cardiology societies have issued a joint statement urging continuation of renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) antagonists in patients
column5: despite theoretical concerns that their use might worsen outcomes in the event of infection with COVID-19.The new statement was issued jointly by the American Heart Association (AHA)
column6: American College of Cardiology (ACC)
column7: and HeartFailure Society of America (HFSA) on March 17.It follows similar recent statements from the European Society of Cardiology (ESC)
column8: as reported yesterday by Medscape Medical News
column9: and the European Society of Hypertension
column10: Canadian Cardiovascular Society
column11: and International Society of Hypertension
column12: among others.""We understand the concern — as it has become clear that people with cardiovascular disease are at much higher risk of serious complications including death from COVID-19
column13: said AHA president Robert A. Harrington
column14: MD
column15: chair of the department of medicine at Stanford University
column16: California
column17: in a statement.""However
column18: we have reviewed the latest research — the evidence does not confirm the need to discontinue ACE inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARBs)
column19: and we strongly recommend all physicians to consider the individual needs of each patient before making any changes to ACE inhibitors or ARB treatment regimens."""

column3: Editor
column4: Relias Media Patients with cardiovascular disease are at a higher risk for serious complications if they contract COVID-19.Thus
column5: three leading cardiology groups this week recommended patients with heart disease
column6: heart failure
column7: and hypertension continue taking prescribed medications for those conditions if they contract the novel coronavirus
column8: unless otherwise directed.The American Heart Association (AHA)
column9: the Heart Failure Society of America
column10: and the American College of Cardiology (ACC) jointly published a statement
column11: calling out two drugs specifically: angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE-i) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).“We have reviewed the latest research.The evidence does not confirm the need to discontinue ACE-i or ARBs
column12: and we strongly recommend all physicians to consider the individual needs of each patient before making any changes to ACE-i or ARB treatment regimens
column13: ” AHA President Robert A. Harrington
column14: MD
column15: FAHA
column16: said."

column1: 30 4691085c-10fb-42f6-ab61-56fb7ad278e8 "Handling the economic damage John Redwood's Diary Speaking for England Skip to content Home About Books Contact Photos Local Issues Debates History Video Gallery Press Releases Articles « Heading for a big economic downturn worldwide Help the self employed » Handling the economic damage By johnredwood | Published: March 24
column2: 2020 The epidemiologists advising the government have succeeded in  persuading them to lock down as much of the country as possible.The aim is to stop the spread
column3: and so reduce the numbers needing hospital treatment.The earlier policy of trace and isolate did not prevent escalation
column4: though it may have slowed the progress of the disease as the advisers hoped.Given this
column5: the best outcome now must be a severe but short lived clampdown with a resulting drop in numbers getting the disease
column6: followed by some relaxations to get more people back into work.The worst outcome would be little progress with getting numbers down and a decision to carry on with many closures in the hope that the policy will sometime start to work as planned.A middle course is likely with a longer period of clampdown and some success with braking the rate of increase."

column6: 2020 -- The American Heart Association (AHA) has issued new guidance for patients with hypertension during the COVID-19 outbreak.At the same time
column7: several new review articles have been published further exploring the possible relationship between the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) and the virus.The AHA guidance
column8: titled ""What people with high blood pressure need to know about COVID-19
column9: notes that individuals with raised blood pressure may face an increased risk for severe complications if they are infected with the virus.Data from the outbreak in Wuhan
column10: China
column11: shows a 10.5% death rate among people with COVID-19 who also have cardiovascular disease
column12: 7.3% for those with diabetes
column13: 6.3% for those with respiratory disease
column14: 6% for those with high blood pressure
column15: and 5.6% for those with cancer."

column2: 27 March
column3: 2020 - 08:31 Experts are urging people with high blood pressure to keep taking their medications as usual during the COVID-19 epidemic.Some patients have been expressing concerns to doctors after the idea started circulating on social media that two common hypertension (high blood pressure) drugs could lead to more severe cases of COVID-19.However
column4: a high-powered group of doctors and scientists in Aotearoa New Zealand have scrutinised the evidence for this theory and determined it is weak and should be disregarded.The Specialist Hypertension Research Network of the North Island of Aotearoa has released a consensus statement
column5: endorsed by Heart Foundation Medical Director and University of Auckland Associate Professor Gerry Devlin
column6: and Heart Foundation Chair
column7: University of Auckland Professor Rob Doughty.It recommends patients keep taking their blood pressure medications as prescribed by their doctors
column8: in line with the latest expert advice from international specialist bodies.One of the statement authors is University of Auckland Professor Julian Paton
column9: Director of Manaaki MÄnawa - The Heart Research Centre."

column4: 2020 -- The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has issued a statement advising that patients continue treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)
column5: despite widely circulated reports that the agents could worsen coronavirus disease.""It is important that patients do not interrupt their treatment with ACE inhibitors or ARBs and there is no need to switch to other medicines
column6: the agency said today.""There is currently no evidence from clinical or epidemiological studies that establishes a link between ACE inhibitors or ARBs and the worsening of COVID-19.""The new guidance is in line with that recently issued by the European Society of Cardiology and three American cardiology societies.The medications are commonly used by patients with hypertension
column7: heart failure
column8: and kidney disease."

column2: 2020 / 10:07 AM / Updated 21 minutes agoBlood-pressure drugs are in the crosshairs of COVID-19 researchDeborah J. Nelson8 Min Read(Reuters) - Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body - killing many patients while barely affecting others.FILE PHOTO: A member of the French Civil Protection service measures blood pressure of a man suspected of being infected with the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)
column3: as its spread continues
column4: in Paris
column5: France
column6: April 5
column7: 2020.REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File PhotoBut some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19
column8: the disease caused by the virus
column9: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable – and what patients should do about it – have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it."

column2: Leo Galland M.D.
column3: has authored this information on what he recommends at coronavirus protection options.He says he has written this to supply useful and practical information for those concerned about the present coronavirus epidemic and also to correct some misinformation that is circulating: BACKGROUND: AN EMERGING PICTURECorona viruses are a family of viruses made from RNA instead of DNA.There are many species that produce respiratory and gastrointestinal illness in humans and animals.Four strains cause the common cold.The pandemic corona virus
column4: COVID-19
column5: first identified in Wuhan
column6: China
column7: has certain distinctive features
column8: some of which are receiving attention in the media: Chinese data indicate that 80% of infected people have minimal symptoms and do not seek medical attention
column9: whereas 15% become moderately to severely ill with cough and shortness of breath and 5% require intensive care."

column5: as opposed to general anti-viral measures

column1: 30 6060b988-2dac-4258-a170-89447e815f63 "What Does Elevated Troponin Mean in COVID-19?| MedPage Today menu Sign Up Log In Edit Profile Manage Subscriptions CME Tracker Log Out Home Specialties Back Allergy & Immunology Anesthesiology Cardiology Critical Care Dermatology Emergency Medicine Endocrinology Gastroenterology Genetics Geriatrics HIV / AIDS Hospital-Based Medicine Infectious Disease Nephrology Neurology Nursing OB / GYN Oncology / Hematology Ophthalmology Orthopedics Pain Management Pathology Pediatrics Primary Care Psychiatry Pulmonology Radiology Rheumatology Surgery Transplantation Urology CME/CE Health Policy Meetings COVID-19 Videos Opinion Condition Centers Careers Society Partners Back AAD Reading Room ACR Reading Room AGA Reading Room ASCO Reading Room Endocrine Society Reading Room IDSA Reading Room search enter search terms Infectious Disease > COVID-19 What Does Elevated Troponin Mean in COVID-19?— Roughly one in five admitted in Wuhan had apparent cardiac injury by Nicole Lou
column2: Staff Writer
column3: MedPage Today March 25
column4: 2020 MedpageToday share to facebook share to twitter share to linkedin email article Cardiac injury was common among those hospitalized for COVID-19 and found to be associated with a several-fold increase in mortality risk
column5: according to a hospital in Wuhan
column6: China.Abnormally high levels of high-sensitivity cardiac troponin I (above the 99th-percentile upper reference limit) were observed in 19.7% of consecutive patients with lab-confirmed COVID-19
column7: reported Bo Yang
column8: MD
column9: PhD
column10: of Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University
column11: and colleagues in a paper published online in JAMA Cardiology.COVID-19 was more severe when accompanied by cardiac injury
column12: as these patients were:More likely to require noninvasive mechanical ventilation (46.3% vs 3.9%
column13: P<0.001) or invasive mechanical ventilation (22.0% vs 4.2%
column14: P<0.001) than those without cardiac injuryMore likely to have complications
column15: including acute respiratory distress syndrome
column16: acute kidney injury
column17: electrolyte disturbances
column18: hypoproteinemia
column19: and coagulation disordersA higher mortality risk (51.2% vs 4.5%)
column20: whether considered by time from symptom onset (HR 4.26
column21: 95% CI 1.92-9.49) or from admission to end of follow-up (HR 3.41
column22: 95% CI 1.62-7.16)The retrospective cohort study included 416 patients with sufficient medical records and lab results from Jan. 20 to Feb. 10 of this year
column23: with last follow-up on Feb. 15.COVID-19 patients who showed signs of cardiac injury tended to be older and have more comorbidities (such as a history of coronary heart disease and hypertension) compared with peers who didn't have cardiac injury."

column2: several new pieces of information are becoming available.Although high quality research trials are still limited

column1: 30 64934b99-d574-45f0-a2f0-bc4f6e98aab6 "Coronavirus | Do anti-hypertensive drugs raise the risk for COVID-19 patients?- The Hindu 15 Sci-Tech Health Health Coronavirus | Do anti-hypertensive drugs raise the risk for COVID-19 patients?White pad next to a manometer to measure blood pressure and a stethoscope in a hospital
column2: conceptual image | Photo Credit: digicomphoto G. Ananthakrishnan Chennai 20 March 2020 02:27 IST Updated: 20 March 2020 02:28 IST Patients have been told not to discontinue their medication One of the concerns highlighted during the COVID-19 pandemic is whether the use of several common hypertension treatment drugs — coming under the class of Angiotensin-Controlling Enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) — raises risks for patients who contract the novel coronavirus.The issue gained importance in social media and elsewhere
column3: as some reports from severely affected countries such as Italy indicated a poor outcome for COVID-19 patients who have been taking these drugs for an underlying condition.Also read: Interactive map of confirmed coronavirus cases in IndiaAdvertising AdvertisingThe top United States immunologist handling the pandemic
column4: Dr. Anthony Fauci
column5: director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
column6: said in an interaction with the Journal of the American Medical Association on Wednesday that based on extrapolation of available knowledge
column7: putting a patient on an ACE inhibitor could result in an increase in the expression of the enzyme
column8: which is to say
column9: the person taking the drug for hypertension may be
column10: without knowing it
column11: increasing the reception for the virus itself.Entry pointThat is because Angiotensin Converting Enzyme2 (ACE2) receptors have been shown to be the entry point into human cells for SARS-CoV-2
column12: according to medical literature.But
column13: Dr. Fauci said
column14: that was an extrapolation
column15: and not based on data.“It is a possibility that we need to address
column16: ” he said
column17: calling for studies in the wake of media reports from Italy that said 99% of people who died had an underlying condition
column18: and in 75% of these cases
column19: that condition was hypertension.Also read: Coronavirus | The importance of ‘contact tracing’Given the high medical care standards in Italy
column20: he reasoned
column21: if hypertension was an underlying condition
column22: it was bound to have been treated and patients maintained well.Also
column23: if the data appeared skewed towards the condition in spite of this
column24: the cause would have to be investigated
column25: he said.On the same issue
column26: the European Society of Cardiology (ESC)
column27: citing initial data from China
column28: issued a position statement on March 13.It said a concern had arisen because it was observed that just as in the case of the coronavirus causing SARS [Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome]
column29: “the COVID-19 virus binds to a specific enzyme called ACE2 to infect cells
column30: and ACE2 levels are increased following treatment with ACE-i and ARBs.” Watch | Soap or sanitiser?Which works better?"

column1: 30 6729d887-4e32-47e9-9a04-32feac7d1135 "auckland.scoop.co.nz » Blood Pressure Meds Won’t Make COVID-19 Worse Scoop Search Contact Newsagent Login Supercity Business Education Entertainment Health Police Politics Tweet Blood Pressure Meds Won’t Make COVID-19 Worse March 27
column2: 2020Health
column3: PressRelease0 comments Press Release – University of Auckland Experts are urging people with high blood pressure to keep taking their medications as usual during the COVID-19 epidemic.Some patients have been expressing concerns to doctors after the idea started circulating on social media that two common hypertension (high blood pressure) drugs could lead to more severe cases of COVID-19.However
column4: a high-powered group of doctors and scientists in Aotearoa New Zealand have scrutinised the evidence for this theory and determined it is weak and should be disregarded.The Specialist Hypertension Research Network of the North Island of Aotearoa has released a consensus statement
column5: endorsed by Heart Foundation Medical Director and University of Auckland Associate Professor Gerry Devlin
column6: and Heart Foundation Chair
column7: University of Auckland Professor Rob Doughty.It recommends patients keep taking their blood pressure medications as prescribed by their doctors
column8: in line with the latest expert advice from international specialist bodies.One of the statement authors is University of Auckland Professor Julian Paton
column9: Director of Manaaki Mānawa – The Heart Research Centre."

column1: 30 6c849b65-c1f7-46f2-a289-2530d727151e "Blood-pressure drugs are in the crosshairs of COVID-19 research | Physician's Weekly ×Claim Your Free Staff Education Wallboard!Email-id is invalid For latest News and updates Sign UpLog In HomeSpecialtiesAllergy & ImmunologyCardiologyCritical CareDermatologyEndocrinologyGastroenterologyInfectious DiseaseNephrologyNeurologyOB/GYNOncology / HematologyOphthalmologyOrthopedicsPain ManagementPediatricsPrimary CarePsychiatryPulmonologyRheumatologySurgeryUrologyDoctor’s VoiceMeeting CoverageContinuing Education#PWChatCovid-19 Select Page Advertisement Blood-pressure drugs are in the crosshairs of COVID-19 researchPosted by Reuters | Apr 23
column2: 2020By Deborah J. Nelson(Reuters) – Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body – killing many patients while barely affecting others.But some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19
column3: the disease caused by the virus
column4: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable – and what patients should do about it – have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it.Resolving that question has taken on new urgency after an April 8 report by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that 72% of hospitalized COVID-19 patients 65 or older had hypertension.The drugs are known as ACE inhibitors and ARBs
column5: broad categories that include Vasotec
column6: Valsartan
column7: Irbesartan
column8: as well as their generic versions.In a recent interview with a medical journal
column9: Anthony Fauci – the U.S. government’s top infectious disease expert – cited a report showing similarly high rates of hypertension among COVID-19 patients who died in Italy and suggested the medicines
column10: rather than the underlying condition
column11: may act as an accelerant for the virus.Efforts to understand how the virus uses the pathway to the heart and lungs
column12: and the role of the medicines
column13: are complicated by a lack of rigorous studies.“There are millions of Americans that take an ACE inhibitor or AR daily
column14: ” said Dr Caleb Alexander
column15: co-director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Drug Safety and Effectiveness in Baltimore."

column4: MDApr 23 2020 A new study published in the journal JAMA Cardiology in April 2020 reports that patients with hypertension who are taking medications called ACE inhibitors (ACEI) or ARBs are not at higher risk for death or more severe illness with COVID-19.This conclusion supports current guidelines for the treatment of hypertension during this pandemic.COVID-19 and ACE2 receptors Patients with COVID-19 are mostly not very sick and recover after a self-limiting illness.However
column5: in some patients with underlying medical conditions
column6: such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus
column7: the illness becomes severe and may lead to death.Recently
column8: the discovery has been made that the virus gains entry into the cell via the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) 2 molecule on the cell surface."

column4: 2020 -- The European Society of Cardiology (ESC) has issued a statement urging physicians and patients to continue treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)
column5: in light of a newly described theory that those agents could increase the risk of developing COVID-19 and/or worsen its severity.The concern arises from the observation that the new coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 causing COVID-19 binds to angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) to infect cells
column6: and both ACE inhibitors and ARBs increase ACE2 levels.This mechanism has been theorized as a possible risk factor for facilitating the acquisition of COVID-19 infection and worsening its severity.However
column7: paradoxically
column8: it has also been hypothesized to protect against acute lung injury from the disease.Meanwhile
column9: a Lancet Respiratory Medicine article was published March 11 entitled
column10: ""Are patients with hypertension and diabetes mellitus at increased risk for COVID-19 infection?"""

column1: 30 76a917c3-6b95-4318-b5a4-7a3250614513 "High blood pressure patients

column4: do not stop your medicationsBy Indian Link - March 23
column5: 202007The Heart Foundation is calling for the estimated three million Australian adults on high blood pressure medication to continue taking their medicines as prescribed
column6: despite claims that some types of blood pressure tablets increase the risk of COVID-19.Some international researchers have suggested that the use of commonly prescribed ARB and ACE inhibitor medications can increase a person’s risk of infection
column7: severe illness or death from COVID-19.The suggested link between COVID-19 and these medications is based on the observation that they increase levels of the ‘ACE2’ enzyme in the body
column8: the same enzyme that the coronavirus uses to infect the body.However
column9: Heart Foundation Chief Medical Adviser
column10: cardiologist Professor Garry Jennings said at this stage
column11: there is no evidence from people infected with the COVID-19 virus to confirm this theory and advises Australians to continue to take their medications as prescribed.“Continue to take all your medicines
column12: including ARBs or ACE inhibitors
column13: as prescribed by your doctor
column14: ” Professor Jennings said.The medications
column15: ARB (angiotensin receptor blocker) and ACE (angiotensin converting enzyme) inhibitors are used to treat high blood pressure
column16: as well as in cases of heart failure and in treatment following a heart attack.“These medications are widely used and considered safe.They have important benefits in treating high blood pressure and in reducing the risk of illness and death in many chronic health conditions
column17: including heart failure.”More than three million Australians take anti-hypertensive medications
column18: the equivalent to three in 10 Australian adults (hypertension is the medical name for high blood pressure).It’s estimated that more than six million Australians have high blood pressure (34% or 1 in 3) – a major risk factor for coronary heart disease
column19: which is Australia’s single biggest killer.Professor Jennings said stopping prescribed medicine could do more harm than good: “The dangers of suddenly stopping your blood pressure medications are clear and well known whereas the interaction of these types of medicines with COVID-19 is hypothetical and unproven
column20: ” he said.The Heart Foundation along with other international authorities is closely monitoring the emerging experience on COVID-19 and cardiovascular disease.“It’s understandable to feel anxious when there are reports about possible harms from medications."

column2: 27 March 2020
column3: 8:40 am Press Release: University of Auckland Experts are urging people with high blood pressure to keep taking their medications as usual during the COVID-19 epidemic.Some patients have been expressing concerns to doctors after the idea started circulating on social media that two common hypertension (high blood pressure) drugs could lead to more severe cases of COVID-19.However
column4: a high-powered group of doctors and scientists in Aotearoa New Zealand have scrutinised the evidence for this theory and determined it is weak and should be disregarded.The Specialist Hypertension Research Network of the North Island of Aotearoa has released a consensus statement
column5: endorsed by Heart Foundation Medical Director and University of Auckland Associate Professor Gerry Devlin
column6: and Heart Foundation Chair
column7: University of Auckland Professor Rob Doughty.It recommends patients keep taking their blood pressure medications as prescribed by their doctors
column8: in line with the latest expert advice from international specialist bodies.One of the statement authors is University of Auckland Professor Julian Paton
column9: Director of Manaaki Mānawa – The Heart Research Centre.“Scientists around the world are racing right now to gather and make sense of COVID-19 data
column10: ” he says.“Inevitably
column11: there will be some false starts
column12: some dead ends.Going by the best evidence available right now
column13: this seems to be one of them.”The source of the idea was speculation made by several scientists in letters to prominent medical journals
column14: BMJ and Lancet Respiratory Medicine.The scientists had noticed that COVID-19 patients with existing conditions such as hypertension and diabetes had more severe symptoms."

column5: 2020 (HealthDay News) -- Could a blood pressure or diabetes medicine make COVID-19 more severe?A proposed new theory says the coronavirus could be binding to angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptors in the lower respiratory tracts.Commonly used drugs ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)
column6: often used to control heart failure and blood pressure
column7: can increase the number of ACE2 receptors in the body -- making these patients more susceptible to severe COVID-19.Dr. James Diaz
column8: a professor at Louisiana State University's School of Public Health in New Orleans
column9: warned of the possible risk in a letter to the editor published online March 24 in the Journal of Travel Medicine
column10: based on an analysis of nearly 1
column11: 100 COVID-19 patients by Chinese researchers."

column22: scientists claimACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may lead to worse illnessPatients should not stop taking their medication unless their doctor says so The pills increase amounts of an enzyme the coronavirus uses to infect the bodyExperts said patients with high blood pressure or diabetes should be monitoredCoronavirus symptoms: what are they and should you see a doctor?By Sam Blanchard Senior Health Reporter For Mailonline Published: 07:53 EDT
column23: 13 March 2020 | Updated: 07:54 EDT
column24: 13 March 2020 e-mail View comments People with high blood pressure and diabetes could be at higher risk of severe or fatal coronavirus symptoms because of how their medicines work
column25: scientists say.Drugs called ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may change the shape of someone's cells in a way that makes it easier for the coronavirus to infect them.The common medications were prescribed almost 65million times in England last year and cost the NHS more than £100m.A paper published in prestigious British medical journal The Lancet Respiratory Medicine studied how the coronavirus latches on to people's cells to infect them.But a doctor has warned that patients who take the medicines must not stop doing so – they should speak to their doctor if they have concerns.Other risk factors for severe or deadly coronavirus infection include age – over-80s are most likely to die – and heart disease.People with weak immune systems
column26: such as cancer patients
column27: or those with long-term lung conditions are also at higher risk but are by no means guaranteed to get seriously ill.It comes as the number of confirmed coronavirus patients in the UK has hit 590 and 10 people have died – the Government says 5
column29: 000 people may be infected.Scientists said medicines taken by thousands of people could increase the risk of a coronavirus patient developing deadly symptoms (stock image)The article was published by scientists at University Hospital Basel
column30: in Switzerland
column31: and the University of Thessaloniki in Greece.It explains that the coronavirus sticks to cells and attacks them by latching onto something called angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2).Some people with high blood pressure or type 1 or type 2 diabetes have to take drugs which increase the amount of ACE2 that they have on their cells
column32: in order to control their illness.The drugs studied were ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).The most prescribed versions of these in England are Ramipril
column33: Losartan
column35: according to NHS data.RELATED ARTICLES Previous 1 Next EXCLUSIVE: Grand Princess cruise British couple tell of..."

column2: warn against discontinuation International Business Times
column3: Singapore Edition Asia Pacific World Technology Business Sports Entertainment Science Coronavirus Science Heart and kidney medicines do not increase coronavirus risk say doctors
column4: warn against discontinuationResearchers warn that there is no substantiated evidence to prove that the consumption of crucial life-saving prescriptions increases the risk of COVID-19 By Jeevan Biswas Updated March 28
column5: 2020 23:47 +08 Close UK PM Boris Johnson tests positive for Coronavirus As the COVID-19 pandemic gains unprecedented momentum
column6: fake news and misinformation are spreading on social media.From phony cures to unscientific claims
column7: there seems to be no dearth of inaccurate medical information.A new study highlights one particular piece of information that is doing the rounds that can prove fatal for several people — patients on certain medications to treat heart and kidney diseases are at a larger risk of contracting the disease.Researchers from the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine warn that there is no substantiated evidence to prove that the consumption of crucial life-saving prescriptions —angiotensin II type 1 receptor blockers (ARBs) and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors — can make one more susceptible to coronavirus.This could potentially put millions of lives at risk as these drugs are commonly prescribed for those suffering from cardiovascular conditions
column8: renal ailments
column9: and hypertension.""The only thing we can conclude definitively
column10: based on all the known data
column11: is that there is no credible evidence whatsoever that ARBs enhance susceptibility to COVID
column12: said Dr. Murray Epstein
column13: senior author of the paper.Representational Picture Pixabay What is the basis of the misinformation?Research on the SARS-CoV-2 virus has found that the lethal virus gains entry into lung cells by binding with angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptors in the lower respiratory tracts of patients who are infected with the disease.Some studies have suggested that the ARBs increase the presence of the ACE2 receptors in the cardiopulmonary circulation or blood circulation within the lungs.Fulled by media coverage and misinformation on social media
column14: significant numbers of patients have discontinued these medications either on the basis of their own judgment or after being advised by their doctors
column15: the authors said."

column3: 2020 6:00AM EDT Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body - killing many patients while barely affecting others.By Deborah J. Nelson April 23 (Reuters) - Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body - killing many patients while barely affecting others.But some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19
column4: the disease caused by the virus
column5: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable – and what patients should do about it – have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it."

column15: 2020 at 1:10 pm Share: Share this restaurant in Twitter Share this restaurant in Facebook Share this restaurant in WhatsApp Share this restaurant in Messenger Share this restaurant by email 0 There is no evidence that taking vital medicines for high blood pressure and other conditions will create somehow increase COVID-19 complications or the chances of contracting the virus
column16: Superintendent for Public Health Charmaine Gauci has said.“There have been a number of studies that show that there is no evidence that high-blood pressure medicines have a link to complications if you catch COVID-19.I would rather make an appeal and warning for those who have high blood pressure to continue taking their medicine."

column6: leading to patient anxiety and uncertainty about whether to keep taking these medications.Doctors report being inundated with calls from panicked patients who want to discontinue treatment."
