column29: as well as their generic versions.Reuters @moneycontrolcom Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body - killing many patients while barely affecting others.But some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19
column30: the disease caused by the virus
column31: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable  and what patients should do about it have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it.Resolving that question has taken on new urgency after an April 8 report by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that 72% of hospitalized COVID-19 patients 65 or older had hypertension.Close The drugs are known as ACE inhibitors and ARBs
column32: broad categories that include Vasotec
column33: Valsartan
column35: as well as their generic versions.In a recent interview with a medical journal
column36: Anthony Fauci - the U.S. government's top infectious disease expert - cited a report showing similarly high rates of hypertension among COVID-19 patients who died in Italy and suggested the medicines
column38: may act as an accelerant for the virus."

column2: we may earn an affiliate commission.Learn more Home News The mysterious connection between the coronavirus and the heart By Yasemin Saplakoglu - Staff Writer 08 April 2020 Doctors say some patients with COVID-19 can have heart damage.Shares Comments (0) (Image: © Shutterstock) The novel coronavirus mainly attacks the lungs.But doctors have been increasingly reporting cases of another battlefield raging within the body: the heart.More than 1 in 5 patients develop heart damage as a result of COVID-19 in Wuhan
column3: China
column4: one small study published March 27 in the journal JAMA Cardiology suggested.While some of these patients have a history of heart conditions

column1: 30 a088fba6-92a3-486d-a891-2717f54fee74 "Are patients with hypertension and diabetes mellitus at increased risk for COVID-19 infection?⋆ The Savage Nation Advertisements Skip to content Top Menu HOME Podcast HOW TO LISTEN JOIN Advertise About Savage Archives Photos Savage’s Eye Camera Teddy’s Corner Main Menu Are patients with hypertension and diabetes mellitus at increased risk for COVID-19 infection?Share on facebookTweet on twitter THE LANCET The most distinctive comorbidities of 32 non-survivors from a group of 52 intensive care unit patients with novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in the study by Xiaobo Yang and colleagues1 were cerebrovascular diseases (22%) and diabetes (22%).Another study2 included 1099 patients with confirmed COVID-19
column2: of whom 173 had severe disease with comorbidities of hypertension (23·7%)
column3: diabetes mellitus (16·2%)
column4: coronary heart diseases (5·8%)
column5: and cerebrovascular disease (2·3%).In a third study
column6: 3 of 140 patients who were admitted to hospital with COVID-19
column7: 30% had hypertension and 12% had diabetes.Notably
column8: the most frequent comorbidities reported in these three studies of patients with COVID-19 are often treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; however
column9: treatment was not assessed in either study."

column4: M.D.Dr. David Dunaief Hypertension (high blood pressure) and COVID-19 are intertwined.Those who have hypertension are more susceptible to COVID-19 and are more likely to get a severe form and experience complications from the virus.A study done in China captured the statistics: of 1099 patients infected
column5: 15 percent had hypertension
column6: and of those with severe cases
column7: 23.7 percent had hypertension (1).Ultimately
column8: those with hypertension are at higher risk

column3: confusion has persisted over whether it’s safe to take Ibuprofen for symptoms related to COVID-19.The World Health Organization
column4: which earlier this week recommended against taking Ibuprofen
column5: indicated Thursday that it was walking back that advice.""WHO is aware of concerns on the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (i.e.
column6: ibuprofen) for the treatment of fever for people with COVID-19
column7: ” said a statement from the organization.“At present
column8: after a rapid review of the literature
column9: WHO is not aware of published clinical or population-based data on this topic.We are consulting with physicians treating COVID-19 patients and are not aware of reports of any negative effects of ibuprofen
column10: beyond the usual known side effects that limit its use in certain populations.Based on currently available information
column11: WHO does not recommend against the use of ibuprofen.”AdvertisementThursday’s statement from the WHO followed an earlier comment from a spokesman for the organization
column12: who told reporters in Geneva Tuesday that the group was looking into a recent article published in The Lancet Respiratory Medicine suggesting Ibuprofen may not be safe
column13: Science Alert reported.“In the meantime
column14: we recommend using rather paracetamol
column15: and do not use ibuprofen as a self-medication."

Nelson8 Min Read(Reuters) - Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body - killing many patients while barely affecting others.FILE PHOTO: A member of the French Civil Protection service measures blood pressure of a man suspected of being infected with the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)
column3: as its spread continues
column4: in Paris

column6: April 5
column7: 2020.REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File PhotoBut some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19
column8: the disease caused by the virus
column9: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable – and what patients should do about it – have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it."

column5: Ph.D.Apr 9 2020 Emerging concerns that common antihypertensive treatment approaches with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) – jointly known as renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitors – may exert a negative effect in COVID-19 patients are not grounded in scientific evidence
column6: as reported by researchers in a recent review article published in Mayo Clinic Proceedings journal.The worldwide public health crisis due to the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) that causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is considered the worst pandemic outbreak of modern times.Many health care systems around the world are overwhelmed by high numbers of patients requiring intensive care
column7: especially those with hypertension and other underlying health conditions.Interplay between the virus
column8: receptors
column9: and drugs It is known that angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) acts as a homolog of ACE and a functional receptor for coronaviruses – including SARS-CoV-2.Although found in many organ systems throughout the human body
column10: it is densely distributed in the lungs and on lymphocytes; hence
column11: contributing to the prevalent lung involvement in COVID-19 (primary interstitial pneumonia
column12: acute respiratory distress syndrome
column13: or ARDS
column14: and lymphopenia)."

column4: 2020 -- Initial data from one Chinese center on the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) in patients hospitalized with COVID-19 appear to give some further reassurance about continued use of these drugs.The report from one hospital in Wuhan found that among patients with hypertension hospitalized with the COVID-19 virus
column5: there was no difference in disease severity or death rate in patients taking ACE inhibitors or ARBs and those not taking such medications.The data were published online April 23 in JAMA Cardiology.The study adds to another recent report in a larger number of COVID-19 patients from nine Chinese hospitals that suggested a beneficial effect of ACE inhibitors or ARBs on mortality."

column2: 2020 In News Summary Leave a comment facebook tweet google+ There is plenty of information floating around the Internet about what medications may or may not be useful in treating the symptoms associated with COVID-19.The extent of the pandemic
column3: coupled with our digital capabilities
column4: is leading to a tremendous quantity of information reaching both individuals and healthcare workers regarding COVID-19.In this ever-evolving situation
column5: it’s important to stay updated with information from reliable sources.It has been reported that the use of ibuprofen could worsen the severity of COVID-19 for individuals diagnosed with the disease."

column19: scientists claimACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may lead to worse illnessPatients should not stop taking their medication unless their doctor says so The pills increase amounts of an enzyme the coronavirus uses to infect the bodyExperts said patients with high blood pressure or diabetes should be monitoredCoronavirus symptoms: what are they and should you see a doctor?By Sam Blanchard Senior Health Reporter For Mailonline Published: 07:53 EDT
column20: 13 March 2020 | Updated: 07:54 EDT
column21: 13 March 2020 e-mail View comments People with high blood pressure and diabetes could be at higher risk of severe or fatal coronavirus symptoms because of how their medicines work
column22: scientists say.Drugs called ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may change the shape of someone's cells in a way that makes it easier for the coronavirus to infect them.The common medications were prescribed almost 65million times in England last year and cost the NHS more than £100m.A paper published in prestigious British medical journal The Lancet Respiratory Medicine studied how the coronavirus latches on to people's cells to infect them.But a doctor has warned that patients who take the medicines must not stop doing so – they should speak to their doctor if they have concerns.Other risk factors for severe or deadly coronavirus infection include age – over-80s are most likely to die – and heart disease.People with weak immune systems
column23: such as cancer patients
column24: or those with long-term lung conditions are also at higher risk but are by no means guaranteed to get seriously ill.It comes as the number of confirmed coronavirus patients in the UK has hit 590 and 10 people have died – the Government says 5
column26: 000 people may be infected.Scientists said medicines taken by thousands of people could increase the risk of a coronavirus patient developing deadly symptoms (stock image)The article was published by scientists at University Hospital Basel
column27: in Switzerland
column28: and the University of Thessaloniki in Greece.It explains that the coronavirus sticks to cells and attacks them by latching onto something called angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2).Some people with high blood pressure or type 1 or type 2 diabetes have to take drugs which increase the amount of ACE2 that they have on their cells
column29: in order to control their illness.The drugs studied were ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).The most prescribed versions of these in England are Ramipril
column30: Losartan
column31: Lisinopril and Candesartan
column32: according to NHS data."

column1: 30 d16aea21-ed72-4082-99eb-a9b395156243 "Medicines for high blood pressure & diabetes could raise the risk of deadly coronavirus ⋆ The Savage Nation Advertisements Skip to content Top Menu HOME Podcast HOW TO LISTEN JOIN Advertise About Savage Archives Photos Savage’s Eye Camera Teddy’s Corner Main Menu Medicines for high blood pressure & diabetes could raise the risk of deadly coronavirus Share on facebookTweet on twitter Daily Mail – UK: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may lead to worse illnessThe pills increase amounts of an enzyme the coronavirus uses to infect the bodyExperts said patients with high blood pressure or diabetes should be monitoredPatients should not stop taking their medication unless their doctor says so People with high blood pressure and diabetes could be at higher risk of severe or fatal coronavirus symptoms because of how their medicines work
column2: scientists say.Drugs called ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may change the shape of someone’s cells in a way that makes it easier for the coronavirus to infect them and cause a more severe illness.The common medications were prescribed almost 65million times in England last year and cost the NHS more than £100m.They are given to treat diabetes or high blood pressure and around 10 per cent of people in the UK – some 6.6million – are estimated to take them regularly.Read more at the Daily Mail Advertisements Posted UnderNewsShare on facebookTweet on twitter Post navigation OHIO AND ILLINOIS-ALL RESTAURANTS AND BARS CLOSED!WILL THE NATION BE NEXT?NEED A LAUGH?"

column3: 2020 10:08 am Healthcare The biochemistry of how COVID-19 attacks the body: a synopsis of the medical studies I’ve been doing some reading over the past several weeks
column4: trying to understand how the COVID-19 virus attacks the human body.Below are quotes I found most noteworthy or interesting from these articles.In essence
column5: they indicate that biochemically the novel coronavirus
column6: COVID-19
column7: mainly binds to the ACE-2 receptor of cell surfaces to gain entrance.These are most prevalent in nasal and mucus cells
column8: alveoli (oxygen-exchanging cells in the longs)
column9: and some cells lining the small intestine
column10: which explains why the disease may start as abdominal discomfort in many patients.There are some conditions
column11: especially high blood pressure and diabetes – or
column12: possibly
column13: medications for those conditions – which cause these ACE-2 receptors to be more expressed."

column8: analysis and commentary from academic experts.)Irving Steinberg
column9: University of Southern California (THE CONVERSATION) It has been barely a few weeks since the coronavirus was declared a pandemic.The pace at which the SARS-CoV-2 virus has spread across the globe is jolting
column10: but equally impressive is the speed at which scientists and clinicians have been fighting back.I am a pharmacotherapy specialist and have consulted on infectious disease treatments for decades.I am both exhilarated and worried as I watch the unprecedented pace and implementation of medical research currently being done.Speed is
column11: of course
column12: important when a crisis such as COVID-19 is at hand."

column1: 30 d93f2f44-4739-45ff-8709-53fc933d0d54 "Antihypertensive drugs and risk with COVID-19?| Physician's Weekly ×Claim Your Free Staff Education Wallboard!Email-id is invalid For latest News and updates Sign UpLog In HomeSpecialtiesAllergy & ImmunologyCardiologyCritical CareDermatologyEndocrinologyGastroenterologyInfectious DiseaseNephrologyNeurologyOBGYNOncology / HematologyOphthalmologyOrthopedicsPain ManagementPediatricsPrimary CarePsychiatryPulmonologyRheumatologySurgeryUrologyDoctor’s VoiceMeeting CoverageContinuing Education#PWChatCovid-19 Select Page Antihypertensive drugs and risk with COVID-19?Posted by Physicians Weekly | Apr 1
column2: 2020 Lei Fang and colleagues suggest that clinicians should consider withholding angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) because of a potential increased risk of worse clinical outcomes in patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)
column3: and they suggest calcium channel blockers as an alternative.The hypothesis behind this suggestion is that the entry point for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the ACE2 receptor and that ACEIs and ARBs have the potential to upregulate ACE2.However
column4: data for this mechanism are largely from animal studies of heart tissue.Human data have not consistently shown increased ACE2 levels."

column3: the disease caused by the virus
column4: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable - and what patients should do about it - have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it.Resolving that question has taken on new urgency after an April 8 report by the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention showed that 72 per cent of hospitalised Covid-19 patients 65 or older had hypertension."

column4: MDApr 20 2020 The COVID-19 pandemic has forced clinicians and academicians to intensive research to find evidence for many conventional therapies.A new round-up editorial published in the journal Cardiovascular Research in April 2020 summarizes the current clinical grounds for and against the use of the commonly used angiotensin axis inhibitors in patients with COVID-19.Why is ACE/ARB blockade controversial?"

column20: 13 March 2020 | Updated: 07:54 EDT
column21: 13 March 2020 e-mail View comments People with high blood pressure and diabetes could be at higher risk of severe or fatal coronavirus symptoms because of how their medicines work
column22: scientists say.Drugs called ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers may change the shape of someone's cells in a way that makes it easier for the coronavirus to infect them.The common medications were prescribed almost 65million times in England last year and cost the NHS more than £100m.A paper published in prestigious British medical journal The Lancet Respiratory Medicine studied how the coronavirus latches on to people's cells to infect them.But a doctor has warned that patients who take the medicines must not stop doing so – they should speak to their doctor if they have concerns.Other risk factors for severe or deadly coronavirus infection include age – over-80s are most likely to die – and heart disease.People with weak immune systems
column23: such as cancer patients
column24: or those with long-term lung conditions are also at higher risk but are by no means guaranteed to get seriously ill.It comes as the number of confirmed coronavirus patients in the UK has hit 590 and 10 people have died – the Government says 5
column26: 000 people may be infected.Scientists said medicines taken by thousands of people could increase the risk of a coronavirus patient developing deadly symptoms (stock image)The article was published by scientists at University Hospital Basel
column27: in Switzerland
column28: and the University of Thessaloniki in Greece.It explains that the coronavirus sticks to cells and attacks them by latching onto something called angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2).Some people with high blood pressure or type 1 or type 2 diabetes have to take drugs which increase the amount of ACE2 that they have on their cells
column29: in order to control their illness.The drugs studied were ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).The most prescribed versions of these in England are Ramipril
column30: Losartan
column31: Lisinopril and Candesartan
column32: according to NHS data."

column8: the enzyme that converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II in the lungs and other tissues and organs

column1: 30 e6dcd1e2-5ef1-4976-85ef-e8c1f3ba4111 "Medical groups say heart meds don't worsen new coronavirus symptoms | Health24 advertisement Health 24 Infectious Diseases News Medical Lifestyle Experts Diet & Nutrition Medical Schemes Beyond Beauty Home  >  Medical  >  Infectious Diseases  >  Coronavirus 18 March 2020 Medical groups say heart meds don't worsen new coronavirus symptoms Experts strongly recommend that all physicians consider the individual needs of each patient before making any changes to their heart treatment regimens.0 Two types of heart medications do not make coronavirus infection worse
column2: three major US medical groups say in a new joint statement meant to dispel misinformation about the use of the medications in people with the Covid-19 virus.The American Heart Association (AHA)
column3: the Heart Failure Society of America and the American College of Cardiology (ACC) recommend continuation of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) medications for all patients already prescribed those drugs for heart failure
column4: high blood pressure or heart disease.People with heart disease are already at increased risk for serious complications from the Covid-19 virus
column5: the groups noted.Heart disease patients diagnosed with the coronavirus should ""be fully evaluated before adding or removing any treatments
column6: and any changes to their treatment should be based on the latest scientific evidence and shared decision-making with their physician and health care team""
column7: the experts said in an AHA news release.No adverse outcomes""We understand the concern – as it has become clear that people with cardiovascular disease are at much higher risk of serious complications
column8: including death from Covid-19
column9: said Dr Robert Harrington
column10: AHA president and chair of the department of medicine at Stanford University.""However
column11: we have reviewed the latest research – the evidence does not confirm the need to discontinue ACE [inhibitors] or ARBs
column12: and we strongly recommend all physicians to consider the individual needs of each patient before making any changes to… treatment regimens
column13: Harrington added.The joint statement was published 17 March 2020.According to Dr Richard Kovacs
column14: president of the ACC
column15: ""The continued highest standard of care for cardiovascular disease patients diagnosed with Covid-19 is our top priority
column16: but there are no experimental or clinical data demonstrating beneficial or adverse outcomes among Covid-19 patients using ACE [inhibitors] or ARB medications.""Kovacs is professor of cardiology at Indiana University School of Medicine.""We urge urgent
column17: additional research that can guide us to optimal care for the millions of people worldwide with cardiovascular disease and who may contract Covid-19.These recommendations will be adjusted as needed to correspond with the latest research
column18: Kovacs explained in the statement.READ | Coronavirus: When and how to use masksSEE | How your body is affected by the Covid-19 virusREAD | Coronavirus in SA: All the confirmed casesImage credit: iStock Related articles Intense exercise can trigger heart trouble in the unprepared Like with medicine
column19: it is possible to underdose and overdose on exercise – more is not always better and can lead to cardiac events."

column1: 30 e73b0573-06ed-4db9-8742-575d1e06e503 "INSIGHT-Blood-pressure drugs are in the crosshairs of COVID-19 research Select EditionPacificSouth AsiaEast and South East AsiaEurope and Central AsiaCentral AfricaEast AfricaSouthern Africa West AfricaMiddle East and North AfricaNorth America Latin America and Caribbean HOME NEWS RESEARCH LIVE DISCOURSE BLOG / OPINION SUBMIT PRESS RELEASE About Career Advertisement Team Partnership Knowledge Partnership Media Partnership Contact Us NEWS RESEARCH LIVE DISCOURSE BLOG / OPINION INTERVIEW SUBMIT PRESS RELEASE Agro-Forestry Art & Culture Technology Economy Education Energy Politics Law & Governance Health Science Social Sports Transport Urban Development WASH Advertisement Home News Health Article INSIGHT-Blood-pressure drugs are in the crosshairs of COVID-19 research Reuters | Updated: 23-04-2020 16:05 IST | Created: 23-04-2020 15:31 IST Representative Image Image Credit: ANI Scientists are baffled by how the coronavirus attacks the body - killing many patients while barely affecting others.But some are tantalized by a clue: A disproportionate number of patients hospitalized by COVID-19
column2: the disease caused by the virus
column3: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable – and what patients should do about it – have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it.Resolving that question has taken on new urgency after an April 8 report by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention showed that 72% of hospitalized COVID-19 patients 65 or older had hypertension."

column7: 2020 Share Adjust Comment Print In the past week
column8: there were reports that some common medications might make COVID-19 worse.Many news reports stated that anti-inflammatories like ibuprofen and a class of common blood pressure medications might either make infection more likely or the illness more severe.While the World Health Organization initially put out a press release suggesting that people might want to avoid ibuprofen during the current outbreak
column9: it subsequently withdrew that statement citing insufficient evidence.The blood pressure medication story began with a research letter published in the journal Lancet Respiratory Medicine.It asked
column10: rather provocatively
column11: if patients with hypertension and diabetes were at increased risk of COVID-19 infection.There is little doubt that patients with pre-existing medical conditions are at higher risk if they become infected.Of course
column12: patients with high blood pressure and diabetes are more likely to be older
column13: and age in and of itself would increase that risk
column14: as well."

column9: have high blood pressure.Theories about why the condition makes them more vulnerable – and what patients should do about it – have sparked a fierce debate among scientists over the impact of widely prescribed blood-pressure drugs.Researchers agree that the life-saving drugs affect the same pathways that the novel coronavirus takes to enter the lungs and heart.They differ on whether those drugs open the door to the virus or protect against it."

column6: 2020Patients need to keep taking ACEIs/ARBsAs Covid-19 cases mount
column7: some have raised concern about the use of angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI) or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) because SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes Covid-19) uses the ACE2 receptor to gain entry to targeted cells
column8: and this receptor is “predominantly expressed by epithelial cells of the lung
column9: intestine
column10: kidney
column11: heart
column12: and blood vessels.”The question then became
column13: could treatment with ACEIs or ARBs increase the availability of ACE2 and thus the increase the risk of Covid-19?Media coverage of this issue has raised the possibility that patients may discontinue use of their medications
column14: which would then increase the risk of cardiovascular events
column15: including worsening heart failure or stroke.JAMA Cardiology addressed these concerns in a pair of viewpoint articles — and both make the case that persons taking ACEIs and/or ARBs should continue taking their meds as prescribed
column16: while also supporting the hypothesis that ACEI/ARBs may prove to be beneficial in Covid-19.In their paper

column31: noted that “hypertension
column32: diabetes
column33: and cardiovascular diseases were the most frequent comorbidities in affected patients
column34: and case fatality rates tended to be high in these individuals.”Moreover
column35: patients with those comorbidities are likely to be treated with ACEI and ARBs.“Both ACE and ACE2 belong to the ACE family of dipeptidyl carboxydipeptidases and exert distinct physiological functions.ACE cleaves angiotensin I to angiotensin II
column36: which in turn binds and activates angiotensin II receptor type 1.This activation leads to vasoconstrictive
column40: ACE2 also degrades angiotensin II to angiotensin 1-7 and angiotensin I to angiotensin 1-9."

column6: B.Sc.Apr 29 2020 Researchers in India have conducted a meta-analysis investigating the effects of using angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) on outcomes among patients with COVID-19.They say their data suggest that continuing these treatments among this patient group is not only safe but significantly reduces the risk of severe disease and death.Furthermore
column7: “the findings of this meta-analysis reinforce the recommendations issued by the various agencies to continue ACEi/ARB in patients with comorbidities who contract COVID-19
column8: ” they write.Urgent need for a clinical trial The team of consultant endocrinologists says the findings highlight the urgent need for a randomized controlled trial to confirm the potential beneficial effects of using ACEi/ARB
column9: but that in the meantime their meta-analysis could help to reassure clinicians until further information becomes available.A pre-print version of the paper can be accessed in the medRxiv server
column10: while the article undergoes peer review."

Coastal Section Post your Real Estate Ad Sold On - Rockhampton Obituaries Classifieds Classifieds Real Estate Motoring Jobs Buy & Sell Notices Trades & Services Health & Beauty Personals Businesses for Sale Post an Ad Find Your Local Search by keyword Search by location Search by category Add your business Special Features Capricorn Health Guide The CQU Village Festival Program Mackay Sugar City Sounds My First Year 2020 One Perfect Day CQ Industry APN Network Health Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ Health Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ by Hannah Paine 25th Apr 2020 5:20 PM 0 France is hoping to trial nicotine patches on healthcare workers after a study suggested that smokers may have a lesser chance of catching coronavirus.The surprising findings come despite health officials around the world repeatedly warning that smokers who contract the lung-attacking COVID-19 have a greater risk of severe cases.A study conducted by French researchers at the Pasteur Institute studied close to 700 students
column2: their families and teachers at a school in Crépy-en-Valois
column3: The Telegraph reported.The research found that smokers were four times less likely to catch COVID-19
column4: with only 7.2 per cent of smokers contracting coronavirus while 28 per cent of nonsmokers were infected.Researchers in France believe nicotine may prevent coronavirus.The findings from the Pasteur Institute tie in with research from a Paris hospital
column5: which found a low rate of smokers were admitted with the virus."

column1: 31 02973796-fa75-4a01-8514-c1e5d46770aa "France finds smoking may help you RESIST Covid-19… if you don’t mind dying of something else — The Duran – Blog of Staś Skip to content Blog of Staś Staś France finds smoking may help you RESIST Covid-19… if you don’t mind dying of something else — The Duran Staś Uncategorized April 23
column2: 2020 3 Minutes In a reversal of prevailing Covid-19 wisdom
column3: a French study appears to show smokers are less at risk from the virus
column4: affirming the results of an earlier Chinese study.The data aren’t conclusive – but they’re certainly surprising.Nicotine may protect smokers against the coronavirus
column5: according to a paper published on Tuesday in the French Academy of Sciences’ Biology Reports.Studying 482 patients hospitalized with Covid-19 in Paris’s Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital
column6: the researchers found just 5 percent were daily smokers – far lower than the 25.4 percent of the French population who smoke daily.While the results cannot be considered conclusive evidence for nicotine protecting smokers against coronavirus – the study size is small
column7: and did not include patients in intensive care – they “strongly suggest that daily smokers have a much lower probability of developing a symptomatic or serious infection with Sars-CoV-2 compared to the general population
column8: ” the paper’s authors argue.“Basically

column1: 31 0bdbf383-45db-4238-a93d-d1a1b6a4ee48 "Study: Smokers Appear Less Likely to Be Hospitalised with COVID-19 – True Pundit HomeSponsorFeaturedVideoPoliticsBusinessWorldSecurityTechnologyScienceEntertainmentSportsNews Tips HomeSponsorFeaturedVideoPoliticsBusinessWorldSecurityTechnologyScienceEntertainmentSportsNews Tips Politics
column2: Science 2 hours agoStudy: Smokers Appear Less Likely to Be Hospitalised with COVID-19 by admin 0Share:The study presents an analysis of the current smoking prevalence among hospitalized patients with COVID-19 in China
column3: compared to the population smoking prevalence in China (52.1% in males and 2.7% in females).Through a systematic research of the literature (PubMed) we identified 7 studies examining the clinical characteristics of a total of 2352 hospitalized COVID-19 patients that presented data on the smoking status.The expected number of smokers was calculated using the formula Expected smokers = (males x 0.521) + (females x 0.027).An unusually low prevalence of current smoking was observed among hospitalized COVID-19 patients (8.7%
column4: 95%CI: 7.6-9.9%) compared to the expected prevalence based on smoking prevalence in China (30.3%
column6: P < 0.0001).This preliminary analysis does not support the argument that current smoking is a risk factor for hospitalization for COVID-19
column7: and might even suggest a protective role.The latter could be linked to the down-regulation of ACE2 expression that has been previously known to be induced by smoking.However
column8: other confounding factors need to be considered and the accuracy of the recorded smoking status needs to be determined before making any firm conclusions."

column3: 2020 17SHARESShareTweet A review of scientific studies has added more evidence to the claim that people who smoke might have a lower risk of becoming seriously ill with COVID-19.University College London academics looked at 28 papers and found the proportions of smokers among hospital patients were ‘lower than expected’.One public health professor said there was ‘something weird going on with smoking and coronavirus’ and experts are struggling to explain the connection.One of the studies showed that in the UK the proportion of smokers among COVID-19 patients was just five per cent

column1: 31 1584625d-a004-4a39-8b6c-f87c0453a4f0 "Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ | Central Telegraph Skip to site map Menu premium_icon Subscribe premium_icon Login Hi My Profile Notifications Admin Site Logout Just In News Sport What's On Lifestyle Jobs Motoring Real Estate Obituaries Classifieds 15-30°C Sunny Biloela Biloela Taroom Monto Moura News Local Just In Queensland National World Offbeat CQ Industry Sport Local Sport National Sport Horse Racing NRL AFL Rugby Union Cricket Soccer Netball Golf Lifestyle Entertainment Health Smarter Shopping Parenting Easy Eating Gardening Travel Fashion Dating Photos Buy Photos Video Find your local Search by keyword Search by location Search by category Add Your Business What's On Events Place an Event Gigs Competitions Jobs Jobs News Find a Job Special Reports Post a job Motoring Motoring News Big Rigs Real Estate Real Estate News Search Buy Search Rent Tools & Calculators Home Loans Property Guide Classifieds Real Estate Jobs Motoring Buy & Sell Notices Tributes Trades & Services Personals All Classifieds Obituaries Stud Cattle Directory Health Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ Health Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ by Hannah Paine 25th Apr 2020 5:20 PM 0 France is hoping to trial nicotine patches on healthcare workers after a study suggested that smokers may have a lesser chance of catching coronavirus.The surprising findings come despite health officials around the world repeatedly warning that smokers who contract the lung-attacking COVID-19 have a greater risk of severe cases.A study conducted by French researchers at the Pasteur Institute studied close to 700 students
column2: their families and teachers at a school in Crépy-en-Valois
column3: The Telegraph reported.The research found that smokers were four times less likely to catch COVID-19
column4: with only 7.2 per cent of smokers contracting coronavirus while 28 per cent of nonsmokers were infected.Researchers in France believe nicotine may prevent coronavirus.The findings from the Pasteur Institute tie in with research from a Paris hospital
column5: which found a low rate of smokers were admitted with the virus."

column4: which can cause individuals who have contracted Covid-19 to suffer more severe symptoms.Jean-Pierre Changeux
column5: a renowned French neurobiologist
column6: suggested nicotine may stop the virus from reaching cells in the body.Nicotine may also lessen the overreaction of the immune system that has been seen in the most severe Covid-19 cases.The results coincide with a Chinese study showing that only 12.6 percent of 1

column2: a report that claimed that smokers were less likely to contract coronavirus raised eyebrows last week.The study
column3: by the Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital in Paris

column1: 31 227d6c4f-3cea-4c79-bde4-9beeb50b0218 "France finds smoking may help you RESIST Covid-19… if you don’t mind dying of something else – Infosurhoy Skip to content Infosurhoy Latest Science News and Reports Main Navigation News News Summary Top Stories Technology Economy Entertainment Health Science Sports France finds smoking may help you RESIST Covid-19… if you don’t mind dying of something else By Denis Bedoya  On April 23
column2: 2020 In News Leave a comment facebook tweet google+ In a reversal of prevailing Covid-19 wisdom
column3: a French study appears to show smokers are less at risk from the virus
column4: affirming the results of an earlier Chinese study.The data aren’t conclusive – but they’re certainly surprising.Nicotine may protect smokers against the coronavirus
column5: according to a paper published on Tuesday in the French Academy of Sciences’ Biology Reports.Studying 482 patients hospitalized with Covid-19 in Paris’s Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital
column6: the researchers found just 5 percent were daily smokers – far lower than the 25.4 percent of the French population who smoke daily.While the results cannot be considered conclusive evidence for nicotine protecting smokers against coronavirus – the study size is small
column7: and did not include patients in intensive care – they “strongly suggest that daily smokers have a much lower probability of developing a symptomatic or serious infection with Sars-CoV-2 compared to the general population
column8: ” the paper’s authors argue.“Basically
column9: we have 80 percent fewer smokers in Covid patients than in the general population of the same sex and the same age
column10: ” researcher and internal medicine specialist Zahir Amoura told France Inter on Wednesday."

column1: 31 25ebccb8-bb7e-48f1-8be1-564d42279147 "Smokers 'four times less likely' to contract Covid-19
column2: prompting nicotine patch trials on patients Jump to navigation Smokers 'four times less likely' to contract Covid-19
column3: prompting nicotine patch trials on patients Researchers in France will test nicotine patches on health workers and patients but reiterated smoking could also cause more severe illness By Henry Samuel 23 April 2020 • 5:04pm Researchers at Paris' Pitié-Salpétrière hospital believe nicotine protects cells from coronavirus attack Credit:  Science Photo Library Frontline health workers and patients in France may be given nicotine patches after studies found that four times fewer smokers contracted Covid-19 than non-smokers.It may sound counterintuitive that people who puff on Gauloises are less likely to catch a virus that can cause deadly attacks on the lungs.However
column4: that was the statistical outcome of an in-depth study conducted by the Pasteur Institute
column5: a leading French research centre into the disease.The institute tested almost 700 teachers and pupils of a school in Crépy-en-Valois in one of the hardest-hit areas in France
column6: as well as their families.The “highly accurate” tests found that only 7.2 per cent of smokers from among the adults tested were infected while four times as many non-smokers
column7: some 28 per cent
column8: were infected.Arnaud Fontanet
column9: an epidemiologist at the institute
column10: warned that they were not encouraging people to take up smoking
column11: remarking that those smokers who do catch the virus “risk suffering more complications” than others."

column1: 31 27b9e1ee-31ad-4caf-95b2-7acd469762de "Coronavirus UK: More ‘weird’ proof smokers may be at less risk – Jimmys Post Skip to content Jimmys Post Politics Technology Entertainment Lifestyle Sports Google News Coronavirus UK: More ‘weird’ proof smokers may be at less risk Posted on April 28
column2: 2020 by admin A review of scientific studies has added more evidence to the claim that people who smoke might have a lower risk of becoming seriously ill with COVID-19.University College London academics looked at 28 papers and found the proportions of smokers among hospital patients were ‘lower than expected’.One public health professor said there was ‘something weird going on with smoking and coronavirus‘ and experts are struggling to explain the connection.One of the studies showed that in the UK the proportion of smokers among COVID-19 patients was just five per cent
column3: a third of the national rate of 14.4 per cent.Another found in France the rate was four times lower.In China
column4: a study noted 3.8 per cent of patients were smokers – despite more than half of the population regularly smoking cigarettes."

column3: April 23
column4: 2020 Tweet PARIS
column5: France (AFP)— Nicotine could protect people from contracting the coronavirus
column6: according to new research in France
column7: where further trials are planned to test whether the substance could be used to prevent or treat the deadly illness.� The findings come after researchers at a top Paris hospital examined 343 coronavirus patients along with 139 people infected with the illness with milder symptoms.� They found that a low number of them smoked
column8: compared to smoking rates of around 35 per cent in France's general population.""Among these patients
column9: only five percent were smokers
column10: said Zahir Amoura
column11: the study's co-author and a professor of internal medicine.� The research echoed similar findings published in the New England Journal of Medicine last month that suggested that 12.6 per cent of 1
column12: 000 people infected in China were smokers.�That was a much lower figure than the number of regular smokers in China's general population
column13: about 26 per cent
column14: according to the World Health Organization (WHO).� The theory is that nicotine could adhere to cell receptors
column15: therefore blocking the virus from entering cells and spreading in the body
column16: according to renown neurobiologist Jean-Pierre Changeux from France's Pasteur Institut who also co-authored the study.The researchers are awaiting approval from health authorities in France to carry out further clinical trials.� They plan to use nicotine patches on health workers at the Pitie-Salpetriere hospital in Paris -- where the initial research was conducted -- to see if it protects them against contracting the virus.� They have also applied to use the patches on hospitalised patients to see whether it helps reduce symptoms and also on more serious intensive care patients
column17: Amoura said.� The researchers are looking into whether nicotine could help to prevent ""cytokine storms""
column18: a rapid overreaction of the immune system that scientists think could play a key role in fatal COVID-19 cases.� But with further research needed
column19: experts are not encouraging people to pick up smoking or use nicotine patches as a protective measure against the virus.� ""We must not forget the harmful effects of nicotine
column20: said Jerome Salomon
column21: France's top health official.� ""Those who do not smoke should absolutely not use nicotine substitutes""
column22: which cause side effects and addiction
column23: he warned.Tobacco is the number one killer in France
column24: with an estimated 75
column25: 000 deaths per year linked to smoking.� France is one of the hardest hit countries by the coronavirus in Europe
column26: with more than 21
column27: 000 deaths and over 155
column28: 000 reported infections.� Now you can read the Jamaica Observer ePaper anytime
column29: anywhere.The Jamaica Observer ePaper is available to you at home or at work
column30: and is the same edition as the printed copy available at http://bit.ly/epaperlive ADVERTISEMENT POST A COMMENT HOUSE RULES 1.We welcome reader comments on the top stories of the day."

column3: probably nicotine
column4: could put smokers at a lower risk of getting the disease.The researchers are awaiting approval from French authorities to start clinical trial of nicotine patch on hospitalised patients and the general population at the Pitie Salpetriere hospital.The initial study conducted at Pitie Salpetriere
column5: part of the H�pitaux de Paris
column6: found that daily smokers have much lower probability of developing symptomatic or severe SARS-CoV-2 infection as compared to the general population.‘Reported rates of current smokers among SARS-CoV-2-infected patients are heterogeneous

column1: 31 4038b253-f256-4cf2-bfeb-ba554fc439a6 "Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ | Stanthorpe Border Post Skip to site map Menu premium_icon Subscribe premium_icon Login Hi My Profile Notifications Admin Site Logout Just In News Sport What's On Lifestyle Jobs Motoring Real Estate Obituaries Classifieds 9-23°C Sunny Stanthorpe Stanthorpe Warwick Toowoomba News Local Just In Queensland National World Offbeat Sport Local Sport National Sport Horse Racing NRL AFL Rugby Union Cricket Soccer Netball Golf Lifestyle Entertainment Health Smarter Shopping Parenting Home & Style Easy Eating Gardening Travel Fashion Dating Photos Buy Photos Video Find your local Search by keyword Search by location Search by category Add Your Business What's On Events Place an Event Gigs Competitions Jobs Jobs News Find a Job Special Reports Post a job Motoring Motoring News Big Rigs Real Estate Real Estate News Search Buy Search Rent Tools & Calculators Classifieds Real Estate Jobs Motoring Buy & Sell Notices Tributes Trades & Services Personals All Classifieds Obituaries Health Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ Health Nicotine patches ‘may prevent virus’ by Hannah Paine 25th Apr 2020 5:20 PM 0 France is hoping to trial nicotine patches on healthcare workers after a study suggested that smokers may have a lesser chance of catching coronavirus.The surprising findings come despite health officials around the world repeatedly warning that smokers who contract the lung-attacking COVID-19 have a greater risk of severe cases.A study conducted by French researchers at the Pasteur Institute studied close to 700 students
column2: their families and teachers at a school in Crépy-en-Valois
column3: The Telegraph reported.The research found that smokers were four times less likely to catch COVID-19
column4: with only 7.2 per cent of smokers contracting coronavirus while 28 per cent of nonsmokers were infected.Researchers in France believe nicotine may prevent coronavirus.The findings from the Pasteur Institute tie in with research from a Paris hospital
column5: which found a low rate of smokers were admitted with the virus."

column18: 28 April 2020 e-mail 1 View comments A review of scientific studies has added more evidence to the claim that people who smoke might have a lower risk of becoming seriously ill with COVID-19.University College London academics looked at 28 papers and found the proportions of smokers among hospital patients were 'lower than expected'.One public health professor said there was 'something weird going on with smoking and coronavirus' and experts are struggling to explain the connection.One of the studies showed that in the UK the proportion of smokers among COVID-19 patients was just five per cent
column19: a third of the national rate of 14.4 per cent.Another found in France the rate was four times lower.In China
column20: a study noted 3.8 per cent of patients were smokers - despite more than half of the population regularly smoking cigarettes.When smokers do get diagnosed with the virus
column21: however
column22: they appear to be more likely to get so sick that they need ventilation
column23: two studies in the review showed.Researchers admit that hospitals are probably not recording patients' smoking status properly
column24: potentially because they are too busy
column25: patients are too sick to answer
column26: or because people lie in their answers.But they are struggling to knock down mounting evidence suggesting an apparent protective effect given by cigarettes
column27: which one expert today admitted was 'weird'."

column7: 352 last update: Apr 23 11:40 PM French Researchers Suggest Smoking Reduces Covid-19 Risk Posted 5 hours ago by Raza Rizvi French researchers are all set to test nicotine patches on coronavirus patients after a recent study suggested that smokers might be defying the virus way better than others.A study presented at a major Paris hotel identified that a substance in tobacco – potentially nicotine – might be stopping the tobacco consumers from contracting the virus.They are now awaiting approval for clinical trials.A team of researchers questioned 480 coronavirus patients at Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital in Paris.Among those 350 patients were hospitalized while 50 others had mild symptoms and were allowed to go home.Those in the hospital had a median age of 65 and only 4.4 percent of them were regular smokers."

column13: 22 April 2020 e-mail 32 shares 27 View comments A group of researchers in Paris are planning to examine whether nicotine patches will help prevent - or lessen the effects of - the novel coronavirus.It comes after a French study found that few people hospitalized
column14: or at home
column15: with coronavirus were regular smokers compared to the general population.The team theorized that nicotine could prevent the virus from infecting cells or that nicotine was preventing the immune system from overreacting to the virus
column16: reported The Guardian.To test this theory
column17: scientists plan to put nicotine patches on COVID-19 patients - both in and out of intensive care - and on frontline workers to see if the stimulant has any effect on preventing the spread of the virus.French researchers plan to give nicotine patches (pictured) to hospitalized coronavirus patients
column18: intensive care patients and frontline workers It comes after a study found 4.4% of 350 coronavirus patients hospitalized were regular smokers and 5.3% of 130 patients at home smoked compared to the general population.Pictured: A man wearing a face mask smokes a cigarette in Paris

Ad Find Your Local Search by keyword Search by location Search by category Add your business Special Features Bundaberg Life & Style Seniors Guide to Living APN Network Health France to trial nicotine patches to prevent COVID-19 Health France to trial nicotine patches to prevent COVID-19 by Hannah Paine 25th Apr 2020 5:20 PM 0 France is hoping to trial nicotine patches on healthcare workers after a study suggested that smokers may have a lesser chance of catching coronavirus.The surprising findings come despite health officials around the world repeatedly warning that smokers who contract the lung-attacking COVID-19 have a greater risk of severe cases.A study conducted by French researchers at the Pasteur Institute studied close to 700 students
column2: their families and teachers at a school in Crépy-en-Valois
column3: The Telegraph reported.The research found that smokers were four times less likely to catch COVID-19

column1: 31 58b3327e-a7ef-4d63-9498-f6b94828be46 "Does smoking prevent coronavirus and what is the impact of nicotine?| Metro News News... but not as you know it News Sport Trending News Coronavirus UK World Weird Tech Sport Football Tennis Cricket Boxing UFC Snooker Darts Entertainment Showbiz TV Film Music Gaming Soaps EastEnders Emmerdale Coronation Street Hollyoaks Lifestyle Sex Health Fashion Food Travel Platform Video More Lifestyle Discounts Submit Stuff Competitions Property Jobs Advertise Weather Trending Search Metro Follow us Follow Metro.co.uk on Facebook Follow Metro.co.uk on Twitter Follow Metro.co.uk on Pinterest Follow Metro.co.uk on Instagram 135.6m shares AdvertisementAdvertisementAdvertisement Are smokers less likely to get coronavirus and how does nicotine impact Covid-19?Anna PaulMonday 27 Apr 2020 4:17 pm Share this article via facebookShare this article via twitterShare this article via messengerShare this with Share this article via emailShare this article via flipboardCopy link Close up of male hand take a pack of cigarette.(Credits: Getty Images)It may seem counterintuitive
column2: but last week
column3: a group of researchers in France discovered regular smokers may be less susceptible to catching Covid-19.The research ostensibly defies any logic
column4: especially considering another group of researchers from China previously said smokers are 14 times more likely to develop severe symptoms from the virus.While the study is ongoing
column5: French authorities have limited the sales of nicotine-based products
column6: banning all online sales and only allowing pharmacies to dispense one month’s worth of supplies at a time."

column6: Space & RoboticsStudy finds smoking reduces chance of getting coronavirus symptomsA study has found that smoking significantly reduces the chances of getting symptoms from coronavirus COVID-19Jak Connor | Apr 24
column7: 2020 at 12:32 am CDT (3 mins
column8: 26 secs time to read)There's absolutely no doubt that smoking is one of the unhealthiest things someone can do; it significantly reduces life expectancy and causes numerous health complications.But what if smoking actually stops people from developing symptoms if they have a COVID-19 infection?Well
column9: that might actually be the case as a new study from French doctors has found that those who smoke every day are much less likely to develop a severe COVID-19 infection.A report from The Guardian says that French doctors conducted this study on COVID-19 patients and found that nicotine patches might be the answer we are looking for.According to the Pitie-Salpetriere study
column10: ""Our cross-sectional study strongly suggests that those who smoke every day are much less likely to develop a symptomatic or severe infection with Sars-CoV-2 compared with the general population.The effect is significant.It divides the risk by five for ambulatory patients and by four for those admitted to hospital.We rarely see this in medicine."""

column7: 5:15 ET6 SCIENTISTS are set to give nicotine patches to coronavirus patients as a trial treatment - to see if they will ward off Covid-19.However
column8: experts are urging people that this is not an excuse to smoke or take up smoking
column9: as cigarettes have fatal health risks.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news & updates 6 Researchers are examining the impact of nicotine patches on Covid-19Credit: Getty Images - Getty And the World Health Organisation (WHO) has warned that cigarettes can actually increase the risk of contracting Covid-19 - and smokers may also already have lung disease or reduced lung capacity ""which would greatly increase risk of serious illness"".French researchers are examining the impact of nicotine patches on Covid-19 after a new study claimed few people hospitalised
column10: or at home
column11: with coronavirus were regular smokers compared to the general population.The team suggested that nicotine could prevent the virus from infecting cells or that nicotine was preventing the immune system from overreacting to the virus
column12: according to The Guardian.Despite this
column13: ASH (Action on Smoking and Health) say that these reports suggesting that the percentage of smokers attending hospital for Covid-19 is less than we might have expected are ""uncertain"" and rely on people being able to report on their smoking and healthcare professionals having the time to record it."

column4: 2020 22:26 Get short URLFILE PHOTO.© REUTERS/Leonhard FoegerFollow RT on In a reversal of prevailing Covid-19 wisdom
column5: a French study appears to show smokers are less at risk from the virus
column6: affirming the results of an earlier Chinese study.The data aren’t conclusive – but they’re certainly surprising.Nicotine may protect smokers against the coronavirus
column7: according to a paper published on Tuesday in the French Academy of Sciences’ Biology Reports.Studying 482 patients hospitalized with Covid-19 in Paris’s Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital
column8: the researchers found just 5 percent were daily smokers – far lower than the 25.4 percent of the French population who smoke daily.While the results cannot be considered conclusive evidence for nicotine protecting smokers against coronavirus – the study size is small
column9: and did not include patients in intensive care – they “strongly suggest that daily smokers have a much lower probability of developing a symptomatic or serious infection with Sars-CoV-2 compared to the general population
column10: ” the paper’s authors argue.“Basically
column11: we have 80 percent fewer smokers in Covid patients than in the general population of the same sex and the same age
column12: ” researcher and internal medicine specialist Zahir Amoura told France Inter on Wednesday."

column15: 15 April 2020 e-mail 40 shares 130 View comments When world-famous artist David Hockney wrote a letter to the Daily Mail saying he believes smoking could protect people against the coronavirus many scoffed.Mr Hockney wrote: 'Could it not be that smokers have developed an immune system to this virus?With all these figures coming out
column16: it’s beginning to look like that to me.'Understandably the claim was brushed off as laughable and 'rubbish' by many.But is it?A leading infectious disease expert at University College London
column17: Professor Francois Balloux
column18: said there is 'bizarrely strong' evidence it could be true.And data from multiple Chinese studies shows that COVID-19 hospital patients contained a smaller proportion of smokers than the general population (6.5 per cent compared to 26.6 per cent)
column19: suggesting they were less likely to end up in hospital."

column2: 2020 by admin Obesity raises the risk of dying from coronavirus by nearly 40 per cent
column3: according to a major study of data collected from NHS hospitals.The research
column4: based on 17
column5: 000 COVID-19 admissions
column6: revealed that overall a third of Britons hospitalised with the life-threatening virus die.Death rates were 37 per cent higher among obese patients
column7: second only to dementia (39 per cent) but more than heart disease (31 per cent).Heart disease was also found to be the most common underlying health condition in coronavirus patients hospitalised with the infection.The study
column8: considered to be the largest of its kind in Europe
column9: revealed more than half (53 per cent) of patients had at least one comorbidity.Almost a third (29 per cent) had heart disease – conditions which block blood vessels and make it hard to pump blood and oxygen around the body."

column8: marijuana
column9: and other smoking (and vaping) due to it’s potential for increasing the likelihood that users could get sick and/or die from novel coronavirus/COVID-19.Smoking during quarantine was warned against in comments earlier this year from Dr. Nora Volkow of the National Institute on Drug Abuse.Dr. Volkow also warned that substance abuse and other substance use disorders could be hit significantly harder by the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 as this global pandemic unfolds.Who claimed nicotine stopped coronavirus?"

column3: but Canadian experts say people should avoid jumping to conclusions.The Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital in Paris examined 480 coronavirus patients — 350 were hospitalized while the rest remained at home with less serious symptoms.They found that a low number of patients in both categories were smokers.Of those in hospital

column12: 28 April 2020 e-mail 173 shares 376 View comments A review of scientific studies has added more evidence to the claim that people who smoke might have a lower risk of becoming seriously ill with COVID-19.University College London academics looked at 28 papers and found the proportions of smokers among hospital patients were 'lower than expected'.One public health professor said there was 'something weird going on with smoking and coronavirus' and experts are struggling to explain the connection.One of the studies showed that in the UK the proportion of smokers among COVID-19 patients was just five per cent
column13: a third of the national rate of 14.4 per cent.Another found in France the rate was four times lower.In China
column14: a study noted 3.8 per cent of patients were smokers - despite more than half of the population regularly smoking cigarettes.When smokers do get diagnosed with the virus
column15: however
column16: they appear to be more likely to get so sick that they need ventilation
column17: two studies in the review showed.Researchers admit that hospitals are probably not recording patients' smoking status properly
column18: potentially because they are too busy
column19: patients are too sick to answer
column20: or because people lie in their answers."

column5: it can be hard to sort through what is actually a fact and what is a myth.Maybe you've got a friend writing on Facebook about how coronavirus will die with a change of season

column17: 15 April 2020 e-mail View comments When world-famous artist David Hockney wrote a letter to the Daily Mail saying he believes smoking could protect people against the coronavirus many scoffed.Mr Hockney wrote: 'Could it not be that smokers have developed an immune system to this virus?With all these figures coming out
column18: it’s beginning to look like that to me.'Understandably the claim was brushed off as laughable and 'rubbish' by many.But is it?A leading infectious disease expert at University College London
column19: Professor Francois Balloux
column20: said there is 'bizarrely strong' evidence it could be true.And data from multiple Chinese studies shows that COVID-19 hospital patients contained a smaller proportion of smokers than the general population (6.5 per cent compared to 26.6 per cent)
column21: suggesting they were less likely to end up in hospital."

column3: it’s beginning to look like that to me.’ Understandably the claim was brushed off as laughable and ‘rubbish’ by many.But is it?A leading infectious disease expert at University College London

column1: 31 c9fc91c0-606b-4571-a393-57d1b5834c41 "Coronavirus: French researchers use nicotine in coronavirus treatment | World | News | Express.co.uk Express.Home of the Daily and Sunday Express.9°C Find us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter Find us on Instagram LoginRegister Your AccountSign Out Apps Puzzles Horoscopes Discounts Shop Paper HOME News Showbiz & TV Sport Comment Finance Travel Entertainment Life & Style UK Weather World Royal Politics Science Nature Weird Sunday Scotland HomeNewsWorld French researchers investigate the use of nicotine in coronavirus treatmentRESEARCHERS in France are investigating whether nicotine could prevent - or lessen the impact of - coronavirus.By Melanie Kaidan PUBLISHED: 06:58
column2: Thu
column3: Apr 23
column5: Thu
column6: Apr 23
column7: 2020 0 The group of scientists suspect either that nicotine could stop the virus from infecting cells or that nicotine was preventing the immune system from overreacting to the virus
column8: The Guardian reported.It comes after a French study found that not many people who had caught the virus were regular smokers.Related articles Housing market on the brink: 500
column9: 000 fewer properties to be sold in... Face masks will NOT be handed out if government ramps up guidelines To put this theory to test
column10: the researchers intend to provide Covid-19 patients in and out of intensive care with nicotine patches.The would also test it on healthcare workers to analyse whether it can prevent the spread of the virus.For the study
column11: performed at Pitié Salpêtrière
column12: part of the Hôpitaux de Paris
column13: the group inspected 480 Covid-19 patients.Three hundred and fifty were hospitalized and the rest recovered at home.The outcome was that the patients in hospital
column14: with a median age of 65
column15: only 4.4 percent were regular smokers."

column1: 31 cbab0a1e-8f94-4704-accf-d726b4f16e51 "Claims About Smoking and Covid-19 Examined – Tobacco Reporter Advertise Digital Edition This Month Past Issues Events GTNF Golden Leaf Awards About Rules GLA Entry Form Subscribe Buyers’ guide About us Our Mission Our People Our Reputation Contact Claims About Smoking and Covid-19 Examined Science April 16
column2: 2020 0 Photo: maja7777 | PixaBay Francois Balloux
column3: an infectious disease expert at University College London
column4: says there is “bizarrely strong” evidence for the suggestion
column5: made by artist David Hockney and others
column6: that smoking could protect people against the coronavirus.According to an article in The Daily Mail
column7: data from multiple Chinese studies shows that Covid-19 hospital patients contained a smaller proportion of smokers than the general population (6.5 percent compared to 26.6 percent)
column8: suggesting they were less likely to end up in the hospital.Another study
column9: by America’s Centers for Disease Control (CDC) of more 7
column10: 000 people who tested positive for the coronavirus
column11: found that just 1.3 percent of them were smokers—against the 14 percent of all Americans that the CDC says smoke.Critics
column12: however
column13: attribute the counterintuitive findings to improper recording.“It’s really difficult to assess how well smoking status has been recorded in an emerging epidemic and a lot of these people have been too sick to answer or may not have replied totally honestly
column14: ” said Jamie Brown
column15: a tobacco and public health expert at University College London.“We know
column16: generally
column17: smokers tend to come from lower income groups
column18: which have poorer access to healthcare and may be more likely to die in the community.”Both Public Health England and the CDC have urged people to stop smoking to protect their health.“It is abundantly clear from the research into previous coronaviruses that smoking makes the impact of a coronavirus worse
column19: ” British Health Secretary Matt Hancock said last month.His chief medical adviser
column20: Chris Whitty
column21: added: “If you are going to give up smoking

column1: 31 fc96e4c9-6134-4584-9e32-4909f47b2bcc "Coronavirus: France drastically limits sale of nicotine products | EuronewsEnglish English Français Deutsch Italiano Español Português Русский Türkçe Ελληνικά Magyar فارسی العربية Shqip Newsletters Europe World Business Sport Culture Europe World Business Sport Culture Living Sci-tech Travel Video More Europe World Business Sport Culture Living Sci-tech Travel Video Living Sci-tech Travel Video ProgrammesLive Europe Brussels Bureau Smart Regions State Of The Union Business Business Planet Markets Real Economy Target World Aid Zone Good Morning Europe Inspire Middle East No Comment Spotlight The Cube The Global Conversation Unreported Europe View World News Culture Cinema Cult Musica Sport Sci-tech Climate Now Futuris Ocean Sci-Tech Space Chronicles With Luca Parmitano Travel Adventures Explore Focus Postcards Taste Special coverageAngola 360 Brexit Climate Crisis Coronavirus Croatia 360 Destination Dubai Protests 2020 Partner contentKerala Tourism All Programmes BREAKING NEWSHome > European affairs > Europe > Coronavirus: France drastically limits sale of nicotine productsThis content is not available in your regionFranceCoronavirus: France drastically limits sale of nicotine products Comments By Alice Tidey  &bullet  last updated: 25/04/2020 - 18:24 Copyright AP Photo/Patrick SisonShare this articleShareTweetSharesendShareTweetSharesendMoreHideShareSendShareShareShareSendShareShareText size Aa Aa France severely curtailed the sale of nicotine products on Friday after a study suggested smokers may be less likely to contract COVID-19.The decree
column2: issued by the Ministry of Health
column3: limits pharmacies from selling more than a one-month supply of any nicotine products aimed at curbing dependence to cigarettes.Each sale is to be logged by pharmacies whether the buyer had a doctor's prescription or not.Online sale has meanwhile been completely banned.The measures were taken to ""prevent the health risk linked to the excessive consumption or misuse"" of nicotine products by people hoping to protect themselves from the novel coronavirus and ""to guarantee the continuous supply for people requiring medication to stop smoking
column4: the decree states.It comes just days after a study by the Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital in Paris flagged ""that current smoking status appears to be a protective factor against the infection by SARS-CoV-2"".Coronavirus: WHO warns against 'immunity passports' for recovered patientsIt noted that ""compared to the French general population
column5: the Covid-19 population exhibited a significantly weaker current daily smoker rate by 80.3 % for outpatients and by 75.4 % for inpatients"" and theorised that ""nicotine may be suggested as a potential preventive agent against Covid-19 infection.""The hospital now plans to trial the use of nicotine patches or other products on hospitalised COVID-19 patients and in the general population to test its efficiency against the virus.""One should not forget that nicotine is a drug of abuse responsible for smoking addiction.Smoking has severe pathological consequences and remains a serious danger for health
column6: it warned.France has suffered greatly from the pandemic with 22
column7: 245 deaths recorded in hospitals and care homes since the beginning of the outbreak — the fourth highest tally in the world as of April 24.Last month

column7: 2020 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Vir Biotechnology
column8: Inc. (Nasdaq: VIR)
column9: a clinical-stage immunology company focused on immune approaches to treating and preventing serious infectious diseases
column10: today announced that it has identified two monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) that bind to SARS-CoV-2 (previously known as “2019-nCoV”)
column11: which were originally found because they bind and neutralize the original SARS-CoV.The antibodies target the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in the region that the virus uses to enter cells through the cellular receptor ACE2.Infection with SARS-CoV-2 causes the newly named disease
column12: Covid-19.“We are in the process of assessing neutralization with a pseudo-virus
column13: ” said George Scangos
column14: Ph.D.
column15: CEO of Vir.“In addition
column16: we are working with international partners to assess the capacity of these antibodies to neutralize the live virus
column17: SARS-CoV-2.” The company is moving ahead with research to determine if its antibodies
column18: or additional antibodies that it may be able to identify
column19: can be effective as treatment and/or prophylaxis against SARS-CoV-2.To that end
column20: the company is exploring collaborations with a number of other companies and governmental agencies."

column6: Professor of Biology
column7: College of the Holy Cross | The Conversation Amid the chaos of an epidemic
column8: those who survive a disease like COVID-19 carry within their bodies the secrets of an effective immune response.Virologists like me look to survivors for molecular clues that can provide a blueprint for the design of future treatments or even a vaccine.Researchers are launching trials now that involve the transfusion of blood components from people who have recovered from COVID-19 to those who are sick or at high risk.Called “convalescent-plasma therapy
column9: ” this technique can work even without doctors knowing exactly what component of the blood may be beneficial.For the pioneering work of the first treatment using therapeutic serum in 1891 (against diphtheria)
column10: Emil von Behring later earned the Nobel Prize in medicine."

column1: 38 1742222c-9ad2-4e57-9bdd-61e86352b404 "Canadian clinical trial tests plasma therapy for COVID-19.– Infosurhoy Skip to content Infosurhoy Latest Science News and Reports Main Navigation News News Summary Top Stories Technology Economy Entertainment Health Science Sports Canadian clinical trial tests plasma therapy for COVID-19.By Denis Bedoya  On April 12
column2: 2020 In News Summary Leave a comment facebook tweet google+ Can those who survive COVID-19 provide blood to treat others hospitalized by the disease?That’s the question driving a Canadian consortium that has launched one of the world’s largest clinical trials of a potential treatment for COVID-19 —one that goes as far back as the Spanish flu a century ago.The treatment involves taking blood plasma—which contains antibodies—from people who have recovered from COVID-19 infection
column3: and giving it to patients who are sick enough to be hospitalized with the same disease.The proposed Convalescent Plasma for COVID-19 Research (CONCOR) trial is a collaboration between the Canadian Transfusion Research Network
column4: the McMaster Centre for Transfusion Research
column5: Canadian Blood Services
column6: Héma-Québec and academic partners across the country."

column9: 2020 / 09:15 AM EDT Hotline covid category COLUMBUS (WCMH) — The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center announced Tuesday it has transfused the first patient in central and northern Ohio with plasma from a recovered COVID-19 coronavirus patient.The university says the transfusion is part of a nationwide effort to provide this plasma
column10: also known as convalescent plasma
column11: to people who are ill with life-threatening COVID-19 disease.People who’ve recovered from COVID-19 often have antibodies – proteins in the blood – that could possibly attack the virus.Ohio State researchers will also study the donated plasma to learn which antibodies perform best.“This ‘compassionate use’ therapy shows promise to lessen the severity or shorten the length of COVID-19.Our new program involves a routine blood donation process to collect the plasma that will be given to critically-ill COVID-19 patients to fight this infection
column12: ” Dr. Scott Scrape
column13: a pathologist and director of Transfusion Medicine at Wexner Medical Center."

column4: 01 Apr 2020 10:59:07 GMT Chinese scientists seeking potential Covid-19 treatment find 'effective' antibodies Sign in Register News South Africa Africa World State Capture coronavirus Sport Soccer Boxing Cricket Rugby Entertainment Mzansi's Sexiest Pic of the day Good Life Sex & Relationships Health Weddings Motoring SebenzaLIVE Opinion Columnists Letters S Mag Business Money BusinessLIVE Video Light Version World Chinese scientists seeking potential Covid-19 treatment find 'effective' antibodies By Reuters - 01 April 2020 - 12:19 Scientists have isolated several antibodies that are ""extremely effective"" at blocking the ability of the new coronavirus to enter cells.Image: REUTERS/Yves Herman A team of Chinese scientists has isolated several antibodies that it says are ""extremely effective"" at blocking the ability of the new coronavirus to enter cells
column5: which eventually could be helpful in treating or preventing Covid-19.There is currently no proven effective treatment for the disease
column6: which originated in China and is spreading across the world in a pandemic that has infected more than 850
column7: 000 and killed 42
column8: 000.Zhang Linqi at Tsinghua University in Beijing said a drug made with antibodies like the ones his team have found could be used more effectively than the current approaches
column9: including what he called ""borderline"" treatment such as plasma.Plasma contains antibodies but is restricted by blood type.In early January
column10: Zhang's team and a group at the 3rd People's Hospital in Shenzhen began analysing antibodies from blood taken from recovered Covid-19 patients
column11: isolating 206 monoclonal antibodies which showed what he described as a ""strong"" ability to bind with the virus' proteins.They then conducted another test to see if they could actually prevent the virus from entering cells
column12: he told Reuters in an interview.Among the first 20 or so antibodies tested
column13: four were able to block viral entry and of those

column3: April 09
column4: 2020 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Tiziana Life Sciences plc (Nasdaq: TLSA) (“Tiziana” or the “Company”)
column5: a biotechnology company focused on innovative therapeutics for inflammatory and autoimmune diseases
column6: announced today that it has developed investigational new technology to treat COVID-19 infections
column7: which consists of direct delivery of anti-IL-6 receptor (anti-IL-6R) monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) into the lungs using a handheld inhaler or nebulizer.Development of this novel technology is a step forward toward expediting  development of  TZLS-501
