column5: Inc.: Humanigen's Lenzilumab as a Potential Therapeutic for Lung Damage Arising From CoronavirusCoronavirus triggers cytokine storm in infected patients resulting in severe lung damage and deathLenzilumab is in clinical studies for prevention of cytokine storm BURLINGAME
column6: CA / ACCESSWIRE / March 9
column7: 2020 / Humanigen
column8: Inc.
column9: (OTCQB:HGEN) (""Humanigen"")
column10: a clinical stage biopharmaceutical company focused on developing its portfolio of clinical and preclinical therapies for the treatment of cancers and infectious diseases
column11: announced today that it is actively exploring clinical stage strategies and partnerships to evaluate whether lenzilumab
column12: the company's proprietary Humaneered® anti-human-GM-CSF monoclonal antibody
column13: may reduce or prevent cytokine storm resulting from COVID-19 (or coronavirus
column14: also referred to as SARS-CoV-2) infection.A recent pre-publication
column15: titled ""Aberrant pathogenic GM-CSF+ T cells and inflammatory CD14+CD16+ monocytes in severe pulmonary syndrome patients of a new coronavirus""
column16: supports the hypothesis that cytokine storm-induced immune mechanism have contributed to patient mortality with the current pandemic strain of coronavirus.The severe clinical features associated with COVID-19 and other coronaviruses result from an inflammation-induced lung injury requiring intensive care unit (ICU) care and mechanical ventilation.This lung injury is a result of cytokine storm resulting from a hyper-reactive immune response.The lung injury that leads to death is not directly related to the virus
column17: but appears to be a result of a hyper-reactive immune response to the virus triggering a cytokine storm that can continue even after viral titers begin to fall.The authors of the study assessed samples from patients with severe pneumonia resulting from COVID-19 infection to identify whether inflammatory factors such as GM-CSF
column18: IL-6
column19: IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha were implicated.The authors noted that steroid treatment in such cases has been disappointing in terms of outcome
column20: but suggest that a monoclonal antibody that targets GM-CSF may prevent or curb the hyper-active immune response caused by COVID-19 in this setting.Humanigen believes that the authors' findings are clearly worthy of further investigation
column21: suggesting that to reduce or eradicate ICU care and prevent deaths from COVID-19 infection
column22: an intervention may be needed to prevent cytokine storm.Lenzilumab has been shown to prevent cytokine storm in animal models and this work has been published in peer reviewed publications.Patients are soon expected to be enrolled in a clinical study to determine lenzilumab's effect on cytokine storm associated with the hyper-active immune response associated with CAR-T therapy in collaboration with Kite Pharma.Dr.Cameron Durrant
column23: CEO of Humanigen
column24: stated
column25: ""These data confirm previously published data from the SARS and the MERS outbreaks
column26: caused by strains of coronavirus different from the current COVID-19 strains
column27: which indicated that severe pneumonia in SARS and MERS resulted from cytokine storm."

column9: one of the members of the research team.Bengaluru: In a sign of hope since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic
column10: ten biologists working at Utrecht University in the Netherlands have reported the discovery of the first antibody that can aid the detection and prevention of infection by SARS2
column11: the coronavirus.The team tested this antibody (which is a protein produced by the host body in response to antigens such as viruses) successfully on mice

column13: titled ‘A human monoclonal antibody blocking SARS-CoV-2’
column14: posted on BioRxiv
column15: a website where biologists publish about their research projects.At the end of a detailed explanation

column18: the antibody was isolated before the pandemic."

column10: ten biologists working at Utrecht University in the Netherlands have reported the discovery of the first antibody that can aid the detection and prevention of infection by SARS2
column11: the coronavirus.The team tested this antibody (which is a protein produced by the host body in response to antigens such as viruses) successfully on mice

Latest News Business Education Food Movies Sports Technology Lifestyle ENTERTAINMENT HEALTH TRAVEL TV Home HEALTH Vir Bio inks $362M Covid-19 contract manufacturing deal with Samsung Biologics HEALTH Vir Bio inks $362M Covid-19 contract manufacturing deal with Samsung Biologics by siteadmin 12 April 2020 written by siteadmin 12 April 2020 A small biotechnology company focused on antiviral drugs that has lately gained prominence in the fight against Covid-19 has added a division of one of Korea’s largest business conglomerates to its growing portfolio of big-ticket biopharma partnerships.San Francisco-based Vir Biotechnology said Thursday that it made a partnership with Songdo
column3: South Korea-based Samsung Biologics.The deal focuses on large-scale manufacturing of monoclonal antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 and builds on two deals that Vir had previously announced
column4: namely its manufacturing agreement with China-based WuXi Biologics and a letter of intent with Cambridge
column5: Massachusetts-based Biogen.The Samsung Biologics deal is worth about $362 million
column6: and the manufacturer is expected to start manufacturing as early as October and produce potential commercial batches of the drug starting in 2021.“With millions of people being impacted by this virus
column7: accessibility to effective treatment is paramount
column8: ” Samsung Biologics CEO Tae Han Kim said in a statement.“Vir’s candidate molecules
column9: supported by Samsung Biologics’ production scale
column10: have the potential to bring hope to countless lives across nations suffering from Covid-19.” The two lead product candidates for Covid-19 in Vir’s portfolio are VIR-7831 and VIR-7832
column11: both monoclonal antibodies that have shown an ability to neutralize the SARS-CoV-2 virus in cell culture testing."

column11: 24 April 2020 e-mail View comments Modern science has scarcely presented a more crucial goal
column12: offering untold riches and perhaps even a Nobel prize to the victor
column13: as well as the chance to return the world to normal.Yet the search for a cure for coronavirus is also uniquely perilous thanks to the dangers inherent in rushing new medical products to market.Across the globe
column14: thousands of researchers employed by governments
column15: laboratories and drug firms are working flat-out to crack this all-important riddle.As are endless armchair experts
column16: whose numbers now evidently include Donald Trump.Yesterday
column17: the world’s most powerful man used a press conference to propose various highly unorthodox new treatments for coronavirus
column18: including ‘injecting’ disinfectant into the body and blasting patients with ultraviolet light.Back in the real world
column19: researchers are working tirelessly to combat the virus.But while bullish claims have been made for a host of possible treatments
column20: the truth is that scientists have little idea which ones might end up being of use.‘Four months into the pandemic
column21: we have had millions of people infected but no data yet to show that any particular treatment is especially effective
column22: ’ says Professor Babak Javid
column23: the Principal Investigator at Tsinghua University school of medicine in Beijing
column24: and a consultant in infectious diseases at Cambridge University Hospitals.Nonetheless
column25: here are some of the most likely candidates:Trump’s malaria pillIn mid-March
column26: the American President used Twitter to amplify reports that Covid-19 patients could be successfully treated via a combination of the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine and a common antibiotic
column27: Azithromycin.In a later press conference
column28: the President insisted that ‘common sense’ qualified him to make such a claim
column29: urging Americans to ‘take it’ and asking them: ‘What have you got to lose?’Well
column30: quite a lot
column31: as it turned out.The drugs have a catalogue of nasty side-effects
column32: including an increased risk of cardiac arrest
column33: skin blistering
column34: hearing loss and an ‘inability to move the eyes’.A study this week of 368 male coronavirus patients found that 28 per cent of those treated via hydroxychloroquine alone and 22 per cent who received both drugs (the malaria treatment and azithromycin) in U.S. hospitals died."

column2: as soon as the genetic sequence was posted for the new coronavirus then rampaging through China—it didn’t even have the name SARS-CoV-2 yet—Florian Krammer and his lab went to work.Krammer is a virologist and vaccinologist at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine; he specializes in figuring out the bits and pieces of viruses that can teach the human immune system to recognize and fight off germs.But this time
column3: Krammer wasn’t looking for the soul of a new coronavirus vaccine—at least
column4: not necessarily.He was looking for the sequence for the gene that makes a protein called a spike.Coronaviruses wave it from their outer shells like a cudgel.It’s part of the machinery they use to attach to and invade cells
column5: turning them into factories for making more viruses (and making people sick along the way).Krammer planned to engineer cells to make that spike protein
column6: so he could drag it through a blood sample to see if any antibodies—the action heroes of the immune system—stuck to it."

column6: a drug used to treat some forms of arthritis
column7: might be an effective treatment for those with severe cases of COVID-19
column8: according to the preliminary findings of a study published Wednesday by the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.The drug is a monoclonal antibody -- a cloned immune cell -- that is intended to bind to interleukin-6
column9: or IL-6
column10: a type of cytokine protein research suggests is part of an overactive immune response that causes serious illness in some of those infected with the new coronavirus.By binding to IL-6
column11: the researchers said
column12: tocilizumab effectively works to disrupt this immune response
column13: allowing patients to recover.However
column14: the authors
column15: from China
column16: emphasized that the findings are preliminary and need to be confirmed in a larger study."

column2: 2020Latest Science News and Reports | Latest Breaking News open menu Back [BREAKING] COVID-19 Update: Lysol Urges People Not to Drink or Inject Disinfectants to Treat Coronavirus By Denis Bedoya on April 25
column3: 2020 23SHARESShareTweet The company that makes Lysol is urging customers not to consume its products after claims that “injecting” disinfectants could cure and protect people from coronavirus.Reckitt Benckiser (RB)
column4: a British company
column5: warned Friday that human intake of disinfectant merchandise is dangerous.The company
column6: which also sells Dettol in the United Kingdom
column7: issued the statement following “latest speculation and social media activity.” Claims have been circulating online
column8: suggesting that medical experts should try exposing the human body to UV light and injecting disinfectants as a treatment for coronavirus.Rumors also speculated that bleach should kill the virus in saliva or respiratory fluids in five minutes
column9: and isopropyl alcohol “should kill it even more quickly.” The said claims were made after acting Undersecretary for Science and Technology at the Department of Homeland Security William Bryan told reporters about the impacts of light
column10: bleach
column11: and isopropyl alcohol on coronavirus.ALSO READ: Clorox and Lysol Aren’t Lying When They Claim They Can Kill ‘Coronavirus’… But There’s A Catch!Due to recent speculation and social media activity
column12: RB said in a statement on its website they “[were] asked whether internal administration of disinfectants [might] be appropriate for investigation or use as a treatment for coronavirus.” “Our disinfectant and hygiene products should only be used as intended and in line with usage guidelines
column13: ” RB wrote in the statement."

column15: autism

column18: and multiple sclerosis.Prosecutors say that in late March

column2: after tearing into POTUS for ‘disinfectants’ line | Mo4ch News - Mo4ch News Breaking Home World UK US Sports Business Science Technology Lifestyle Saturday
column3: April 25
column4: 2020 New mo4ch:>Trump’s media critics silent on Cristina Cuomo’s ‘BLEACH BATH’ Covid-19 tip
column5: after tearing into POTUS for ‘disinfectants’ line | Mo4ch News Mo4ch News April 25
column6: 2020 world While media critics were busy mocking US President Donald Trump’s recent musings about Covid-19 treatments
column7: the wife of a top CNN anchor offered her own novel therapy: bathing in bleach – drawing silence from the same detractors.American media outlets could hardly contain their ridicule for the president following Thursday’s daily White House briefing
column8: sneering after Trump asked about the possibility of internally ‘disinfecting’ coronavirus patients in his typical rambling style.The loosely worded question –  posed to an expert present at the briefing – was soon transformed into a directive for Americans to inject themselves with common household cleaners in the minds of some critics.But similar outrage was nowhere to be found after Cristina Cuomo
column9: the wife of CNN anchor Chris Cuomo
column10: took to her blog this week with a massive 3
column11: 000-word article debuting her latest medical tips.Cuomo – who along with her husband and son tested positive for the coronavirus – relayed her doctor’s recommendation to use Clorox brand bleach as “a type of homeopathic bath
column12: ” arguing the noxious brew would “combat the radiation and metals in my system.” “We want to neutralize heavy metals because they slow up the electromagnetic frequency of our cells
column13: which is our energy field
column14: and we need a good flow of energy
column15: ” Cuomo quoted her doctor as saying
column16: adding (dubiously) that “Clorox is sodium chloride – which is technically salt.” While some news agencies did take notice of the bizarre health advice
column17: few took to the rooftops to condemn Cuomo for ordering her readers to flavor their food with the off-white liquid – which is “technically” just salt after all – or another equally tortured reading.READ MORE: No
column18: Trump did NOT suggest injecting disinfectant to treat Covid-19 As Cuomo’s husband hit CNN’s airwaves to lambaste the president for his ‘disinfection’ remark
column19: the outlet was sure to keep radio silence on her medically-questionable blog post
column20: prompting some netizens to point out the blatant double standard."

column7: 2020 / 09:03 PM CDT / Updated: Mar 13
column8: 2020 / 09:03 PM CDT AUSTIN (KXAN) — Austin Public Health announced Friday that event organizers are strongly recommended to to cancel due to coronavirus concerns — and the three presumptive positive cases of COVID-19 in Travis County.Additionally
column9: APH is recommending several safety guidelines
column10: including: Increase the frequency of sanitizing frequently touched surfaces Encourage attendees to stay at least six feet away from each other to reduce risk Keep an adequate supply of hand soap
column11: disinfectants
column12: tissues
column13: and paper towelsEncourage attendees to follow increased hygiene
column14: such as hand-washing for 20 seconds with soap and water
column15: or alcohol-based sanitizer “The health and safety of Austin-Travis County residents and visitors is our highest priority and today we’re adopting a regional strategy to help minimize the spread of this disease
column16: ” said Dr. Mark Escott
column17: interim health authority for Austin-Travis County.“We are looking for opportunities to mitigate risk while keeping businesses operating.If we can find the right balance we can better sustain our community.” Restaurants Meanwhile
column18: emergency rules for restaurants and food establishments have been recommended as well.New rules
column19: effective Friday
column20: March 13
column21: state that food permit holders and people in charge of food businesses must: Display “Help Prevent Disease” signs provided by Austin Public Health in a prominent public location clearly visible to the general public and patrons Make hand sanitizer available to the general public and to patron Disinfect and sanitize commonly touched surfaces and nonfood-contact surfaces of equipment of the establishment at least once every hourAdopt and implement a policy that provides for the immediate exclusion of food handlers from duties if they develop a fever greater than or equal to 100.4 degrees during their shift APH says that failure to comply with these Emergency Rules
column22: which will expire July 12
column23: will constitute a public health hazard and may result in immediate suspension of food establishment permits.For more information
column24: you can visit AustinTexas.gov/COVID19."

column12: secure
column13: accurate and healthy election as concerns surround the coronavirus (COVID-19) increase.Meanwhile
column14: the Cuyahoga County BOE is also scrambling to find hundreds more poll workers before Tuesday’s elections.This week
column15: the BOE was forced to change 39 polling locations due to coronavirus concerns.Some locations combined
column16: while others relocated entirely.Residents who were impacted will get a notice in the mail."

column3: 2020.Commonwealth Media Services: Natalie KolbBy Leada Gore | lgore@al.com Alabama Power is the latest company to outline its plans related to coronavirus.“We are focused on the safety and well-being of our employees and customers

column3: 2020 2:06 pm Winnipeg Mayor Brian Bowman.THE CANADIAN PRESS/John Woods comments Leave a comment facebook Share this item whatsapp Share this item via WhatsApp twitter Share this item on Twitter email Send this page to someone via email more Share this item more Share this item Smaller font Descrease article font size -A Larger font Increase article font size A+ Share this item facebook Share this item via WhatsApp whatsapp Share this item on Twitter twitter Send this page to someone via email email Share this item on Pinterest pinterest Share this item on LinkedIn linkedin Share this item on Reddit reddit Copy article link Copy link Winnipeg’s mayor has a simple message: Don’t drink or inject household cleaners.Brian Bowman gave the seemingly common-sense advice at a press conference held to update Winnipeggers on the city’s response to COVID-19 Friday.The warning comes after U.S. President Donald Trump floated the idea of injecting or ingesting bleach as a possible cure for COVID-19 Thursday.3:58 Trump’s disinfectant suggestion “dangerous and idiotic” and “hugely irresponsible
column4: ” doctor says Trump’s disinfectant suggestion “dangerous and idiotic” and “hugely irresponsible
column5: ” doctor says Injecting yourself or eating bleach — a poison — will make you sick
column6: and you shouldn’t do it
column7: according to doctors.READ MORE: Coronavirus: Additional case reported
column8: surgical activities to increase over next week “I can’t believe I have to say this.But I’m going to just urge Winnipeggers to not consume or inject any disinfectants
column9: ” Bowman said Friday.“That includes Windex
column10: that includes Clorox
column11: that includes Lysol
column12: and other household cleaning products.Story continues below advertisement “These are products not to be consumed or injected and we would urge people
column13: please observe the safety warnings on the labels and follow the expertise from health officials
column14: including those at Manitoba Health.” 1:07 Accidental poisonings from cleaning supplies
column15: disinfectants rising during pandemic Accidental poisonings from cleaning supplies
column16: disinfectants rising during pandemic Bowman said he’s heard no reports of anyone in Winnipeg drinking or injecting household cleaners
column17: but added he has had people asking him about it online.“Obviously
column18: with news over the last 24 hours
column19: there’s a lot of discussion about it so I just wanted to add my voice to remind people to follow the safety warnings on those household cleaning products
column20: ” he said."

column3: Flu & Cough Lung Cancer Smoking Cessation Quit-Smoking Assessment Lung Disease & Respiratory Health News Dangerous Claims That Bleach Can Treat COVID-19 By Robert Preidt HealthDay Reporter THURSDAY
column4: April 9
column5: 2020 (HealthDay News) -- A warning letter has been sent to a company marketing bogus and dangerous chlorine dioxide products for the prevention and treatment of COVID-19
column6: the U.S. Food and Drug Administration says.The fraudulent claims by the Genesis II Church of Health and Healing about its ""Miracle Mineral Solution"" products are especially concerning in relation to children
column7: who are at increased risk for harm from consuming chlorine dioxide
column8: according to the FDA.The joint warning letter from the FDA and the Federal Trade Commission gave the company 48 hours to outline what it's done to correct the violations.The FDA has previously warned consumers against buying or drinking chlorine dioxide products sold online as medical treatments."

column1: 39 4e1f3870-63bd-4f94-b61c-0b12319fe80f "Fact Vs Fiction: Busting Social Media Myths On Coronavirus NDTVBusinessहिन्दीMoviesCricketLifestyleHealthFoodTechHOPAutoবাংলাதமிழ்AppsTrainsArtLIVE TVLATESTCoronavirusINDIAVIDEOWORLDOPINIONCITIESOFFBEATPhotosTrendsTV ScheduleSOUTHPEOPLEScienceEDUCATIONWEATHERFact Vs Fiction: Busting Social Media Myths On CoronavirusSearchHomeWorldFact Vs Fiction: Busting Social Media Myths On Coronavirus Fact Vs Fiction: Busting Social Media Myths On Coronavirus Social media is filled with myths about how people might stop the new coronavirus.WorldReutersUpdated: March 19
column2: 2020 12:11 pm ISTSocial media is filled with myths about how people might stop the new coronavirus.London: Social media is filled with myths about how people might stop the new coronavirus.Here are some facts to address the fiction:TransmissionFiction:- The new coronavirus can be spread by mosquito bites and in Chinese food.Fact:- No.The new coronavirus is a respiratory virus that spreads primarily via droplets when an infected person coughs
column3: sneezes or breathes out
column4: or through droplets of saliva or discharge from the nose.ProtectionFiction:- Regularly rinsing your nose with saline can prevent infection with COVID-19.Fact:- No.There is no evidence that regularly rinsing the nose with saline has protected people.There is some weak evidence that regularly rinsing the nose with saline can help some people recover more quickly from the common cold
column5: but it does not prevent respiratory infections.Fiction:- Some claims on social media suggest that spraying alcohol or chlorine all over your body can protect against COVID-19 infection
column6: or that gargling bleach or drinking excessive amounts of water can somehow ""flush it out"".Fact:- There is no evidence to back these claims.- Good hygiene practices including frequent hand washing and avoiding close social contact can help reduce the risk of infection.Fiction:- Hand dryers are effective in killing the new coronavirus.Fact:- No."

column2: April 27
column3: 2020 Tweet KINGSTON
column4: Jamaica - One of the island's leading bleach manufacturers
column5: Pioneer Manufacturing Distribution Company Limited
column6: producer and distributor of the Chloro-Do brand
column7: is warning Jamaicans not to ingest bleach in an attempt to ward off the COVID-19 virus.Managing director of Pioneer Alfred Thomas
column8: said the product is safe when diluted and used for sanitation purposes
column9: such as the wiping of commonly used spaces in homes and public areas.� “If swallowed
column10: bleach can cause symptoms such as gagging; pain and irritation in the mouth and throat; pain
column11: vomiting and possible burns in the oesophagus and stomach
column12: while shock can appear within a few hours.� “If the symptoms are not treated immediately
column13: permanent damage can be done to the gastrointestinal track and internal organs
column14: ” Thomas said.The company executive also reiterated the warning printed on containers advising that bleach should be kept out of the reach of children and that purchasers should read directions carefully before use.Thomas said until a cure is found for the COVID-19 virus
column15: Jamaicans can protect themselves by staying home
column16: practising social distancing
column17: good respiratory etiquette
column18: sanitising and washing hands frequently with soap and water
column19: wipe commonly used spaces and wearing masks when in public.� Now you can read the Jamaica Observer ePaper anytime
column20: anywhere.The Jamaica Observer ePaper is available to you at home or at work
column21: and is the same edition as the printed copy available at http://bit.ly/epaperlive ADVERTISEMENT POST A COMMENT HOUSE RULES 1."

column6: W.Va. (WTRF) – As of Saturday morning

column9: 2020 / 09:27 AM EDT CHARLOTTESVILLE
column10: Va. (Nexstar Media Wire) – A Virginia poison control center is reminding residents that they should never drink bleach – and that doing so will certainly not prevent coronavirus.The Blue Ridge Poison Center said in a letter obtained by WCAV
column11: “There is a lot of confusing
column12: incomplete
column13: and just plain inaccurate information circulating about how to prevent the COVID-19 virus (“coronavirus”) from spreading.Some advice measures simply won’t help
column14: and some could be downright dangerous.The Blue Ridge Poison Center at UVA Health warns that drinking bleach will not prevent COVID-19 infections and could cause serious injury.” While bleach is an effective tool for disinfecting car handles
column15: desktops and other surfaces
column16: the BRPC warns that the cleaning agent can burn one’s mouth
column17: throat and stomach."

column1: 39 65d7ad57-3713-454f-8578-879dd4bc6027 "Whoopi Goldberg: Last Person Who 'Suggested Anyone Use Bleach' Was Nazi Death Camp Doctor Skip to content PoliticsEntertainmentMediaEconomyWorldLondon / EuropeBorder / Cartel ChroniclesIsrael / Middle EastAfricaAsiaLatin AmericaAll WorldVideoTechSportsSocial JusticeB Inspired BREITBART PoliticsEntertainmentMediaEconomyWorldLondon / EuropeBorder / Cartel ChroniclesIsrael / Middle EastAfricaAsiaLatin AmericaWorld NewsVideoTechSportsSocial JusticeB InspiredWiresAbout UsPeople BREITBART CoronavirusTara ReadeMission Reopen USANancy PelosiMake China PayCheat-by-Mail Whoopi Goldberg: Last Person Who ‘Suggested Anyone Use Bleach’ Was Nazi Death Camp Doctor 6 Pam Key27 Apr 2020 Monday on ABC’s “The View
column2: ” co-host Whoopi Goldberg made a comparison between Doctor Josef Mengele
column3: who tortured and murdered Holocaust victims at the Auschwitz concentration camp
column4: and Donald Trump
column5: noting Mengele was the “last person that really even suggested anyone use bleach.” Goldberg said
column6: “Well
column7: I have to say the reason that the story is still in the news is if you have little kids
column8: you have to constantly explain to them
column9: no
column10: you cannot drink bleach.You cannot do this.You know
column11: the last person that really even suggested anyone use bleach was a man called Dr. Mengele
column12: and he did bad things to people.So we don’t discuss bleach.” She continued
column13: “I have all of the compassion for everybody because it’s not an easy job
column14: but one of those journalists sitting there should have stood up and said
column15: No
column16: sir
column17: that is a dangerous thing to say because you can actually kill people.” Referencing White House coronavirus response coordinator Dr. Deborah Birx
column18: Goldberg said
column19: “She should have said
column20: No
column21: sir
column22: and yes
column23: she should have jumped up.That’s part of the reason they’re there.They’re there to protect us and to make sure we are getting the facts
column24: and it wasn’t a joke because that’s not how you do a joke."

column3: but they can be harmful to the body April 24
column4: 2020 3:08 AM CNN Posted: April 24
column5: 2020 3:08 AM Updated: April 24
column6: 2020 3:10 AM by CNN (CNN) — Sunlight and bleach can both kill the new coronavirus
column7: a federal official told the daily White House briefing Thursday.But President Trump turned what should have been a simple scientific summary into a puzzling stream of dangerous ideas about somehow streaming light into the body and suggestions about injecting disinfectants.Here’s what was said
column8: and what science really tells us about safely killing viruses.Bill Bryan
column9: a senior official at the US Department of Homeland Security
column10: said studies on the virus showed bleach kills coronavirus in about five minutes
column11: and isopropyl alcohol destroys it even faster.Tests showed the virus in droplets of saliva survives best indoors and in dry conditions.“The virus dies the quickest in the presence of direct sunlight under these conditions
column12: ” he said."

column1: 39 66e02742-726b-4c72-a025-2c82c91e9efa "Coronavirus: Going Overboard With Disinfectants Could Be Deadly to Kids
column2: Experts Say – Infosurhoy Press ""Enter"" to skip to content Search Search Infosurhoy InfosurhoyApril 30
column3: 2020Latest Science News and Reports | Latest Breaking News open menu Back News News Summary Top Stories Technology Economy Entertainment Health Science Sports Coronavirus: Going Overboard With Disinfectants Could Be Deadly to Kids
column4: Experts Say By Denis Bedoya on April 30
column5: 2020 18SHARESShareTweet As many Americans fight the coronavirus pandemic through careful cleaning at home
column6: experts warn that the increased use of cleaning products may pose a hazard to kids.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said emergency poison control calls related to household cleaning items
column7: and disinfectants had been up 20.4% between January and March this year.ALSO READ: [BREAKING] COVID-19 Update: Lysol Urges People Not to Drink or Inject Disinfectants to Treat Coronavirus Experts say the obsession with cleanliness usually leads to negligence when it comes to the usage of these merchandise with kids within the home.Samara Geller
column8: a senior research and database analyst from the Environmental Working Group
column9: told The Post aggressive cleaning calls for careful consideration
column10: says “As many people hunker down indoors to flatten the curve of the coronavirus epidemic
column11: they may be using disinfectants and other cleaning products more frequently
column12: ” she mentioned.Geller said using these chemicals safely is more important than ever; thus
column13: making sure to follow label directions exactly.Following the instructions is specifically vital now seeing that merchandise such as those containing ammonia or bleach “can cause or exacerbate respiratory issues
column14: ” Geller added."

column1: 39 67f62eaf-d01a-4918-a2c8-11d7a3593d00 "Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update: FDA Warns Seller Marketing Dangerous Chlorine Dioxide Products that Claim to Treat or Prevent COVID-19 Questions?+1 (202) 335-3939 Set Up FREE Account Submit Release Why Us Press Releases Services Pricing & Comparison Chart Distribution Resources Contact Contact Contact World Media Directory · RSS · Email Newsletters There were 678 press releases posted in the last 24 hours and 166
column2: 896 in the last 365 days.Coronavirus (COVID-19) Update: FDA Warns Seller Marketing Dangerous Chlorine Dioxide Products that Claim to Treat or Prevent COVID-19 For Immediate Release: April 08
column3: 2020 The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has issued a warning letter to a seller that markets fraudulent and dangerous chlorine dioxide products known as “Miracle Mineral Solution” for prevention and treatment of “Novel Coronavirus Disease 2019” (COVID-19).The FDA has previously warned consumers not to purchase or drink chlorine dioxide products sold online as medical treatments
column4: as the agency is not aware of any scientific evidence supporting their safety or effectiveness and they pose significant risks to patient health.The FDA is taking this action to protect Americans as part of its response to the global COVID-19 pandemic.“Despite previous warnings
column5: the FDA is concerned that we are still seeing chlorine dioxide products being sold with misleading claims that they are safe and effective for the treatment of diseases
column6: now including COVID-19."

column6: Ohio (WKBN) – As COVID-19 spreads
column7: more people may feel the need to isolate themselves to stay healthy.Still
column8: experts say keeping in touch with loved ones is important.That can be as simple as talking to someone on the phone
column9: video chatting or using social media so you’re not completely isolated
column10: which could worsen symptoms of depression.It’s important to be aware so you don’t fall into bad habits.“Bad coping mechanisms would be drinking too much alcohol
column11: using drugs…overeating
column12: over-isolating without having any connection to the outside world
column13: ” said April Caraway
column14: with the Trumbull County Mental Health and Recovery Board.She added getting outdoors is always good
column15: and there are ways to stay active and exercise even during isolation."

column3: Gabby Landsverk
column4: Business Insider US - April 24
column5: 2020 President Trump suggested April 23 that disinfectants might be used “by injection” in the body as “a cleaning” to treat COVID-19
column6: the disease the coronavirus causes.The comment delighted fringe movement activists who’ve been promoting drinking bleach to cure conditions like autism
column7: and infuriated medical professionals
column8: who’ve long known the solution can be deadly.Even bleach companies are begging people not to drink
column9: inject
column10: or otherwise ingest their products.Experts say the very ingredients that make bleach so effective at killing viruses on surfaces is what makes them toxic to the human body and have sent an increasing number of people to the ER with accidental poisonings.Visit Business Insider’s homepage for more stories.When President Trump heard about the power of heat
column11: ultraviolet light
column12: and bleach to kill the novel coronavirus on surfaces during a White House coronavirus press briefing April 23
column13: he took the information an unscientific leap further."

column2: incomplete
column3: and just plain inaccurate information circulating about how to prevent the COVID-19 virus (“coronavirus”) from spreading
column4: ” a letter from the Blue Ridge Poison Center obtained by CBS19 read.“The Blue Ridge Poison Center at UVA Health warns that drinking bleach will not prevent COVID-19 infections and could cause serious injury.”The center told the station it has been receiving reports of people drinking cleaning products to protect them from the COVID-19 virus.“When used correctly
column5: cleaning products can be a safe and effective weapon against the spread of disease-causing germs including the COVID-19 virus
column6: ” the center said.“However
column7: these products and others used to clean and disinfect may have the potential to be toxic if used incorrectly.”The advisory echoes incidents in Iran
column8: where dozens died from drinking bootleg liquor
column9: thinking it would fight off the virus.So far
column10: more than 4
column11: 200 cases of the virus in the United States and its territories have been reported
column12: including 75 deaths
column13: according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.At least 51 cases have been reported in Virginia.- READ MOREListen to the insightful Thomas Paine Podcast Below --Share: Previous ArticleChina Threatens EMP Attack in South China Sea Next ArticleActress Rosanna Arquette Issues Vicious Tweet: Jewish Conspiracy Behind Coronavirus 0 admin March 18

column7: Ga. (CBS46) -- Pictures
column8: posts and memes mocking President Trump’s comment about disinfectants and Coronavirus have flooded many social media timelines.However
column9: after that statement suggesting injections of disinfectants can stave off Covid-19
column10: areas around the country reported a spike in calls to poison control centers.The president later said he was merely being sarcastic.On Monday during a press conference
column11: President Trump said he wouldn’t take any responsibility for people using disinfectants
column12: even if they were to die.Director of the Georgia Poison Control Center Gaylord Lopez said he hasn’t seen an increase in the number of calls.However he did say two men reportedly drank cleaning chemicals over the weekend.One of them allegedly consumed 16 ounces of bleach and was in the hospital for 24 hours."

column10: 2020 mariya smith0 In the wake of Russia’s meddling in the 2016 election
column11: Facebook and Twitter have been forced to respond to the proliferation of fake news on their platforms.And while many probably assume that the bulk of that misinformation is political in focus
column12: trolls and bots on social media have actually been linked to the marketing of vaping products
column13: the anti-vax movement and now
column14: fake cures for coronavirus.A quick glance at Facebook
column15: Twitter
column16: Instagram or TikTok will provide a slew of these fake cures: garlic
column17: masturbation
column18: bleach
column19: even cocaine.Prominent QAnon YouTuber Jordan Sather
column20: for example
column21: tweeted out to his more than 121k followers that a “miracle mineral solution
column22: ” which effectively involves drinking bleach
column23: can wipe out COVID-19.”Not only is chlorine dioxide (aka “MMS”) an effective cancer cell killer
column24: it can wipe out coronavirus too
column25: ” he wrote.“Big Pharma wants you ignorant.” Would you look at that.Not only is chlorine dioxide (aka “MMS”) an effective cancer cell killer
column26: it can wipe out coronavirus too.No wonder YouTube has been censoring basically every single video where I discuss it over the last year.Big Pharma wants you ignorant.https://t.co/7cqmyUxcXY— Jordan Sather (@Jordan_Sather_) January 23
column27: 2020 The FDA has long warned that drinking chlorine dioxide products can lead to “severe vomiting
column28: severe diarrhea
column29: life-threatening low blood pressure caused by dehydration
column30: and acute liver failure.” Yet
column31: with each new outbreak or high-profile illness that arises
column32: these products are seemingly promoted on social media and sold by independent distributors anew."

column3: Texas (KFDA) - The Texas Panhandle Poison Center is clearing up some confusion on how to prevent the coronavirus from spreading.In a news release
column4: the center is warning the public that drinking bleach won’t prevent COVID-19 and that it could actually cause some serious injuries.Cleaning products
column5: like bleach and hand sanitzer
column6: are safe and effective weapons to prevent the spread of germs
column7: including the coronavirus.While the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends to use diluted bleach solutions on surfaces
column8: children and even adults could mistake it for a drink if it’s rebottled.In fact
column9: exposure to cleaning products is the second leading cause of calls to poison centers nationwide.Children under the age of six are at risk because their curiosity could lead them to swallowing or eating cleaning products that are left within reach."

column11: 2020 / 09:19 AM EDT Please enable Javascript to watch this video WASHINGTON (AP) — The House approved legislation early Saturday to provide direct relief to Americans suffering physically
column12: financially and emotionally from the coronavirus pandemic.President Donald Trump on Friday declared the outbreak a national emergency
column13: freeing up money and resources to fight it
column14: then threw his support behind the congressional aid package.From the Rose Garden
column15: Trump said
column16: “I am officially declaring a national emergency
column17: unleashing as much as $50 billion for state and local governments to respond to the crisis.Trump also announced a range of executive actions
column18: including a new public-private partnership to expand coronavirus testing capabilities with drive-through locations
column19: as Washington tries to subdue the new virus whose spread is roiling markets
column20: shuttering institutions and disrupting the lives of everyday Americans.But he denied any responsibility for delays in making testing available as his administration has come under criticism for being too slow to respond.Trump said
column21: “I don't take responsibility at all"" for the slow rollout of testing."

column8: 2020 / 08:34 AM MDT / Updated: Mar 14
column9: 2020 / 08:34 AM MDT CLEVELAND (WJW) — The Cuyahoga County Court in Ohio is looking to release hundreds of inmates from the Cuyahoga County Jail Saturday morning due to coronavirus concerns
column10: according to our sister station WJW in Cleveland.Judges concerned about the virus spreading through the jail.Cuyahoga County judges are holding a special Saturday morning session to try to settle cases with guilty pleas
column11: release inmates or send them to prison
column12: or release them on house arrest.Administrative Judge Brendan Sheehan told the I-TEAM earlier this week that inmates are already in poor health
column13: and it wouldn’t take much for the coronavirus to spread wildly behind bars.Sheehan also said almost any kind of inmate could be considered.“You gotta remember
column14: the goal of this is to protect the community and the safety of the inmates."

column6: one of which included a child from Westerly who recently received an autograph from a Utah Jazz player with the virus
column7: town officials confirmed Friday.Westerly Police Chief Shawn Lacey said two kids from Westerly tested positive: one is a 2nd grader at Springbrook Elementary School
column8: the other
column9: a toddler
column10: lives in Westerly but attends preschool in Mystic
column11: Connecticut.He said the children are not related.As a result
column12: Westerly Superintendent Mark Garceau said Springbrook students and staff have been asked to self-quarantine through March 25.Lacey said one of the children had recently returned from a cruise to the Bahamas
column13: and the other had received an autograph from one of the two Utah Jazz players who tested positive for the virus when the team played the Boston Celtics this past weekend.He did not specify which child attended the NBA game
column14: which was played at the TD Garden in Boston."

column9: there are several food delivery services available to bring food to your door.In addition to individual restaurants with delivery services (check their websites)
column10: the following services are available: DoorDash — will deliver from several restaurants including Chipolte
column11: Firehouse Tavern
column12: and McDonald’s.Postmates — will deliver from several local restaurants as well as chains like Five Guys
column13: Denny’s and SubwayUber Eats — will deliver from Panda Express
column14: Popeye’s
column15: and Donatos Pizza
column16: among several othersGrub Hub — will deliver from chains like Buffalo Wild Wings
column17: Taco Bell
column18: and Wendy’sEatStreet — works more closely with local restaurants instead of national chainsClusterTruck — an independently owned

column3: 2020 5:26 am Lysol maker: Please don’t drink our cleaning products The company that makes Lysol is urging customers not to consume its cleaning products after President Donald Trump suggested the possibility of injecting disinfectants to protect people from coronavirus.Reckitt Benckiser
column4: a British company
column5: warned Friday that human consumption of disinfectant products is dangerous warned.It issued the statement following “recent speculation and social media activity.” “As a global leader in health and hygiene products
column6: we must be clear that under no circumstance should our disinfectant products be administered into the human body (through injection
column7: ingestion or any other route)
column8: ” the company said in a statement.RB said products should only be “used as intended and in line with usage guidelines.“We have a responsibility in providing consumers with access to accurate
column9: up-to-date information as advised by leading public health experts
column10: ” the company said.The statement followed remarks from President Trump on Thursday on the use of disinfectants."

column2: bleach or any disinfectant can cure coronavirus in the body.Credit... Suzanne Kreiter/The Boston Globe via Getty ImagesBy Amelia NierenbergApril 24
column4: 4:50 p.m. ETThere is no evidence that sunlight can cure coronavirus on the human body.Same for disinfectant and bleach.So
column5: do not drink bleach.Do not inject disinfectant.And do not believe there is some cure for coronavirus coming from ultraviolet light.During Thursday’s White House coronavirus briefing
column6: a science administrator
column7: Wiliam N. Bryan
column8: said the government had tested how sunlight and disinfectants like bleach and alcohol can quickly kill Covid-19 on surfaces.Hearing that
column9: President Trump returned to the lectern.He speculated about injecting a disinfectant into a human body."

column2: 2020 @ 3:43am Shot of an attractive young woman seated on a washing machine while holding bleach to wash her washing with inside of a laundry room during the dayWhile one would assume common sense would prevent most people from doing this
column3: but the fact that the warning had to be issued honestly doesn’t surprise me personally.A Virginia poison center has actually issued the following warning: “Drinking bleach will not prevent you from getting the coronavirus.” Issued by the Blue Ridge Poison Center
column4: the warning makes sure to clearly inform the citizens of this proud community that bleach is “for cleaning
column5: not drinking” — and it can cause serious internal damage when ingested.via GIPHY That being said
column6: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says bleach will kill the coronavirus on frequently touched surfaces.Even then
column7: don’t go pouring bleach everywhere my fellow idiots.The CDC recommends mixing five tablespoons of bleach per gallon of water.What’s the worst thing you’ve ingested?"

column9: Sputnik
column10: Kremlin Pool Photo via AP) MOSCOW (AP) — Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a law on constitutional changes that could keep him in power for another 16 years
column11: a step that must still be approved in a nationwide vote.Putin signed the measure on Saturday
column12: the Kremlin said
column13: three days after it sailed through the Russian parliament with only one vote against.It must be approved by the country’s Constitutional Court and in a referendum set for April 22.Under current law
column14: Putin would not be able to run for president again in 2024 because of term limits
column15: but the new measure would reset his term count
column16: allowing him to run for two more six-year terms.He has been in power since 2000."

column12: 2020 / 08:50 AM EDT / Updated: Mar 14
column13: 2020 / 09:18 AM EDT Please enable Javascript to watch this video CLEVELAND (WJW) — As the number of coronavirus cases grows
column14: officials in Ohio and across the country are taking actions to prevent further spread.President Trump declared a national emergency Friday
column15: opening up $50 billion for state and local governments to respond to the outbreak.The declaration gave the Secretary of Health and Human Services Secretary emergency authority to waive federal regulations and laws to give doctors and hospitals “flexibility” in treating patients.The president also suspended the accrual of interest on federal student loans indefinitely to help ease the financial burden of the situation.Meanwhile
column16: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi passed coronavirus relief legislation to provide direct relief to Americans suffering physically
column17: financially and emotionally from the pandemic.The measure also adds paid emergency leave and free testing for COVID-19."

column4: fake news and false cures you should avoid By Jasper Hamill Reporter Lab technicians handle suspected COVID-19 samples as they carry out a diagnostic test for coronavirus (Image: PA) 1 comment Under normal circumstances
column5: few people would consider drinking bleach or taking a bath in cow dung.But these are not ordinary times and the spread of the feared Wuhan coronavirus has prompted an outpouring of strange
column6: unscientific ""cures"" and fake news on social media.Teams of researchers around the world are frantically trying to find drugs or vaccines to treat Covid-19.It’s thought that a vaccine is at least one year away and although an Australian team has claimed drugs used to treat HIV or malaria could beat the coronavirus
column7: we’re some away from a genuine cure.That hasn’t stopped fakers and scammers from circulating wild claims about how to beat the disease.A Sense About Science guide to dealing with fake news and conspiracy theories Tracey Brown
column8: director of the charity Sense about Science
column9: urged the public to look out for fake news and check everything they read online."

column7: bleach: Doctors reject Trump’s ‘idiotic’ coronavirus cures By Josh K. Elliott Global News Posted April 24
column8: 2020 11:35 am Updated April 24
column9: 2020 11:51 am 3:58 Trump’s disinfectant suggestion “dangerous and idiotic” and “hugely irresponsible
column10: ” doctor says WATCH: Doctors and health experts urged people not to drink or inject disinfectant on Friday after U.S. President Donald Trump suggested scientists should investigate inserting the cleaning agent into the body as a way to cure COVID-19.comments Leave a comment facebook Share this item whatsapp Share this item via WhatsApp twitter Share this item on Twitter email Send this page to someone via email more Share this item more Share this item Smaller font Descrease article font size -A Larger font Increase article font size A+ Share this item facebook Share this item via WhatsApp whatsapp Share this item on Twitter twitter Send this page to someone via email email Share this item on Pinterest pinterest Share this item on LinkedIn linkedin Share this item on Reddit reddit Copy article link Copy link U.S. President Donald Trump is not a doctor
column11: but he tried playing one on live TV Thursday by throwing out unproven guesses for stopping the coronavirus pandemic
column12: which has killed tens of thousands of American citizens.Speaking from the White House during his daily press briefing
column13: the former real estate mogul and reality TV star floated the idea of injecting oneself with bleach or blasting the virus with ultraviolet light and heat — i.e.tanning — as potential tactics for killing the virus that causes COVID-19.He also raised the possibility of shining light inside the body to kill the virus.READ MORE: ‘Give me liberty or … COVID-19’ — The irony of coronavirus protests in the U.S. Dr. Deborah Birx
column14: the only real medical expert in the room from Trump’s team
column15: only half-smiled and blinked in astonishment.The president also did not present any hard evidence of his claims
column16: although he did trot out his top science official with the Department of Homeland Security to pitch the sunlight idea based on anecdotal evidence."

column3: the fact that the warning had to be issued makes one wonder.A Virginia poison center has issued the following warning: “Drinking bleach will not prevent you from getting the coronavirus.” Issued by the Blue Ridge Poison Center
column4: the warning says bleach is “for cleaning
column5: not drinking” — and it can cause serious internal damage when ingested.That said
column6: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says bleach will kill the coronavirus on frequently touched surfaces.But even then
column7: don’t use it full-strength.The CDC recommends mixing five tablespoons of bleach per gallon of water.TAGS bleach cdc corey foley coronavirus mitch elliott myth poison #Trending Series 2: #10 Mike Zupan - Zupan's Markets Series 2: #11 Judah Newby - The State of Oregon Sports FLASHBACK: Series 1: #41 - Bill Schonely Series 2: #9 - A Look at Anthony Bourdain Series 2: #12 May Arden - Opera | Last Man Recently Played March 18th

column1: 39 eccb3956-810f-470e-9a9a-b6b8ef8bc665 "Calls to U.S. poison centers spiked as coronavirus spread | FOX 13 Tampa Bay NewsCoronavirusWeatherSportsGood DayWe Live Here More Expand / Collapse search Watch Live ☰ Search site News Watch LiveLocalConsumerHealthPoliticsFOX 13 InvestigatesSeen on TVCoronavirus Latest from FloridaClosings & cancellationsSymptoms & preventionMap: Florida casesMap: Worldwide casesWatch CoronavirusNOWCoronavirusNOW.comWeather SkyTower Radar ViewsLive Radar FeedInteractive RadarMarine WeatherLive WebcamsTropicsMyFoxHurricaneSports BuccaneersRaysLightningHigh School SportsGood Day TrafficCharley's WorldHometown HeroesExtraordinary OrdinariesRecipesFirst BirthdaysWe Live Here What's RightOne Tank TripsTheme ParksBay Area BestCare ForceAbout Us FOX 13 News StaffWhat's On FOXContestsWTVT HistoryJobs & InternshipsClosed CaptioningContact Us Calls to U.S. poison centers spiked as coronavirus spread By Arun Kristian Das Published 17 hours ago Updated 5 hours ago Coronavirus FOX 5 NY Facebook Twitter Print Email article (CDC MMWR) NEW YORK - Poison control hotlines around the U.S. reported a 20% increase in calls related to exposure to household cleaners and disinfectants in the first quarter of the year compared to the same period in 2019
column2: the CDC said.Although the agency stopped short of entirely pinning the increase on the efforts by Americans to clean their homes out of fear the coronavirus
column3: the number of daily calls to poison centers ""increased sharply"" in the beginning of March
column4: which tracks with the growth of COVID-19 cases and health warnings.""Although a casual association cannot be demonstrated
column5: the timing of these reported exposures correspond to increased media coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic
column6: reports of consumer shortages of cleaning and disinfectant products
column7: and the beginning of some local and state stay-at-home orders
column8: a CDC Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report stated.>MORE CORONAVIRUS COVERAGEThe MMWR highlighted a disturbing case of a woman who said she heard on the news that she should clean groceries before consuming them.———— Get breaking news alerts in the FOX5NY News app.It's FREE!Download for iOS or Android ————""She filled a sink with a mixture of 10% bleach solution
column9: vinegar

column2: 2020 4:43AM ET Allstar Picture Library Limited / AlamyHoping to ward off a global pandemic with no known cure
column3: Americans have turned to increasingly desperate options: swallowing fish tank cleaner
column4: popping colloidal silver
column5: chugging Alex Jones’ “Superblue Silver Immune Gargle.” But the latest trend comes from a source a little closer to home: human breast milk.Milk sellers across the country told The Daily Beast they have seen an increase in buyers reaching out to purchase breast milk—not to feed their babies
column6: but to boost their immunity against the new coronavirus.While the practice is rare
column7: and highly discouraged by health experts
column8: the principle behind it is being studied by at least two prominent universities.“It’s an interesting idea
column9: ” said Lars Bode
column10: chair of Collaborative Human Milk Research at the University of California
column11: San Diego.“Maybe not the right thing to do for multiple different reasons.” But the idea that human milk could contain COVID-fighting properties?"

column2: 2020 - 08:45 Breast pumpblanscapeDepositPhotosDeposit Photos Researchers at Amsterdam University Medical Center are studying whether breast milk can be used to protect vulnerable groups
column3: like the elderly and young babies
column4: against the coronavirus.They are looking into whether mothers who have recovered from Covid-19 have antibodies against the virus in their breast milk.""It is perhaps a strange picture
column5: elderly people drinking breast milk
column6: researcher Brit van Keulen said on the Amsterdam UMC website.""But if it protects against a deadly virus
column7: we should just get over that embarrassment.""It is already well established that breast milk protects newborn children against respiratory infections
column8: Van Keulen explained.""This is because there are antibodies in breast milk."

column1: 40 437eddd5-70dd-4f78-a7bd-4893b74f544c "Breastfeeding babies 'helps prevent viral infection' in the first months after birth | Daily Mail Online Home U.K. News Sports U.S. Showbiz Australia Femail Health Science Money Video Travel Columnists DailyMailTV Latest Headlines Games My Profile Logout Login Feedback Wednesday
column2: Apr 15th 2020 1PM 51°F 4PM 53°F 5-Day Forecast Advertisement show ad Breastfeeding a baby 'can help prevent viral infection and illness' in the first four months after birth
column3: study findsUS scientists studied stools of babies in search of signs of viral infection Found little or no sign of virus colonisation in a baby's gut at birth   Found 30% of infants fed only on formula milk had viruses at four months old  But only 9% of children of the same age that were fed on a diet including breastmilk carried viruses By Joe Pinkstone For Mailonline and Colin Fernandez Science Correspondent For The Daily Mail Published: 13:46 EDT
column4: 15 April 2020 | Updated: 13:49 EDT
column5: 15 April 2020 e-mail 1 View comments Babies who are breastfed in infancy carry fewer harmful viruses in their guts than those fed exclusively on bottle milk
column6: a study claims.Scientists studied the first stools of 20 babies aged up to four days and a separate group of 124 babies aged between one and four months.Evidence from the faecal matter found even a mixed diet of breast and formula milk strongly inhibits the build-up of viral populations in the infant gut.Less than one in ten (nine per cent) of four-month-old babies given breast milk – or a combination of breast and bottle feeds – carried viruses.However
column7: 30 per cent of infants fed only on formula milk had viruses at this age.Scroll down for video Babies who are breastfed in infancy carry fewer harmful viruses in their guts than those fed exclusively on bottle milk
column8: a study claims.Less than one in ten (nine per cent) of four-month-old babies given breast milk – or a combination of breast and bottle feeds – carried viruses (stock photo)What is the NHS advice for breastfeeding mothers?The NHS guidance for getting your baby to latch onto your breast is as follows:  Hold your baby close to you with their nose level with the nipple.Wait until your baby opens their mouth really wide with their tongue down."

column4: B.Sc.Mar 26 2020 Researchers at University of California San Diego School of Medicine are launching a pair of studies to answer critical questions regarding the roles COVID-19 may play in breast milk and pregnancy.Breastmilk and COVID-19 The University of California San Diego School of Medicine and the Family Larsson-Rosenquist Foundation (FLRF) are collaborating to launch studies into breastfeeding and breast milk as they relate to COVID-19.As part of a larger consortium
column5: researchers will address two critical questions: Is COVID-19 transmitted via human milk?Can breast milk protect infants from COVID-19?We already know breast milk contains properties that help protect infants from diseases
column6: such as diarrhea and pulmonary infections."

column2: 2020 / 9:18 AM Breast milk may help shield infants from catching viruses By HealthDay News (0) New mothers have long been told that breast milk is best for their baby
column3: and now there's more evidence that breastfeeding helps protect babies against potentially harmful viruses.With the coronavirus pandemic on everyone's mind
column4: the new research is especially timely.However
column5: the report did not look specifically at the virus that causes COVID-19.For the study
column6: the investigators analyzed the types and numbers of viruses in the first and subsequent stools of hundreds of newborns in the United States and Botswana.Immediately after birth
column7: the babies had little or no evidence of viruses or bacteria
column8: but their numbers were high by time the babies were a month old
column9: the researchers found.RELATED Study: Breastfeeding may reduce risk for ovarian cancer by 24% Most of the first wave of viruses were beneficial ones
column10: but those that can make people sick were more prominent by age 4 months."

column1: 40 57836f50-717b-41b4-b2d3-70d90a72a228 "Coronavirus With a Baby: Here's What Parents Need to Know Trending Latest Sections Tech Health Space Environment Humans Physics Nature Politics & Society Comment & Opinion Sections Tech Health Space Environment Humans Physics Nature Politics & Society Comment & Opinion Follow Us Facebook Twitter Instagram Daily Email RSS Feed Company About Us Our Team Contact Us Privacy Policy Terms & Conditions © ScienceAlert Pty Ltd. All rights reserved.(Westend61/Getty Images) HEALTH Coronavirus With a Baby: Here's What Parents Need to Know KARLEEN GRIBBLE & NINA JANE CHAD
column2: THE CONVERSATION 13 MARCH 2020 If you have a baby
column3: you may be worried about them catching the coronavirus
column4: particularly after media reports of an Australian infant diagnosed with it.The good news is
column5: the evidence so far is babies almost never get seriously ill from the coronavirus.And even if infected
column6: they may have no symptoms.However
column7: the coronavirus could affect infants in other ways.For instance
column8: there may be difficulties accessing health care
column9: consumer goods and child care.Thinking about these possibilities now
column10: and preparing for them
column11: can help you manage what may come.Health care access may be tricky
column12: but there are waysIf the coronavirus becomes widespread
column13: the health system will struggle to cope for a while.Up to 20 percent of people who get COVID-19 need treatment in hospital for up to two weeks or more.Hospitals and general practices may be overwhelmed by others sick with the coronavirus
column14: which may make it difficult to access health care if your baby gets sick for any reason.Recognising this
column15: the Australian government recently announced special provisions for parents of newborns to be bulk-billed when consulting a doctor or nurse via phone or video call rather than in person.There are also things you can do to help keep your baby healthy so they don't need medical treatment.By protecting them
column16: you also protect the people around them who may be more vulnerable to serious illness from the coronavirus."

column1: 40 5c3157fa-98db-4abe-9abd-03a808fae6c2 "Breast Milk Is Being Studied As Potential Coronavirus ProtectionRomperJamie Grill/The Image Bank/Getty ImagesBreast Milk Is Being Studied As Potential Coronavirus ProtectionBy Morgan BrinleeApril 16
column2: 2020ShareAmid the ongoing pandemic
column3: a New York-based scientist is studying breast milk's potential to protect against coronavirus.Rebecca Powell
column4: a human milk immunologist
column5: researcher
column6: and assistant professor at The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York City
column7: is researching whether or not antibodies found in breast milk can protect against the novel coronavirus.While studies have already proven that breast milk has a number of benefits for babies' immune systems — helping to ward off a number of diseases and infections both during breastfeeding and after being weaned — it's less clear if it could protect against coronavirus.In an effort to examine breast milk's potential to protect against COVID-19
column8: the respiratory illness caused by the coronavirus currently infecting millions of people around the world
column9: Powell is looking to obtain breast milk samples from women living in New York City
column10: a hot spot for the virus
column11: or who have been confirmed to have had the virus.Powell told VICE News that she intends to check each sample she receives for COVID-19 antibodies to determine if the supplier was infected or exposed to the virus.Next she'll determine how many antibodies are present
column12: what classes they are
column13: how resistant they are
column14: and
column15: finally
column16: whether they have the ability to fight off the novel coronavirus."

column4: the internet is awash with bizarre conspiracy theories amid the worldwide coronavirus pandemic.Now
column5: a strange theory is doing the rounds
column6: claiming that ‘drinking breast milk can cure coronavirus.’ The theory suggests that breast milk ‘contains COVID-19 antibodies’ that when consumed
column7: can protect you from catching the virus.However
column8: doctors have now busted this myth
column9: saying there's absolutely no proof that drinking breast milk can prevent coronavirus.Speaking to CBS News
column10: Dr Dyan Hes
column11: a paediatrician with New York City’s Gramercy Paediatrics
column12: said: “There's no proof that breast milk at all can cure Covid or give you antibodies.Breast milk in bottles on refrigerator shelf (file image) (Image: Getty) Read More Related Articles Coronavirus: Diabetic patients with high blood glucose more likely to die
column13: study warns Read More Related Articles Coronavirus death rate is double for men than women in one age group
column14: new stats show ""There's no data that I know of that has been published yet about it.” Dr Hes added that while breast milk is good for a baby’s developing immune system
column15: there’s little evidence that breast milk contains coronavirus antibodies that are helpful to adults."

column6: breast milk can't prevent or cure COVID-19 in adults By Sophie Lewis April 14
column7: 2020 / 5:11 PM / CBS News COVID-19's stealth impact on children As fears of the coronavirus continue to spread in the United States
column8: some people have turned to unorthodox
column9: unproven and even dangerous methods to attempt to ward off the disease.Now
column10: rumors are spreading that breast milk could contain COVID-19 antibodies
column11: but doctors say there's no evidence to support that claim.""There's no proof that breast milk at all can cure COVID or give you antibodies
column12: Dr. Dyan Hes
column13: a pediatrician with New York City's Gramercy Pediatrics
column14: told CBSN's Anne-Marie Green and Vladimir Duthiers on Tuesday.""There's no data that I know of that has been published yet about it.""For years
column15: people have been selling and buying human breast milk online for adult consumption
column16: touting its supposed benefits as a ""superfood"" with immune-boosting properties.These claims have been repeatedly debunked by doctors
column17: who say drinking breast milk as an adult has no health benefit and can lead to a number of illnesses."

column2: 2020 / 03:59 PM PDT / Updated: Mar 26
column3: 2020 / 03:59 PM PDT SAN DIEGO (CNS) — The University of California San Diego School of Medicine and the Family Larsson-Rosenquist Foundation have collaborated to launch twin studies into breastfeeding and breast milk as they relate to COVID-19.In the first study
column4: researchers will address two questions: “Is COVID-19 transmitted via human milk?” and “Can breast milk protect infants from COVID-19?” “We already know breast milk contains properties that help protect infants from diseases
column5: such as diarrhea and pulmonary infections
column6: ” said Dr. Lars Bode
column7: director of UC San Diego’s Larsson-Rosenquist Foundation Mother-Milk- Infant Center of Research Excellence.“We urgently need to determine whether or not the virus is found in breast milk and discover breast milk components with antiviral properties that could protect infants from COVID-19.” The foundation is donating $100
column8: 000 to assist scientists at the research center.In a collaborative effort with other human milk research labs
column9: the center seeks to determine whether or not the virus is present in breast milk.These technologies will be available for clinical studies planned at UC San Diego and elsewhere.The center is teaming with UC San Diego virologists and infectious disease specialists to screen breast milk components for their potential antiviral properties."

column1: 40 9239ff9e-c3cd-4a61-b7c7-bff6287154e7 "Cautious hope for antibody to coronavirus in breast milk Inland – Infosurhoy Press ""Enter"" to skip to content Search Search Infosurhoy InfosurhoyApril 25
column2: 2020Latest Science News and Reports | Latest Breaking News open menu Back Cautious hope for antibody to coronavirus in breast milk Inland By Denis Bedoya on April 25
column3: 2020 15SHARESShareTweet “We know that breast milk protects newborn children against respiratory infections
column4: ” said Britt van Keulen
column5: a doctor at the Dutch Mother’s Milk Bank of Amsterdam UMC and involved in the study.“That’s because there are antibodies in breast milk
column6: ” she continues.“By breastfeeding
column7: the mother passes on her own antibodies to her child.” Van Keulen suspects that corona antibodies could also pass into breast milk.She refers to a woman who was pregnant during the 2003 sars outbreak.“This woman became seriously infected with the Sars virus and gave birth to a healthy baby at 38 weeks.Antibodies to the sars virus were found in her breast milk."

column1: 40 9f11cdec-e4a1-4c8d-a3ca-c5c7ac1ea463 "Breast milk may lead to fewer viruses in infants - OrissaPOST Home State Metro National International Business Opinion Feature Timeout Entertainment Sports Sci-Tech IPL 2020 Others Coronavirus Olympics 2020 Rajya Sabha Polls CAA JNU Home State Metro National International Business Opinion Feature Timeout Entertainment Sports Sci-Tech IPL 2020 Others Coronavirus Olympics 2020 Rajya Sabha Polls CAA JNU No Result View All Result Home Feature Breast milk may lead to fewer viruses in infants Indo-Asian News Service Updated: April 18th
column3: 07:16 IST 0 Share on FacebookShare on TwitterShare on WhatsAppShare on Linkedin New York: Even small amounts of breast milk strongly influences the accumulation of viral populations in the infant’s gut and provides a protective effect against potentially pathogenic viruses
column4: according to a new study.The findings expand upon prior research that suggests that breastfeeding plays a key role in the interaction between babies and the microbial environment.This latest research
column5: published in the journal Nature
column6: could influence strategies for the prevention of early gastrointestinal disorders
column7: and encourage mothers to feed babies breast milk even when mixed with formula.“These findings can help us better understand why some babies get sick and develop life-threatening infections in their first months of life
column8: ” said study senior author Frederic Bushman from the University of Pennsylvania in the US.For the findings
column9: the research team measured the numbers and types of viruses in the first stool — meconium — and subsequent stools of newborns in the US and Botswana using advanced genome sequencing and other methods.Upon delivery
column10: babies had little or no colonization
column11: but by one month of life populations of viruses and bacteria were well developed
column12: with numbers of viruses reaching a billion per gram of gut contents."

column6: they should follow the guidelines everyone should follow.That includes frequent washing of hands
column7: not touching your face
column8: face mask if going out and minimal contact with others.Continue to attend prenatal doctor visits."

column3: 07:05 IST 0 Share on FacebookShare on TwitterShare on WhatsAppShare on Linkedin New York: During the current coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic
column4: breastfeeding and the provision of human milk to infants is recommended by national and international organisations because it is effective against infectious diseases– It strengthens the immune system by directly transferring antibodies from the mother
column5: say researchers.While the current coronavirus continues to affect all people
column6: families will still give birth and bring new life into the world.In the study
column7: published in the Journal of Obstetric
column8: Gynecologic and Neonatal Nursing
column9: researchers at the University of Pennsylvania provides guidance regarding breastfeeding and COVID-19 and reaffirms why it is of paramount importance to promote and protect the use of human milk and breastfeeding.“While it is unknown if COVID-19-positive mothers can transmit the virus through milk
column10: in limited studies the virus has not been detected in human milk
column11: ” said study author Diane Lynn Spatz from the University of Pennsylvania in the US.According to the researchers
column12: during this current pandemic
column13: there have been reports of formula shortages and price gouging the cost of infant formula.“We should use this pandemic as a way to increase the visibility of the critical role of human milk and breastfeeding for all families at all times and educate the public about the importance of the use of human milk and breastfeeding as lifesaving medical interventions
column14: ” She added."

column2: Singapore Edition Asia Pacific World Technology Business Sports Entertainment Science Coronavirus World Will drinking breast milk cure you from Coronavirus?Here is the truthRumours are doing the rounds on social media that drinking breast milk helps a person not to catch coronavirus By Vinod DSouza April 18
column3: 2020 19:43 +08 Close 12 people die of Coronavirus after attending Jewish wedding in Morocco From claims that 5G caused the coronavirus to the proclamation that eating garlic can cure the disease
column4: the internet is dark and filled with conspiracy theories that can blow your mind.A new yet strange conspiracy theory is now doing the rounds that drinking breast milk can help a person not to catch the coronavirus
column5: as it contains antibodies that are good for the immune system and overall development.However
column6: doctors have busted this myth
column7: claiming there's absolutely no proof whatsoever that drinking breast milk can prevent a person from being infected with the coronavirus.Dr Dyan Hes
column8: a Paediatrician with New York City's Gramercy Paediatrics told CBS News
column9: ''There's no proof that breast milk at all can cure COVID or give you antibodies.here's no data that I know of that has been published yet about it.''"

column5: now called COVID-19 are rising drastically.Last year
column6: in December 2019 in China
column7: the virus has spread around the world.In the last few days
column8: seven more countries reported their first cases of coronavirus leading total numbers of countries affected by the COVID-19 outbreak to 56.As of Thursday
column9: more than 2
column10: 800 people have died globally from COVID-19 while more than 82
column11: 000 infections have been confirmed in dozens of countries
column12: according to the World Health Organization.MERS is caused by a coronavirus from the same family as the one that caused SARS.Reuters Epidemic at a ""decisive point globally"" Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

column33: ‘The Navhind Times’ highlights what one should do in protecting oneself from Coronavirus and preventing the spread of the disease What is Coronavirus?According to the World Health Organisation
column34: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV).A novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans.Coronaviruses are zoonotic
column35: meaning they are transmitted between animals and people.Investigations have found that SARS-CoV was transmitted from civet cats to humans and MERS-CoV from dromedary camels to humans."

column8: less than three months after the world was made aware of the novel coronavirus
column10: 000 people across 177 countries/regions have been infected with it.The infection which reportedly originated from a market in Wuhan city in the Chinese province of Hubei
column11: has claimed more than 27
column12: 800 lives.With nations entering lockdown in an effort to 'flatten the curve' of social interactions by means of social distancing
column13: it is very important to refrain from placing one's beliefs in any miraculous cures or conspiracy theories about COVID-19.Here are some widely shared myths about the novel coronavirus that stand nowhere on the scale of scientific relevance.Temperature
column14: humidity could affect transmission rate of Covid-19This is a myth.The World Health Organisation (WHO) has observed that this infection can be transmitted in any and all areas regardless of climate.Wearing a mask can prevent transmission of Covid-19This is not true.While wearing a mask in a crowded place is advisable
column15: the mask cannot prevent transmission of the novel coronavirus.In some cases where the person wearing the mask touches an infected surface before touching his/her face to re-adjust the mask
column16: this protective gear could lead to infection
column17: said the Director of the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Dr Randeep Guleria.Taking a hot bath can prevent infectionThis is a myth."

column4: Mass (WWLP) – The COVID-19 outbreak is a global pandemic
column5: and with that comes a lot of false information on the internet.There are many myths about COVID-19 that have been circulating through social media.Here are some of the most common ones
column6: according to the World Health Organization.Myth #1: Cold weather kills novel coronavirus Truth: The CDC and the WHO have said this from the start: the most effective way to protect yourself from COVID-19 is with frequent handwashing with soap and water or using hand sanitizer with at least 60 percent alcohol.The WHO says there is “no reason to believe cold weather can kill the new coronavirus
column7: ” or other diseases
column8: for that matter."

column4: offering practical steps to stay healthy.David MillsNews Corp Australia NetworkFebruary 29
