column7: and take at least 15 seconds
column8: doctors advise.Source:Getty ImagesSince China first alerted the world to cases of pneumonia in the port city of Wuhan on December 31
column9: fears about this strange new virus have spread even more quickly than the infection itself.More than 85
column10: 000 cases have now been reported in 58 countries
column11: with 24 in Australia.Some 164 people – formerly passengers on the stricken Diamond Princess cruise ship – remain in quarantine in the Northern Territory until March 5.These are some of the most common myths about 2019-nCoV and how you can protect yourself.CORONAVIRUS MYTH BUSTERSAre hand dryers effective in killing the new coronavirus?No.Hand dryers are not effective in killing the 2019-nCoV.To protect yourself against the new coronavirus
column12: you should frequently clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or wash them with soap and water.Can an ultraviolet disinfection lamp kill the new coronavirus?UV lamps should not be used to sterilise hands or other areas of skin as UV radiation can cause skin irritation.Can thermal scanners detect people infected with the new coronavirus?Thermal scanners are effective in detecting people who have developed a fever because of infection with the new coronavirus.However
column13: they cannot detect people who are infected but are not yet sick with fever.This is because it takes between 2 and 10 days before people who are infected become sick and develop a fever.Hand dryers will not stop coronavirus."

column6: 2020 Listen WHO blasts 19 common myths related to coronavirus LAHORE: Just a couple of days after the anti-5G technology protesters in Netherlands
column7: which has recorded around 3
column8: 000 deaths till date due to the ongoing pandemic
column9: had sabotaged phone towers in various cities including Rotterdam
column10: the Geneva-based World Health Organization (WHO) has come out dispelling the myth on its official website that 5G mobile networks do not spread Covid-19.The 5G is the fifth generation of wireless communications technologies supporting cellular data networks
column11: and it is expected to be one of the fastest wireless technologies ever created
column12: resulting in much quicker downloads etc.Large-scale adoption of this wireless technology began in 2019 and today virtually every telecommunication service provider in the developed world is upgrading its infrastructure to offer 5G functionality
column13: but people in various European countries
column14: including Holland
column15: have been expressing concerns over possible health risks and privacy violations since January this year
column16: when around 100 people had rallied against the 5G network in Amsterdam
column17: calling for its rejection on the basis of health and well-being.And now
column18: a vociferous section of the European public thinks 5G mobile networks are spreading Covid-19
column19: forcing the World Health Organization to blast this myth.Having a budget of over $4.2 billion
column20: the United Nations-led WHO thus comes to the fore to categorically declare: ""Viruses cannot travel on radio waves/mobile networks.Covid-19 is spreading in many countries that do not have 5G mobile networks."

column14: says surveyThis Canadian start-up used AI to track coronavirus and raised alarm days before the outbreakBy Krishna Kumar When it comes to infectious diseases
column15: prevention
column16: surveillance and rapid-response efforts can go a long way toward slowing or stalling outbreaks.When a pandemic such as the recent coronavirus outbreak happens
column17: it can create huge challenges for the government and public health officials to gather information quickly and coordinate a response.In such a situation
column18: artificial intelligence (AI) can play a huge role in predicting an outbreak and also minimising or stalling its spread.Detecting an epidemicAI algorithms can help mine through news reports and online content from around the world
column19: helping experts recognise anomalies even before it reaches epidemic proportions.The corona outbreak itself is a great example where researchers applied AI to study flight traveller data to predict where the novel coronavirus could pop up next.A National Geographic report demonstrates how monitoring the internet or social media can help detect the early stages of a potential outbreak."

column8: 17:49WORLD health chiefs are cracking down on ""dangerous"" myths circulating as the deadly coronavirus outbreak continues it's spread.Popular apps and social media platforms have become swamped with unverified information about how to stop yourself getting coronavirus
column9: the World Health Organization warned.Read our coronavirus live blog for all the latest news and updates 3 The new coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in an illustration released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)Credit: Reuters But now
column10: in an attempt to clamp down on these myths
column11: the WHO have debunked 13 of the main rumours - including spraying yourself with alcohol and using hand dryers to kill the bug.It comes as China's latest figures show 71
column12: 810 cases of the illness and 1
column13: 775 deaths - most of them in Hubei.WHO's guidance follows warnings from a coronavirus expert - who said the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories could trigger more cases in the UK.Professor Paul Hunter
column14: of the University of East Anglia's (UEA) Norwich Medical School
column15: said fake news leads to bad advice and people taking ""greater risks"" during health crises."

column17: Indians breathe easier as nation-wide lockdowns kick inSINGAPORE: It is unlikely that COVID-19 patients transmit the deadly novel coronavirus through their tears
column18: according to a study which sheds more light on how the virus spreads via bodily fluids.The study
column19: published in the journal Ophthalmology
column20: assessed tear samples collected from 17 patients with COVID-19 from the time they showed symptoms until they recovered about 20 days later.Since none of the patients had conjunctivitis
column21: also known as pink eye
column22: the researchers
column23: including those from the National Centre for Infectious Diseases in Singapore
column24: said the risk of virus transmission through tears is low.The scientists analysed the presence of the virus in tears samples from the patients throughout the two-week course of the disease.Ivan Seah from the National University Hospital in Singapore also took samples from the back of the nose and throat during the same time period."

column1: 41 d79927e3-a709-47d6-a2b9-826d6fe3762d "Myth Busters: 19 Wrong Beliefs About The Novel Coronavirus – Channels Television CHANNELS TELEVISION LIVE TVLISTENPODCASTS NIGERIA's 13-TIME TV STATION OF THE YEARLOCALPOLITICSBUSINESSHEALTHSPORTSTECHAFRICAWORLD More GoSectionsElections 2019HeadlinePoliticsLocalHealthBusinessEntertainmentEnvironmentSportsCrimePROGRAMSBusiness MorningHard CopyNetwork AfricaPolitics TodaySports This MorningSunrise DailySunriseMore ProgramsLIVE TVPC & MaciPad & iPhoneAndroidListenAPPsDownload Android AppDownload for iOSDownload for Windows PhoneABOUT USAbout Channels TelevisionMeet The TeamExecutive ManagementManagementPresentersContactPrivacy PolicyAdvertise Advertisement Myth Busters: 19 Wrong Beliefs About The Novel Coronavirus Channels Television  Updated April 30
column2: 2020  There is so much information out there about the novel coronavirus
column3: however
column4: a great percent of what has been said are untrue or misleading.At this time when this pandemic has brought the world to its knees
column5: we cannot afford to be misinformed about the virus we are battling and what can be done to see that COVID-19 is eventually defeated.Here are some wrong beliefs that must be shunned if we are to make a headway in this fight against COVID-19.5G mobile networks DO NOT spread COVID-19Viruses cannot travel on radio waves/mobile networks.COVID-19 is spreading in many countries that do not have 5G mobile networks.COVID-19 is spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs
column6: sneezes or speaks.People can also be infected by touching a contaminated surface and then their eyes
column7: mouth or nose.Exposing yourself to the sun or to temperatures higher than 25C degrees DOES NOT prevent the coronavirus disease (COVID-19)You can catch COVID-19
column8: no matter how sunny or hot the weather is.Countries with hot weather have reported cases of COVID-19.To protect yourself
column9: make sure you clean your hands frequently and thoroughly and avoid touching your eyes
column10: mouth
column11: and nose.You can recover from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19).Catching the new coronavirus DOES NOT mean you will have it for life.Most of the people who catch COVID-19 can recover and eliminate the virus from their bodies."

column7: adopt protective measures if you live in

column8: 2020By Niharika SharmaAviation and social media reporterIndia has confirmed nearly 40 cases of the novel coronavirus till now.What’s fuelling a wave of fear across the country
column9: though
column10: is the usual avalanche of fake news on WhatsApp
column11: Facebook and Twitter.So much so that prime minister Narendra Modi had to publicly appeal last weekend to stay away from rumours and follow doctors’ advice.Quartz looked at some of the most widespread claims shared on social media and spoke to experts to verify them.“The most common symptoms of Covid-19 are fever

column11: is yet to be shown.“One major application is in medical situations – the disinfection of personal protective equipment
column12: surfaces

column14: within the HVAC systems
column15: et cetera
column16: ” said study co-author Christian Zollner from the University of California Santa Barbara in the US.Zollner
column17: whose work centres on advancing deep ultraviolet light LED technology for sanitation and purification purposes
column18: added that a small market already exists for UV-C disinfection products in medical contexts.Pointing out the different types of ultraviolet light
column19: Zollner said
column20: UV-A and UV-B are light the Earth gets courtesy of the Sun with important uses
column21: and the rare UV-C is the light of choice for purifying air and water and for inactivating microbes.“UV-C light in the 260 – 285 nanometre wavelength range most relevant for current disinfection technologies is also harmful to human skin
column22: so for now it is mostly used in applications where no one is present at the time of disinfection

column1: 44 58bae335-1c08-4b21-ba0e-3cac68d8788b "Treatment Of Corona-Virus Through Passive Immunization Is A Big Achievement Of Pakistan Scientists - UrduPoint Skip to main content Home Election 2018 Pakistan Politics Crime Middle East Saudi Arabia UAE Bahrain Kuwait Qatar Egypt Jordan Palestine Lebanon Iraq Syria Yemen World Politics Crime Sports Cricket Football Hockey Miscellaneous PSL 2018 PSL 2019 PSL 2020 Business Technology Showbiz Miscellaneous Hollywood Bollywood Lollywood Fashion Health Education Kashmir More WeatherAgricultureNews FeatureInfotainment BlogViralScienceLifestyle Pictures Today News Pictures News Pictures Archive HomeHealthNewsTreatment of Corona-Virus through Passive Immunization is a big achievement of Pakistan Scientists Treatment Of Corona-Virus Through Passive Immunization Is A Big Achievement Of Pakistan Scientists 3 minutes ago Wed 15th April 2020 | 05:48 PM Passive immunity is the transfer of active humoral immunity of ready-made antibodies.When an antibody formed in one individual such as in immunoglobulin therapy or antiserum therapy is given to those individuals who are at higher risk of infection.Writer: Dr.Shaukat Chauhdary Passive immunity is the transfer of active humoral immunity of ready-made antibodies.When an antibody formed in one individual such as in immunoglobulin therapy or antiserum therapy is given to those individuals who are at higher risk of infection.How it works: Antibodies are taken from those who have recovered
column2: or have gained immunity
column3: are given to the sick.This way
column4: there is a chance of recovery if the patients cannot develop their own immunity."

column7: those experiencing respiratory failure who become ventilator dependent.The trial is entitled Randomized Open Label Study of Standard of Care Plus Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG) Compared to Standard of Care Alone in the Treatment of COVID-19 Infection.Dr. Sakoulas
column8: an infectious disease clinician and Associate Editor for the New England Journal of Medicine's NEJM Journal Watch Infectious Diseases
column9: hopes to identify: Whether or not IVIG can halt coronavirus progression to respiratory failure requiring transfer into the intensive care unit (ICU) and mechanical ventilation in admitted COVID-19 patients; and Whether adding IVIG to the standard of care will reduce days requiring oxygen therapy and total hospital days.It is currently believed that 80% of COVID-19 subjects will require no medical treatment
column10: 15% will require non-ICU medical care
column11: and 5% may require ICU admission."

column3: 2020 6:40AM EDT Medical professionals would surely welcome any safe and effective treatment option for people with COVID-19 -- and pharmaceutical companies are doing their best to hastily find solutions.Preclinical and clinical trials now under way are testing seemingly every plausible hypothesis

column3: 2020 4:16PM EDT What happened Shares of Mesoblast (NASDAQ: MESO) fell as much as 22.3% today as investors decided to lock in gains.The stem-cell stock erupted for a 139% gain on Friday after data from a small study suggested the company's cell therapy might significantly improve outcomes for COVID-19 patients placed on mechanical ventilators.The promising early stage results pushed the company's market cap to over $1.6 billion.Mesoblast had been valued at $450 million a few weeks earlier.Today's move suggests investors are taking the biopharma's inexperience and the preliminary nature of the study's data into account.As of 3:58 p.m. EDT on Monday
column4: the small-cap stock had settled to a 21.5% loss."

column1: 45 7c95be2a-d9e9-49c5-88ab-5d2d7548ac0d "Mesoblast Shares Soar 120% After Reporting 83% Survival Rate in COVID-19 Patients with ARDS :: countingpips countingpips global macro investing Home News Opinions Research Free COTs Premium COTs MT4 MT4 Indicators MT4 Demo Accounts MT4 Help Docs Calendar Shop My Account Help 27 Apr Mesoblast Shares Soar 120% After Reporting 83% Survival Rate in COVID-19 Patients with ARDS April 27
column2: 2020 By The Life Science Report Source: Streetwise Reports   04/24/2020 Shares of Mesoblast more than doubled and set a new 52-week high price after the company reported that it achieved a 83% survival rate in New York ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients with moderate to severe acute respiratory distress syndrome who were treated with its allogeneic cell therapy remestemcel-L. Mesoblast Ltd. (MESO:NASDAQ; MSB:ASX) today announced that it had achieved an “83% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients (10/12) with moderate/severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) treated during the period March-April 2020 with two intravenous infusions of Mesoblast’s allogeneic mesenchymal stem cell product candidate remestemcel-L within the first five days.” The company stated that of the 12 patients treated
column3: 75% (9/12) successfully came off ventilator support after a median timeframe of 10 days.The firm advised that all of the patients were treated under an emergency Investigational New Drug (IDA) application or expanded access protocol at Mt.Sinai hospital in New York City and so far seven of the patients have been discharged from the hospital.The company noted that each of the patients had received a variety of experimental agents prior to being treated with remestemcel-L.The firm explained that until now only about 9% (38/445) of ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients at a major referral hospital network in New York City were able to come off ventilator support when treated with existing standard of care treatments during March and April 2020.The company reported that at a second major referral hospital network in New York City over the same period
column4: there was 88% mortality with only 12% survival (38/320) among ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients."

column1: 45 e0ee4d40-8261-4cc3-8c0a-76ca478df1fb "83% Survival in COVID-19 Patients with Moderate/Severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Treated in New York with Mesoblast’s Cell Therapy Remestemcel-L Australian Stock Exchange:MSB.AX GlobeNewswire Register Sign In English Français Contact Us Global Distribution Newswire Services Regulatory Filings Media Partners 83% Survival in COVID-19 Patients with Moderate/Severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Treated in New York with Mesoblast’s Cell Therapy Remestemcel-L Email Print Friendly Share April 24
column2: 2020 06:00 ET | Source: Mesoblast Limited Key points:  83% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients (10/12) with moderate/severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) treated with two infusions of Mesoblast’s allogeneic cell therapy remestemcel-L within the first five days under emergency compassionate use at New York City’s Mt Sinai hospital during the period March-April 2020 75% (9/12) have successfully come off ventilator support within a median of 10 days  These results contrast with only 9% of ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients being able to come off ventilators with standard of care treatment and only 12% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients at two major referral hospital networks in New York during the same time period1
column3: 2  This compassionate use treatment experience has informed the design of the clinical protocol for the randomized
column4: placebo-controlled Phase 2/3 trial of remestemcel-L in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 moderate/severe ARDS patients across North America  NEW YORK
column5: April 24
column6: 2020 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Mesoblast Limited (Nasdaq:MESO; ASX:MSB) today announced 83% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients (10/12) with moderate/severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) treated during the period March-April 2020 with two intravenous infusions of Mesoblast’s allogeneic mesenchymal stem cell product candidate remestemcel-L within the first five days.75% (9/12) have successfully come off ventilator support at a median of 10 days.At this time
column7: seven have been discharged from the hospital.Patients received a variety of experimental agents prior to remestemcel-L. All patients were treated under an emergency Investigational New Drug (IND) application or expanded access protocol at New York City’s Mt Sinai hospital.In contrast
column8: only 9% (38/445) of ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients at a major referral hospital network in New York City were able to come off ventilator support when treated with standard of care during March/April 2020.1 Moreover
column9: there was 88% mortality with only 12% survival (38/320) among ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients at a second major referral hospital network in New York City during the same period.2 These poor outcomes are consistent with earlier published data from China where mortality rates of over 80% were reported in patients with COVID-19 and moderate/severe ARDS.3  Mesoblast Chief Executive Dr Silviu Itescu stated: “The remarkable clinical outcomes in these critically ill patients continue to underscore the potential benefits of remestemcel-L as an anti-inflammatory agent in cytokine release syndromes associated with high mortality
column10: including acute graft versus host disease and COVID-19 ARDS.We intend to rapidly complete the randomized
column11: placebo-controlled Phase 2/3 trial in COVID-19 ARDS patients to rigorously confirm that remestemcel-L improves survival in these critically ill patients.”  Mesoblast Chief Medical Officer Dr Fred Grossman said: “There is a significant need to improve the dismal survival outcomes in COVID-19 patients who progress to ARDS and require ventilators."

column1: 45 fa6dba4b-1ceb-4bec-9e9d-ad374495d91d "83% Survival in COVID-19 Patients with Moderate/Severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Treated in New York with Mesoblast’s Cell Therapy Remestemcel-L Questions?+1 (202) 335-3939 Set Up FREE Account Submit Release Why Us Press Releases Services Pricing & Comparison Chart Distribution Resources Contact Contact Contact World Media Directory · RSS · Email Newsletters There were 698 press releases posted in the last 24 hours and 167
column2: 607 in the last 365 days.83% Survival in COVID-19 Patients with Moderate/Severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome Treated in New York with Mesoblast’s Cell Therapy Remestemcel-L /EIN News/ -- Key points:  83% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients (10/12) with moderate/severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) treated with two infusions of Mesoblast’s allogeneic cell therapy remestemcel-L within the first five days under emergency compassionate use at New York City’s Mt Sinai hospital during the period March-April 2020 75% (9/12) have successfully come off ventilator support within a median of 10 days  These results contrast with only 9% of ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients being able to come off ventilators with standard of care treatment and only 12% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients at two major referral hospital networks in New York during the same time period1
column3: 2 This compassionate use treatment experience has informed the design of the clinical protocol for the randomized
column4: placebo-controlled Phase 2/3 trial of remestemcel-L in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 moderate/severe ARDS patients across North America  NEW YORK
column5: April 24
column6: 2020 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Mesoblast Limited (Nasdaq:MESO; ASX:MSB) today announced 83% survival in ventilator-dependent COVID-19 patients (10/12) with moderate/severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) treated during the period March-April 2020 with two intravenous infusions of Mesoblast’s allogeneic mesenchymal stem cell product candidate remestemcel-L within the first five days.75% (9/12) have successfully come off ventilator support at a median of 10 days.At this time
column7: seven have been discharged from the hospital.Patients received a variety of experimental agents prior to remestemcel-L. All patients were treated under an emergency Investigational New Drug (IND) application or expanded access protocol at New York City’s Mt Sinai hospital."

column2: hand sanitiser and wipes.A rush on hand sanitiser to protect against the coronavirus has seen homemade versions spring up
column3: including one based on a handmade vodka.But vodka maker Tito's quickly shot down a tweet suggesting the use of its spirits is strong enough for that purpose.Some people are combining rubbing alcohol and aloe for a sanitiser.That can work as long as the version is at least 60% alcohol.But posts on social media that suggested Texas-based Tito's Handmade Vodka could be used instead saw the company cite the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to quickly refute the idea.""Per the CDC
column4: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol
column5: Tito's tweeted in reply on Thursday.""Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column6: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.""Content is not available The company did not immediately respond to a request for further comment.As the coronavirus spreads globally
column7: demand for face masks and sanitiser products has soared."

column2: LLC.All Rights Reserved.Powered by WordPress.com VIP Home Cincy Features Rickey Smiley Morning Show Entertainment Cincy Photos Music Videos Local Music Schedule Events Prizes Contest Rules Contact Us Facebook Mobile App Twitter Instagram YouTube Newsletter Mobile Text Club About EEO Advertise Playlist Facebook Twitter CLOSE NewsHome › News Tito’s Is Asking Customers To Stop Using Its Vodka For Hand Sanitizer Common sense ain't all that common Written By: rebecahjacobs Posted 3 hours ago Source: Robin Marchant / Getty The saying “common sense ain’t all that common” becomes more and more prevalent every single day.Apparently
column3: certain people out there think they found a hack by using Tito’s Vodka to make some homemade hand sanitizer and protect themselves against the coronavirus.Of course
column4: this isn’t actually gonna work
column5: so the people over at Tito’s wants you to stop.The famed alcohol brand put out a statement this week to correct anyone who may be misinformed after social media users posted about mixing the beverage with aloe vera and essential oils as a defense against the virus."

column7: Fla. — It's safe to say that misinformation about the novel coronavirus spreading the globe has gotten out of control when a vodka company has to dispel myths about its product.But more on that in a moment."

column1: 47 0f6d1071-9f93-46b4-9b85-85277714f80a "False claim: Handmade hand sanitizer will protect against coronavirus - Reuters Discover Thomson ReutersFinancialGovernment SolutionsLegalReuters News AgencyRisk Management SolutionsTax & AccountingBlog: Answers OnInnovation @ Thomson ReutersDirectory of sitesLoginContactSupportBusinessMarketsWorldPoliticsTVMoreUnited States Reuters Fact CheckMarch 10
column2: 2020 / 9:22 PM / a few seconds agoFalse claim: Handmade hand sanitizer will protect against coronavirus4 Min ReadA Facebook page has posted an image with a recipe for homemade hand sanitizer (see here ).While the post does not claim it is for the current coronavirus outbreak (COVID-19)
column3: the timing and the comments on the post suggest that it may be for this purpose due to the shortage of hand sanitizer (see more on this  here ).The recipe includes 6 tbsp vodka
column4: 4 tbsp aloe vera
column5: 10 drops lavender oil
column6: 10 drops tea tree oil.During the COVID-19 outbreak
column7: the Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommend washing hands frequently with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol (see here ) Vodka usually contains 35-46% alcohol by volume (see: here ).This would not suffice to make it effective to fight coronavirus.The CDC explains why lower alcohol concentration is less desirable generally
column8: here : “Many studies have found that sanitizers with an alcohol concentration between 60–95% are more effective at killing germs than those with a lower alcohol concentration or non-alcohol-based hand sanitizers."

column1: 47 0ff050c4-4176-4028-83ec-d3307289e1bf "Experts alarm as homemade hand sanitizer recipes proliferate online Thursday
column2: March 26
column3: 2020 Search Search Go Menu CanadaLatest HeadlinesOlympicsPoliticsEntertainmentHealthDMCAAbout UsContact UsPrivacy PolicyCategoriesCanadaLatest HeadlinesOlympicsPoliticsEntertainmentHealthPagesDMCAAbout UsContact UsPrivacy PolicyCanadaExperts alarm as homemade hand sanitizer recipes proliferate online David Smith — March 26
column4: 2020 0 comment Recipes for concoctions of homemade hand sanitizers are increasing online
column5: but experts warn that many DIY solutions are ineffective or even harmful.“You don’t want someone making their homemade hand sanitizers that might have a component that would cause some sort of toxic reaction on their hands
column6: ” said Dr. Alyson Kelvin
column7: assistant professor at Dalhousie University in Halifax and member of the Canadian Center for Vaccinology.“We don’t need people in hospitals anymore.”Shortages of hand sanitizer have prompted some Canadian distilleries to make their own.(CBC / Sophia Harris)Commercial hand sanitizer has been hard to come by in recent weeks as news of the spread of the COVID-19 virus prompted Canadians to clear store shelves.Health Canada – which considers alcohol-based hand sanitizers as natural health products – authorizes products that may be sold in Canada and assigns each an eight-digit natural product number
column8: which is displayed on the label of the product.But faced with the shortage of hand sanitizing solutions and other equipment needed to fight the COVID-19 virus
column9: such as masks
column10: gowns and tampons
column11: Health Canada decided to temporarily allow earlier this month the sale of certain products that do not meet certain requirements
column12: such as licensing and bilingual labeling.“The ministry is authorizing the sale of certain products in Canada that may not fully meet all the requirements of this interim measure
column13: ” the ministry said in a statement
column14: noting that it maintains a list of products on its website that benefit from ‘a temporary approval.Dr.Alyson Kelvin is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Microbiology and Immunology at Dalhousie University.(Craig Paisley / CBC)To date
column15: 14 hand sanitizers or disinfectant wipes have received temporary authorization.Some of them are imported.The list currently does not include the many distilleries and breweries across the country that have announced plans to transform their skills into the production of hand sanitizers.Many Canadians turn to social media for information on how to create their own – and some of this information is very misleading.WATCH: Canadians Warned About Hype About Coronavirus Prevention or CuresHealth Canada warns that it is illegal to make false claims or to sell unauthorized COVID-19 health products.2:33A YouTube video touting a concoction of witch hazel
column16: tea tree oil and aloe vera has been viewed 1.8 million times."

column2: 6 & 7 Tito’s Vodka says it doesn’t meet the CDC’s requirements for homemade hand sanitizer Coronavirus by: Nexstar Media Wire Posted: Mar 5
column3: 2020 / 04:28 PM PST / Updated: Mar 5
column4: 2020 / 04:28 PM PST AUSTIN
column5: Texas (KRON) – News of a hand sanitizer shortage nationwide amid the growing coronavirus outbreak has prompted numerous media reports on homemade sanitizer.A Google search brings up a slew of articles online touting recipes for the DIY cleanser.Some recipes include vodka and rubbing alcohol
column6: plus a few other things.But keep in mind that not all vodka is created equal.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka has apparently spent the last 24 hours informing people on social media that its spirits do not contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly ward off germs
column7: The Dallas Morning News reports.“Per the CDC
column8: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol."

column3: you can’t use Tito’s Vodka to make homemade hand sanitizerThe Texas-based vodka brand is advising fans its beverage is not suitable as a hand sanitizer replacement.Austin-based Tito's Handmade Vodka is distilled six times
column4: as the back label proudly states.But the company and the CDC do not recommend using it in homemade hand sanitizer recipes.(COURTNEY PERRY / 89962)By Dom DiFurio5:04 PM on Mar 5
column5: 2020 — Updated 8 minutes agoEmail IconVodka is a sought-after remedy for many things
column6: but the coronavirus panic-driven lack of hand sanitizer is forcing one Texas vodka brand to clarify its limitations.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka appears to have spent the last 24 hours notifying a number of fans on Twitter that its spirits don’t contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly fend off germs.“As soon as we saw the incorrect articles and social posts
column7: we wanted to set the record straight
column8: ” a spokesperson for Tito’s said in a statement provided to The Dallas Morning News.“While it would be good for business for our fans to use massive quantities of Tito’s for hand sanitizer
column9: it would be a shame to waste the good stuff
column10: especially if it doesn’t sanitize (which it doesn’t
column11: per the CDC).”The company’s social media team
column12: commendably
column13: has identified tweets suggesting the use of Tito’s in homemade hand sanitizer recipes and replied with recommendations Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.“Per the CDC
column14: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito’s Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column15: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC
column16: ” Tito’s Vodka tweeted.Per the CDC
column17: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column18: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column6: 2020 / 05:48 AM CST AUSTIN
column7: Texas (KRON) – News of a hand sanitizer shortage nationwide amid the growing coronavirus outbreak has prompted numerous media reports on homemade sanitizer.A Google search brings up a slew of articles online touting recipes for the DIY cleanser.Some recipes include vodka and rubbing alcohol
column8: plus a few other things.But keep in mind that not all vodka is created equal.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka has apparently spent the last 24 hours informing people on social media that its spirits do not contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly ward off germs
column9: The Dallas Morning News reports.“Per the CDC
column10: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol."

column1: 47 1999848d-4d5b-4019-a433-9bb1e213834a "Vodka won't protect you from coronavirus
column2: and 4 other things to know about hand sanitizerYahooSearchSearchMailNewsCoronavirusUSWorldPolitics2020 ElectionHealthScienceOriginalsContact UsVideosPodcastsVodka won't protect you from coronavirus
column3: and 4 other things to know about hand sanitizerJeffrey Gardner
column4: Associate Professor of Biological Sciences
column5: University of Maryland
column6: Baltimore CountyThe ConversationMarch 13
column7: 2020ReblogShareTweetShareSoap and hot water is the best way to clean your hands
column8: but sanitizer is a good second choice.AP Photo/Ric FeldMoreEditor’s note: As concern about coronavirus grows
column9: hand sanitizer is in high demand.Biologist Jeffrey Gardner explains why alcohol is a key ingredient in hand sanitizer
column10: and why he doesn’t recommend making your own supply at home.1.Why is alcohol the main ingredient in most hand sanitizers?Alcohol is effective at killing different types of microbes
column11: including both viruses and bacteria
column12: because it unfolds and inactivates their proteins.This process
column13: which is called denaturation
column14: will cripple and often kill the microbe because its proteins will unfold and stick together.Heat can also denature some proteins – for example
column15: when you cook an egg
column16: the solidified egg whites are denatured proteins.2."

column17: CoronavirusTito's Vodka (Tito's Vodka)SAN ANTONIO – Officials with Tito’s Handmade Vodka are responding to reports that the company’s vodka can be used in lieu of hand sanitizer.The answer is no
column18: based on the recommendation of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention which require a hand sanitizer to contain at least 60% alcohol.“Tito’s Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column19: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC
column20: ” Tito’s officials said in a Twitter post.KSAT reached out to Tito’s
column21: an Austin-based company
column22: directly and received the following statement:As soon as we saw the incorrect articles and social posts
column23: we wanted to set the record straight.While it would be good for business for our fans to use massive quantities of Tito’s for hand sanitizer
column24: it would be a shame to waste the good stuff
column25: especially if it doesn’t sanitize (which it doesn’t
column26: per the CDC).How you can responsibly prepare for an emergency (without hoarding supplies)Per the CDC
column27: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column28: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.Please see attached for more information.pic.twitter.com/3gS4Cv92Xn— TitosVodka (@TitosVodka) March 4

column11: Tito’s Vodka says it doesn’t meet the CDC’s requirements for homemade hand sanitizer News by: Alexa Mae Asperin Posted: Mar 5
column12: 2020 / 06:46 PM EST / Updated: Mar 5
column13: 2020 / 06:46 PM EST AUSTIN (KRON) – Following news of a hand sanitizer shortage nationwide amid the growing coronavirus outbreak
column14: many outlets are advising the masses to make their own hand sanitizer instead.After this recommendation of DIY hand sanitizer
column15: there’s been a surge of articles online touting how you can make your own at home.Apparently
column16: all you need is vodka and rubbing alcohol
column17: plus a few other things.But keep in mind that not all vodka is created equal.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka has apparently spent the last 24 hours informing people on social media that its spirits do not contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly ward off germs
column18: Dallas News reports.“Per the CDC
column19: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol."

column2: vodka is not one of them).By Casey Bond These days
column3: even clean freaks are getting a run for their money.In order to keep the coronavirus at bay
column4: it’s important to disinfect your kitchen
column5: bathrooms ― even the air ― sometimes multiple times per day.But with the recent panic-buying that’s wiped store shelves clean of commercial disinfectants
column6: you might not have the usual products on hand."

column8: 2020 at 5:30amPublic health experts worry that the spread of COVID-19 could be exacerbated by misinformation
column9: and some say federal agencies should do more to stamp out misconceptions.Experts worry that false or even dangerous information about what can protect individuals during the pandemic is being disseminated at an alarming rate.Last month
column10: World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned about the potential onslaught of fake information related to the new coronavirus-based illness known as COVID-19.Loading the player...“We’re not just fighting an epidemic; we’re fighting an infodemic
column11: ” he said.“We call on all governments
column12: companies and news organizations to work with us to sound the appropriate level of alarm
column13: without fanning the flames of hysteria.”Tech companies like Apple and Google have taken steps to censor COVID-19-themed apps not run by health organizations or government agencies
column14: and some state attorneys general have put out warnings about false COVID-19 claims regarding cures
column15: but experts are looking for more action to prevent individuals from being duped.“People are asking what they can do and are not getting much advice from the government
column16: ” said Durland Fish
column17: emeritus professor of epidemiology at the Yale School of Public Health
column18: who is concerned about the lack of information on what individuals can do to prevent contracting COVID-19."

column4: 2020 at 8:35 a.m. | UPDATED: April 2
column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column1: 47 281f8216-1875-46ab-b047-5f48335d1f00 "Tito's Vodka warns it can't be used in homemade hand sanitizer formulas Infosurhoy Navigate News Science Technology Health Sports News Summary Top Stories Entertainment Economy Tito’s Vodka warns it can’t be used in homemade hand sanitizer formulas 0 By Denis Bedoya on March 6
column2: 2020 Top Stories Tito’s Vodka is warning customers that it can’t be used in homemade hand sanitizer formulas because it isn’t strong enough.The US is facing a Purell hand sanitizer shortage as demand for the disinfectant soared 1
column3: 400 percent amid the coronavirus outbreak.The shortage has led people to make their own homemade versions consisting of vodka
column4: aloe gel and essential oils to keep the fast-spreading virus at bay.However
column5: Tito’s Vodka says its brand is not strong enough to be effective in killing germs.On Monday one Twitter user tweeted ‘Just made me some @TitosVodka hand sanitizer’.The Twitter account for Titos Vodka then responded: ‘Per the CDC
column6: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol."

column8: 16:52WITH health officials urging the public to wash their hands to stop coronavirus
column9: people have rushed out to buy hand sanitiser.Experts say that soap and water is effective enough to kill the virus but many have been looking for on-the-go alternatives.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news & updates 3 You should clean your hands for 20 to 30 seconds when using an alcohol-based hand gelCredit: Instagram 3 People are now making their own hand sanitiser as there is a nationwide shortageCredit: Getty Images - Getty If you need to use an alcohol-based hand gel
column10: you need to ensure you use it for 20 to 30 seconds

column5: 2020 at 8:35 a.m. | UPDATED: April 2
column6: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column7: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column8: you can bring germs into your home
column9: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column10: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column1: 47 2c8e1e9e-b22e-4a2b-b143-8f062c88565a "Tito's: Don't Use Our Vodka As Hand Sanitizer | Manufacturing Business TechnologySubscribeVideosBest PracticesBusiness IntelligenceCloud ComputingCRMERPGlobalQuality ControlSecurityTopicsBest PracticesBusiness IntelligenceCloud ComputingCRMERPGlobalQuality ControlSecurityResourcesVideosUser ToolsSubscribeAdvertiseAbout UsContact UsPrivacy PolicyTerms & ConditionsCA Consumer Privacy ActHomeTito's: Don't Use Our Vodka As Hand SanitizerWhat a waste of good vodka.Mike HockettMar 6th
column2: 2020The ongoing global coronavirus outbreak has led to a surge in demand for sanitizer products and personal protective items
column3: including many that are ineffective against preventing the person-to-person spread of the COVID 19 virus that has infected more than 100
column4: 000 people as of Friday morning and killed more than 3
column5: 300.As consumers stockpile such products
column6: others are turning to homemade remedies seen on social media or other unproven sources.One of these includes using liquors as part of a mixture to create a sanitizer
column7: stemming from the misguided belief that the alcohol content can be effective.This trend has risen to the point that Austin
column8: TX-based Titos Vodka Tweeting disclaimers in replies to other consumers saying that consumers shouldn't use their vodka to make this remedy
column9: citing that the Centers for Disease Control states that hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60 percent alcohol
column10: whereas Titos contains 40 percent and would not meet the CDC's recommendation.Per the CDC
column11: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column12: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.Please see attached for more information.pic.twitter.com/ZYDUGH44IN— TitosVodka (@TitosVodka) March 6
column13: 2020 ""As soon as we saw the incorrect articles and social posts
column14: we wanted to set the record straight
column15: ” a spokesperson for Tito’s said in a statement provided to The Dallas Morning News.“While it would be good for business for our fans to use massive quantities of Tito’s for hand sanitizer
column16: it would be a shame to waste the good stuff
column17: especially if it doesn’t sanitize (which it doesn’t
column18: per the CDC).”RelatedHomeSpreading Virus Brings Fears

column10: Mo.(WDAF) — A new poll out Thursday shows former Vice President Joe Biden leading Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders for the Democratic nomination just days before the Missouri presidential primary on March 10.According to a Nexstar/Emerson College poll
column11: a final ballot test of Missouri respondents found 48.1% of voters would choose Biden
column12: with 43.7% voting for Sanders.The margin of error is +/- 4.7% While a number of Democratic candidates will be on the ballot next Tuesday
column13: the race is effectively down to these two with Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren dropping out of the race earlier on Thursday.Among final ballot respondents who didn’t choose Biden or Sanders
column14: 6.3% said they would vote for someone else
column15: while 1.8% chose U.S. Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii.The poll exhibits enduring momentum for Biden
column16: who had a strong showing on Super Tuesday

SubscribeLifestyleFood & DrinkDrinkWhy you shouldn’t make homemade sanitizer with vodka.Picture: SuppliedCoronavirus: Why you shouldn’t make homemade sanitizer with vodkaBy Lutho Pasiya 2h agoShare this article:ShareTweetShareShareShareEmailThe  coronavirus outbreak is said to have caused a hand sanitizer shortage at stores and online retailers almost everywhere
column2: according to consumers.And if you have been on social media lately
column3: almost everyone has a recipe for how you should make your own using vodka.But experts note that it is easy to screw up a recipe for hand sanitizer and that one of the easiest failures can come in not using enough alcohol or maybe you are following a recipe that looks good online but does not result in the right concentration of alcohol.One pharmacist also noted on a thread on Twitter that this is not easy.“I'm a professional compounding pharmacist
column4: and I can make hand sanitizer gel
column5: having learned this art in the 2009 pandemic
column6: and it is VERY DIFFICULT."

column2: 2020 at 11:21 PM EST - Updated March 5 at 11:38 PM MYRTLE BEACH
column3: S.C. (WMBF) - The city of Myrtle Beach will welcome thousands of runners from around the world this weekend for the Myrtle Beach marathon amid concerns of the coronavirus.The city is taking extra health safety precautions reminding runners
column4: volunteers and race spectators to be smart by washing your hands and cutting back on handshakes and high fives during and after the race.Runner James McIlrath said numerous countries have canceled their marathons in fear of spreading the deadly illness.”We saw Tokyo get canceled and just recently Rome marathon got canceled so it’s something we think about
column5: ” McIlrath said.He will be taking part in his second Myrtle Beach Marathon and said health safety is on the mind of runners."

column17: healthFile Photo (Getty Images) (2019 Getty Images)HOUSTON – People are making some erroneous recommendations to fight the coronavirus
column18: and one company is fighting the misinformation.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka clarified on social media that their alcohol cannot be used as a replacement for hand sanitizer.One Twitter user reposted a news article that outlined a person could create their own hand sanitizer by combining vodka
column19: aloe gel and essential oils.The user suggested that he planned to use Tito’s Vodka to make the hand sanitizer.In response
column20: Tito’s Vodka tweeted: “Per the CDC
column21: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito’s Handmade Vodka is 40% of alcohol and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.”Per the CDC
column22: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column23: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.Please see attached for more information.pic.twitter.com/plYf54HPLn— TitosVodka (@TitosVodka) March 4
column24: 2020 Tito’s Vodka responded to several Twitter users that mentioned using the brand for their homemade hand sanitizers.So simply
column25: you cannot use Tito’s Vodka to make homemade hand sanitizer.Here is the full response from Tito’s Vodka: Per the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
column26: “washing hands with soap and water is the best way to get rid of germs in most situations."

column6: 2:15 PM UTCBy Herb WeisbaumThe coronavirus causing COVID-19 is a nasty bug
column7: but like other members of the coronavirus family
column8: it’s no match for good disinfecting products
column9: health experts say.“There are many bad things about the coronavirus
column10: but there is one good thing: It is not very hardy
column11: ” said Dr. John Swartzberg
column12: an expert on infectious diseases and a professor emeritus at the University of California
column13: Berkeley
column14: School of Public Health.“It is easily destroyed by most disinfectants.”Experts at Consumer Reports
column15: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other organizations have weighed in with advice on the products that can help protect us — and our homes — against the coronavirus.“Regular cleaning with normal cleaning supplies does a great job of removing all kinds of germs
column16: not just coronavirus
column17: from surfaces
column18: ” said Catherine Roberts
column19: associate health editor at Consumer Reports.“Focus on high-touch areas — that’s faucet handles
column20: doorknobs
column21: stair rails and countertops — the things that you have your hands on all the time.”Best practice is to disinfect these surfaces several times a day.Roberts suggests making a checklist of all the places you want to clean
column22: so you don’t forget any of them.But commercial disinfecting products contain “pretty serious chemicals
column23: ” she warned."

column4: 9:02 a.m. ETUntil a few months ago
column5: most of us didn’t give hand sanitizer much thought.Now it’s sold out around the world
column6: prompting a variety of do-it-yourself recipes that are designed to be mixed up in a home kitchen.But medical experts discourage D.I.Y.sanitizer for a variety of reasons.For starters
column7: it lacks quality control — a wrong measurement or ingredient and you may end up with less alcohol than needed to kill germs
column8: or a mixture that is contaminated.“We don’t have sterile production facilities in our houses
column9: ” said Dr. Ted Lain
column10: a dermatologist and chief medical officer for Sanova Dermatology
column11: a group of 15 medical practices in Texas and Louisiana."

column4: Ashley Kulp Perth Courier As people across the globe pull together to do their part amid the COVID-19 pandemic
column5: many craft distilleries are realizing they have a specific product that is extremely valuable right now: alcohol.Here in Lanark County

column8: said Stuart Thornley
column9: communications officer with Top Shelf.""Whether it's vodka or hand sanitizer
column10: the base of it (alcohol) is very linked.""When the severity of COVID-19 really started to sink in
column11: distillers worldwide decided to step up.""It's an immense global effort and a real exercise in community conscience
column12: Thornley said."

column1: 47 45aa04d8-0d28-4f81-aa19-a48b22429789 "Many common household cleaning products can kill the coronavirus if you use them properlyNewsNBC News NOWNightly NewsMeet the PressDatelineMSNBCTODAYDiet & FitnessCareersMoneyWellnessRelationshipsShare this  — A BETTER WAYCAREERSDIET + FITNESSMONEYONE SMALL THINGRELATIONSHIPSWELLNESSBETTER BUSINESSHEALTHY RECIPES30-DAY WORKOUTSCLEANING GUIDE Follow better More from NBCNewsThinkAboutContactCareersCouponsPrivacy policyDo Not Sell My Personal InformationTerms of ServiceNBCNews.COM Site MapAdvertiseAdChoices© 2020 NBCNEWS.COMSearchFacebookTwitterEmailSMSPrintWhatsappRedditPocketFlipboardPinterestLinkedinA Better WayMany common household cleaning products can kill the coronavirus if you use them properlyDisinfectant products need to be used properly to be most effective
column2: health experts say.Disinfect high-touch areas such as faucet handles
column3: doorknobs
column4: stair rails and countertops.CasarsaGuru / Getty ImagesGet the Better newsletter.SUBSCRIBEMarch 17
column6: 2:15 PM UTCBy Herb WeisbaumThe coronavirus causing COVID-19 is a nasty bug
column7: but like other members of the coronavirus family
column8: it’s no match for good disinfecting products
column9: health experts say.“There are many bad things about the coronavirus
column10: but there is one good thing: It is not very hardy
column11: ” said Dr. John Swartzberg
column12: an expert on infectious diseases and a professor emeritus at the University of California
column13: Berkeley
column14: School of Public Health.“It is easily destroyed by most disinfectants.”Experts at Consumer Reports
column15: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other organizations have weighed in with advice on the products that can help protect us — and our homes — against the coronavirus.“Regular cleaning with normal cleaning supplies does a great job of removing all kinds of germs
column16: not just coronavirus
column17: from surfaces
column18: ” said Catherine Roberts
column19: associate health editor at Consumer Reports.“Focus on high-touch areas — that’s faucet handles
column20: doorknobs
column21: stair rails and countertops — the things that you have your hands on all the time.”Best practice is to disinfect these surfaces several times a day.Roberts suggests making a checklist of all the places you want to clean
column22: so you don’t forget any of them.But commercial disinfecting products contain “pretty serious chemicals
column23: ” she warned."

column1: 47 47248799-f2ae-4345-8f39-09fcf751b2e9 "Coronavirus: Don't use vodka to sanitise hands - BBC News HomepageAccessibility linksSkip to contentAccessibility HelpBBC AccountNotificationsHomeNewsSportWeatheriPlayerSoundsCBBCCBeebiesFoodBitesizeArtsTasterLocalTVRadioThreeMenuSearchSearch the BBCSearch the BBC News BBC News Navigation Sections Home UK World Business selected Politics Tech Science Health Family & Education Entertainment & Arts Stories Video & Audio In Pictures Newsbeat Reality Check Special Reports Explainers The Reporters Have Your Say Disability Business selected Your Money Market Data Companies Economy Business Business Coronavirus: Don't use vodka to sanitise hands 6 March 2020 Share this with Facebook Share this with Messenger Share this with Twitter Share this with Email Share this with Facebook Share this with WhatsApp Share this with Messenger Share this with Twitter Share Share this with These are external links and will open in a new window Email Share this with Email Facebook Share this with Facebook Messenger Share this with Messenger Messenger Share this with Messenger Twitter Share this with Twitter Pinterest Share this with Pinterest WhatsApp Share this with WhatsApp LinkedIn Share this with LinkedIn Copy this link https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-51763775 Read more about sharing.These are external links and will open in a new window Close share panel Related TopicsCoronavirus outbreak Image copyright Getty Images Image caption A couple prepare for a flight by buying masks
column2: hand sanitiser and wipes.A rush on hand sanitiser to protect against the coronavirus has seen homemade versions spring up
column3: including one based on a handmade vodka.But vodka maker Tito's quickly shot down a tweet suggesting the use of its spirits is strong enough for that purpose.Some people are combining rubbing alcohol and aloe for a sanitiser.That can work as long as the version is at least 60% alcohol.But posts on social media that suggested Texas-based Tito's Handmade Vodka could be used instead saw the company cite the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to quickly refute the idea.""Per the CDC
column4: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol
column5: Tito's tweeted in reply on Thursday.""Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column6: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.""The company did not immediately respond to a request for further comment.As the coronavirus spreads globally
column7: demand for face masks and sanitiser products has soared."

column1: 47 480aa197-b525-471a-a45f-c301f7f14cef "Why You Shouldn't Mix Your Own Hand Sanitizer - The New York Times SectionsSEARCHSkip to contentSkip to site indexLiveLog InLog InToday’s PaperLive|Mixing Your Own Hand Sanitizer?https://nyti.ms/3aHG26e The Coronavirus Outbreak debugid:204 • Latest Updates Understand Face Masks Maps Markets What You Can Do Newsletter AdvertisementContinue reading the main storySupported byContinue reading the main storyMixing Your Own Hand Sanitizer?Recipes circulating on social media say it’s simple.But the end result is not like the real thing
column2: and it may not be effective at killing germs.Credit...Temilade Adelaja/ReutersBy Tara Parker-PopeApril 3
column4: 9:02 a.m. ETUntil a few months ago
column5: most of us didn’t give hand sanitizer much thought.Now it’s sold out around the world
column6: prompting a variety of do-it-yourself recipes that are designed to be mixed up in a home kitchen.But medical experts discourage D.I.Y.sanitizer for a variety of reasons.For starters
column7: it lacks quality control — a wrong measurement or ingredient and you may end up with less alcohol than needed to kill germs
column8: or a mixture that is contaminated.“We don’t have sterile production facilities in our houses
column9: ” said Dr. Ted Lain
column10: a dermatologist and chief medical officer for Sanova Dermatology
column11: a group of 15 medical practices in Texas and Louisiana.“I’m concerned the percentage of alcohol is going to be incorrect."

column5: Calif. (KTLA) – As shoppers stock up amid concerns of a coronavirus outbreak
column6: law enforcement responded to a Southern California Costco Thursday morning after a run on bottled water left some customers irritated
column7: authorities said.Deputies were dispatched to the Costco located at 13111 Peyton Dr. in Chino Hills
column8: according to Cindy Bachman of the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department.She said people there were upset after the store again ran out of water.“After speaking with Costco staff and checking with customers
column9: deputies determined no crime occurred
column10: ” Bachman told the Los Angeles Times.“No other issues have been reported today.” Patrol vehicles from the Sheriff's Department and Chino Hills Police Department could be seen parked outside the store just after 11 a.m.
column11: aerial video showed.Many retailers in the U.S. have been seeing larger than usual crowds recently
column12: as consumers prepare for the spread of COVID-19 throughout the U.S. by purchasing supplies."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column10: plus a few other things.But keep in mind that not all vodka is created equal.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka has apparently spent the last 24 hours informing people on social media that its spirits do not contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly ward off germs

column12: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol."

column3: 2020 Share this:Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) Hoarding and supply chain issues have caused shortages that no one could have anticipated.It’s tough right now to find things like eggs
column4: flour
column5: cleaning supplies
column6: and toilet paper — and it’s also nearly impossible to find hand sanitizer.Yep
column7: that’s right — hand sanitizer.This alcohol-based quick-fix for combatting COVID-19 is either selling at a premium by price gougers or sold out at all of the places you’d normally expect to find it.Tap or click here to find out how soap kills the coronavirus.That shortage has led to a lot of people trying to make their own hand sanitizer to try and stay safe from coronavirus
column8: with DIY recipes being posted all over the internet.Before you take this science project into your own hands
column9: you should know that it’s not a great idea to try to make your own hand sanitizer."

column4: which is produced in Austin at Texas’ oldest legal distillery
column5: is letting their customers know that they shouldn't be using their vodka for homemade hand sanitizers.Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.Fear of the novel coronavirus has led people to stock up on germ-killing gel

column4: doing its corporate due diligence

column5: 2020 / 04:36 PM CST / Updated: Mar 5
column6: 2020 / 04:36 PM CST AUSTIN
column7: Texas (KRON) – News of a hand sanitizer shortage nationwide amid the growing coronavirus outbreak has prompted numerous media reports on homemade sanitizer.A Google search brings up a slew of articles online touting recipes for the DIY cleanser.Some recipes include vodka and rubbing alcohol
column8: plus a few other things.But keep in mind that not all vodka is created equal.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka has apparently spent the last 24 hours informing people on social media that its spirits do not contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly ward off germs
column9: The Dallas Morning News reports."

column10: experts have warned against making your own DIY hand sanitisers.That's because the actual percentage of alcohol might not be enough to kill off viruses
column11: including Covid-19.It needs to be at least 60 per cent alcohol
column12: but many of the products sold in the UK contain around 40 per cent."

column24: social distancingSAN ANTONIO – No hand sanitizer?If you can round up two ingredients
column25: you can make it yourself at home (recipe below).Adeina Anderson
column26: of Creative Lifestyles with Adeina
column27: shares how to make a simple hand sanitizer recipe in the comfort and safety of your own home.Related: Will homemade hand sanitizer protect you?Anderson also shared crafts and do-it-yourself games to keep the kids busy at home.Watch the video above to learn how to make them!*According to the CDC
column28: alcohol-based hand sanitizers can quickly reduce the number of microbes on hands in some situations
column29: but sanitizers do not eliminate all types of germs.Ingredients:• Isopropyl alcohol (It is best to use a bottle of 99% isopropyl alcohol)• Aloe veraDirections:Fill up plastic container with three-quarters 99% isopropyl alcohol
column30: one-quarter aloe vera.From there you can add glitter or a few drops of essential oil for your favorite scent.WARNING: Experts note that if you don’t mix the right amounts of alcohol to aloe vera
column31: you could damage your skin.Related Stories:Coronavirus outbreak keeps local cleaning products company busyLooking for hand sanitizer?Good luck finding itTito’s says its vodka should not be used in lieu of hand sanitizerCopyright 2020 by KSAT - All rights reserved.About the Author:Diana WintersDiana Winters is the executive producer for SA Live and Texas Eats.emailGet AlertsWant the latest news and weather updates?arrownoaltfacebooktwitterinstagramyoutuberssCopyright © 2020 KSAT.com is managed by Graham Digital and pubished by Graham Media Group

column3: 2020 at 9:40 AM Corrections & Clarifications: A photo and video on an earlier version of this story used rubbing alcohol with a lower than recommended percentage of alcohol in it.The CDC advises 60% alcohol in hand sanitizer so it is recommended to use 99% isopropyl alcohol.If you're not prepared to fork over big bucks for a small bottle of hand sanitizer
column4: there's another option beyond good old-fashioned hand-washing with soap and water.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says hand-washing with soap and water is the best way to clean your hands
column5: but when that's not an option
column6: the agency recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol."

column6: you can’t use Tito’s Vodka to make homemade hand sanitizerBy Dom DiFurioThe Dallas Morning NewsFri.
column7: March 6
column8: 2020timer2 min.readDALLAS—Vodka is a sought-after remedy for many things
column9: but the coronavirus panic-driven lack of hand sanitizer is forcing one Texas vodka brand to clarify its limitations.Austin
column10: Texas-based Tito’s Vodka appears to have spent time recently notifying a number of fans on Twitter that its spirits don’t contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly fend off germs.“As soon as we saw the incorrect articles and social posts
column11: we wanted to set the record straight
column12: ” a spokesperson for Tito’s said in a statement provided to the Dallas Morning News.“While it would be good for business for our fans to use massive quantities of Tito’s for hand sanitizer
column13: it would be a shame to waste the good stuff
column14: especially if it doesn’t sanitize (which it doesn’t
column15: per the CDC).”The company’s social media team
column16: commendably
column17: has identified tweets suggesting the use of Tito’s in homemade hand sanitizer recipes and replied with recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.“Per the CDC
column18: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol.Tito’s Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol
column19: and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC
column20: ” Tito’s Vodka tweeted.The number of articles offering advice on how to make homemade hand sanitizer have spiked (naturally) in the last week as stores across the country have seen their shelves cleared of Purell and other brands.The shortage has also led to complaints about price gouging.Popular recipes for homemade hand sanitizer recommend combing either isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or spirits that are at least 180 proof with aloe vera.And while the CDC does acknowledge you can use alcohol-based sanitizers with at least 60% alcohol
column21: health experts say washing your hands with soap and water is a more effective way to prevent the spread of germs.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN...In 2019
column22: Tito’s Vodka unseated Smirnoff for the first time in more than a decade as the best selling vodka in the U.S.
column23: according to beverage market analysis firm IWSR."

column1: 47 752dfdcf-8d5d-420a-b03f-0df825c9d182 "'Don't Waste Your Vodka': Hand Sanitizing In The Age Of COVID-19 | Crooks and Liars Home Politics CLTV MediaBites Search this site: Search Login | Register Username: * Password: * Forgot password?Remember my login on this computer Activism 3/10/20 5:00am Read time: 4 minutes Comments 'Don't Waste Your Vodka': Hand Sanitizing In The Age Of COVID-19 MOST hand sanitizers don't kill viruses as well as a good hand washing.And there's more... By ProPublica ProPublica is a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative newsroom.Sign up for The Big Story newsletter to receive stories like this one in your inbox.It’s tempting
column2: especially now
column3: to buy one of the many hand sanitizers whose label says it “kills 99.99% of illness causing germs.” But that does not mean the product will protect you against the novel coronavirus.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends rubbing on hand sanitizers with at least 60% alcohol when you aren’t able to wash your hands."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column10: 12:00 PM CDT There was perhaps a bit of already self-fulfilling prophecy in a statement last week from Belarus’  president
column11: Alexander Lukashenko
column12: when he said no one in ‘his’ country would die from coronavirus
column13: which could be rendered innocuous by drowning in vodka.Yet
column14: across the Atlantic
column15: it would seem that there are many true believers
column16: even if Texas-based Tito’s Handmade Vodka released a statement last month stating that its vodka would not be effective at all against COVID-19.“While it would be good for business for our fans to use massive quantities of Tito’s for hand sanitizer
column17: it would be a shame to waste the good stuff
column18: especially if it doesn’t sanitize (which it doesn’t
column19: per the CDC)
column20: ” the statement read.Since the outbreak of the coronavirus
column21: various recipes for homemade hand sanitizers using Tito’s Vodka
column22: aloe vera and aromatic oils were circulating online
column23: but the company said that their product did not contain the required percentage of alcohol.However
column24: according to  new market data
column25: many seem to be skipping the other ingredients and going straight to the source.Alcohol sales have skyrocketed as more people stay home and bars remain closed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Nielson research shows alcoholic beverage sales increased in March
column26: with sales up by 55% in the third week of the month compared to the same week last year."

column7: Tito’s Vodka says it doesn’t meet the CDC’s requirements for homemade hand sanitizer Coronavirus by: Alexa Mae Asperin Posted: Mar 5
column8: 2020 / 10:38 AM PST / Updated: Mar 5
column9: 2020 / 10:38 AM PST AUSTIN (KRON) – Following news of a hand sanitizer shortage nationwide amid the growing coronavirus outbreak
column10: many outlets are advising the masses to make their own hand sanitizer instead.After this recommendation of DIY hand sanitizer
column11: there’s been a surge of articles online touting how you can make your own at home.Apparently
column12: all you need is vodka and rubbing alcohol
column13: plus a few other things.But keep in mind that not all vodka is created equal.Austin-based Tito’s Vodka has apparently spent the last 24 hours informing people on social media that its spirits do not contain high enough concentrations of alcohol to properly ward off germs
column14: Dallas News reports."

column1: 47 860805b4-4a65-469f-9c75-9f33f8ec5dd9 "Tito's Handmade Vodka won't protect against coronavirusBeware of scammers Meet car sounds guru How big is my refund?Defining 'what is poor'SUBSCRIBE NOWAs low as $4.99 per monthNews Sports Entertainment Life Money Tech Travel OpinionSubscribeMONEYTito's Vodka warns not to use its spirits in homemade hand sanitizer to protect from coronavirusKelly TykoUSA TODAYTito's Handmade Vodka is warning consumers to not use its spirits in do-it-yourself hand sanitizer recipes to protect against the coronavirus.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says hand-washing with soap and water is the best way to clean your hands
column2: but when that's not an option
column3: the agency recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.The Texas-based vodka brand said Thursday in a statement on Twitter that its vodka is 40% alcohol
column4: which is below the CDC's recommendation.Several brands of vodka are 80 proof as well.With stores across the nation sold out of hand sanitizer or with limited supplies
column5: many are making batches with recipes circulating online versus paying marked-up prices from online sellers.Experts say it's important to pay attention to the percentage of alcohol in the vodka or isopropyl alcohol or ethanol alcohol being used in the homemade recipes.Can't find Purell or hand sanitizers?Here's how to make it at home with vodka or rubbing alcoholGouge much?Purell for $149
column6: face masks for $20: Coronavirus price hikes are making everyone madDr.David Agus
column7: a professor of medicine and engineering at University of Southern California's Keck School of Medicine
column8: suggests using a 180 proof or vodka with a higher percentage of alcohol to “have some benefit.”Two biology professors from Benedictine University in Lisle
column9: Illinois – Tanya Crum
column10: an assistant professor
column11: and Jayashree Sarathy
column12: an associate professor – told USA TODAY that the concentration of ethanol in 80 proof vodka like Tito's is ""not concentrated enough to kill viruses."

column3: which is produced in Austin at Texas’ oldest legal distillery
column4: is letting their customers know that they shouldn't be using their vodka for homemade hand sanitizers.Tito's Handmade Vodka is 40% alcohol and therefore does not meet the current recommendation of the CDC.Fear of the novel coronavirus has led people to stock up on germ-killing gel

column2: 2020 / 9:22 PM / Updated an hour agoFalse claim: Homemade hand sanitizer will protect against coronavirus4 Min ReadA Facebook page has posted an image with a recipe for homemade hand sanitizer (see here ).While the post does not claim it is for the current coronavirus outbreak (COVID-19)
column3: the timing and the comments on the post suggest that it may be for this purpose due to the shortage of hand sanitizer (see more on this  here ).The recipe includes 6 tbsp vodka
column4: 4 tbsp aloe vera
column5: 10 drops lavender oil
column6: 10 drops tea tree oil.During the COVID-19 outbreak
column7: the Center for Disease Control (CDC) recommend washing hands frequently with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol (see here ) Vodka usually contains 35-46% alcohol by volume (see: here ).This would not suffice to make it effective to fight coronavirus.The CDC explains why lower alcohol concentration is less desirable generally
column8: here : “Many studies have found that sanitizers with an alcohol concentration between 60–95% are more effective at killing germs than those with a lower alcohol concentration or non-alcohol-based hand sanitizers."

column12: I decided my contribution to the cause was going to be making a shit ton of hand sanitizer for my family and friends.So
column13: I did some research and found what we computer science nerds would call the canonical reference: “Guide to Local Production WHO-recommended Handrub Formulations.” This document describes two formulations for 75-80% alcohol hand sanitizer
column14: which is in excess of the CDC’s recommendation of 60%.(Note
column15: too
column16: that the CDC recommends good handwashing as the best way to prevent disease
column17: but there are plenty of situations where you want to sanitize your hands but you’re away from a wash basin.)One is made with 99.8% isopropyl alcohol
column18: the other is made with 96% Ethanol
column19: which is Everclear (97% ethanol)."

column1: 47 992d6ecc-b30a-4f98-b2bb-5b4b5e430574 "How to: The science of making your own hand sanitizerSofia Quaglia1 hour agoPandemic proofHow to: The science of making your own hand sanitizerFour scientists explain what you need to do to make your own hand sanitizer.Amidst the coronavirus breakout
column2: everyone is getting in on the hand sanitizer craze.But if your local pharmacy has run out of pre-made hand gel
column3: do not despair — you can make your own.And it is easy.With the guidance and four scientists
column4: here’s how Inverse made our own sanitizer
column5: and how you can too.What is in hand sanitizer?Hand sanitizer is made from three essential ingredients:WaterAlcohol above 60 percentGlycerin (or another gel)“Products like “Purell” are essentially 62 percent ethanol (regular alcohol) mixed in a gel
column6: ” Stephen Morse
column7: professor at Columbia University
column8: tells Inverse.“The purpose of the gel is to make the product easier to carry around
column9: so people have it when they need it
column10: slow the evaporation of the alcohol so it stays on the skin long enough to work well
column11: and to make it gentler on the hands
column12: Morse says.""Vitamin E is often included in the commercial products
column13: ” he adds."
