column3: Mar 28 20209:31 AM EDTTom Huddleston Jr.VIDEO5:4905:49How hand sanitizer sales spike during pandemicsMake ItPanic buying over the coronavirus pandemic has led to a variety of household products flying off the shelves at your local grocery store.That includes staples
column4: like bread and toilet paper
column5: as well as one product that's only been commercially available for a few decades
column6: but which many people clearly now view as a necessity: hand sanitizer.Purchases of the disinfecting gel have skyrocketed in the U.S. ever since the first case of COVID-19 hit the country.During the last week of February
column7: a period that saw the first American death from COVID-19
column8: hand sanitizer sales in the U.S. were up by 300% compared to the same week a year earlier
column9: according to market research from Nielsen.The following week
column10: the first week of March
column11: hand sanitizer sales shot up by 470% compared to the same week a year earlier
column12: Nielsen tells CNBC Make It.That's in an industry that already sees more than $200 million in annual sales of hand sanitizer products in the U.S.
column13: according to Nielsen.Supermarkets and pharmacies across the country have sold out of hand sanitizer
column14: leaving only empty shelves where disinfectant products would normally be found.With some consumers even hoarding hand sanitizer amid the shortage
column15: online prices for the products soared
column16: leading law enforcement officials in many states to threaten prosecution for price-gouging against third-party sellers on sites like Walmart and Amazon (where an 8-ounce bottle of Purell that would normally cost $2.50 was briefly on sale for $90 before being removed by Amazon in early March).What's more
column17: the run on hand sanitizer also came as health officials across the country have remained adamant that the best way for people to combat the spread of potentially dangerous germs is simply through diligent hand-washing with soap and water.(For what it's worth
column18: the U.S. soap industry is worth more than $2 billion per year."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column9: Associate Professor of Biological Sciences
column10: University of Maryland
column11: Baltimore County |  The Conversation 1.Why is alcohol the main ingredient in most hand sanitizers?Alcohol is effective at killing different types of microbes
column12: including both viruses and bacteria
column13: because it unfolds and inactivates their proteins.This process
column14: which is called denaturation
column15: will cripple and often kill the microbe because its proteins will unfold and stick together.Heat can also denature some proteins – for example
column16: when you cook an egg
column17: the solidified egg whites are denatured proteins."

column15: healthWill homemade hand sanitizer protect you?Recipes for homemade hand-sanitizers have been circulating on social media amid a shortage due to coronavirus fears.The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency says it’s time to put down the Tito’s vodka and aloe
column16: because the DIY remedies won’t kill the virus.The EPA released a guide of products qualified for use against the COVID-19 virus Thursday in hopes of discouraging the use of ineffective homemade sanitizers.""Using the correct disinfectant is an important part of preventing and reducing the spread of illnesses along with other critical aspects such as hand washing
column17: ” EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler said.The EPA-approved products include many disinfectants from Clorox to Lysol and include sprays
column18: aerosols and wipes.The full list of approved products can be found here.The agency strongly recommends following the product label use directions for enveloped viruses
column19: as improper use could lead to lingering pathogens.Homemade sanitizers are not formulated specifically to be anti-viral
column20: and improper mixing of solutions could lead to spreading sickness
column21: health officials said.The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention maintain proper hand washing is still the best way to keep from getting sick.Copyright 2020 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.About the Author:Erin DobrzynErin Dobrzyn is working on her line producing skills after coming to News 6 as an assignment editor.She has been with the station since 2018. emailGet AlertsWant the latest news and weather updates?arrownoaltfacebooktwitterinstagramrssCopyright © 2020 ClickOrlando.com is managed by Graham Digital and pubished by Graham Media Group

column6: 2:15 PM UTCBy Herb WeisbaumThe coronavirus causing COVID-19 is a nasty bug
column7: but like other members of the coronavirus family
column8: it’s no match for good disinfecting products
column9: health experts say.“There are many bad things about the coronavirus
column10: but there is one good thing: It is not very hardy
column11: ” said Dr. John Swartzberg
column12: an expert on infectious diseases and a professor emeritus at the University of California
column13: Berkeley
column14: School of Public Health.“It is easily destroyed by most disinfectants.”Experts at Consumer Reports
column15: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other organizations have weighed in with advice on the products that can help protect us — and our homes — against the coronavirus.“Regular cleaning with normal cleaning supplies does a great job of removing all kinds of germs
column16: not just coronavirus
column17: from surfaces
column18: ” said Catherine Roberts
column19: associate health editor at Consumer Reports.“Focus on high-touch areas — that’s faucet handles
column20: doorknobs
column21: stair rails and countertops — the things that you have your hands on all the time.”Best practice is to disinfect these surfaces several times a day.Roberts suggests making a checklist of all the places you want to clean
column22: so you don’t forget any of them.But commercial disinfecting products contain “pretty serious chemicals
column23: ” she warned."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column11: 2020 by wsw staff |ProPublica is a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative newsroom.Sign up for The Big Story newsletter to receive stories like this one in your inbox.It’s tempting
column12: especially now
column13: to buy one of the many hand sanitizers whose label says it “kills 99.99% of illness causing germs.” But that does not mean the product will protect you against the novel coronavirus.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends rubbing on hand sanitizers with at least 60% alcohol when you aren’t able to wash your hands."

column9: Do Not Use Titos Vodka To Make DIY Hand SanitizerBritni de la CretazAmid the coronavirus outbreak ensuing widespread panic across the United States
column10: many big (and small) city residents are stocking up on supplies like food
column11: alcohol wipes
column12: and hand sanitizer.The reaction and prep tactics are already causing shortages in major cities
column13: with even Amazon raising the price of Purell packs to as much as $350.As a result
column14: people are looking to DIY solutions for getting what they need to protect themselves.But MacGyvering healthcare is not always the best idea
column15: and it’s led to a vodka company having to put out warnings to the public over trying to create sanitizing supplies at home.AdvertisementAfter a number of viral blogs and tutorials found people sharing recipes to create hand sanitizer out of alcohol
column16: Tito’s Vodka suddenly became a sought-after ingredient.There’s just one problem: Tito’s isn’t actually potent enough to use to sanitize your hands.As a result
column17: the company has had to put out a statement on social media and whoever runs their Twitter account is doing something they probably never thought would be part of their job description — telling Twitter users not to use Tito’s to stop the spread of coronavirus.“Per the CDC
column18: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol
column19: ” Tito’s statement reads."

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column2: 2020 KID News National News How to make your own hand sanitizer With hand sanitizer sold out at stores across the nation
column3: shoppers are not waiting for shelves to be restocked and are turning to the web to learn how to make homemade versions.Kroger
column4: one of America’s largest supermarket chains
column5: has capped the amount of sanitizating and cold and flu products customers can order on its website
column6: due to the high volume of demand amid the coronavirus outbreak.The company’s website pinned a message to the top of its main webpage
column7: directly underneath the Internet address bar.“Due to high demand and to support all customers
column8: we will be limiting the number of Sanitization
column9: Cold and Flu-related products to 5 each per order
column10: ” the message read.“Your order may be modified at time of pickup or delivery.” SENATE APPROVES $8.3B CORONAVIRUS SPENDING BILL Gary Millerchip
column11: Kroger’s senior vice president and chief financial officer
column12: said the media’s coverage of the virus has made customers hypervigilant and driven up the demand for such items.“I think you’ve seen more in response to the media activity and some of the advice out there in the market of customers starting to spend more on things like water and hand sanitizer and soap
column13: ”  he said Thursday on a conference call with analysts
column14: according to the New York Post."

column1: 47 d1c2e7ef-80f6-4817-8ba9-2a5433c40c53 "Experts alarmed as recipes for homemade hand sanitizer proliferate online | CBC News – Jimmys Post Skip to content Jimmys Post Politics Technology Entertainment Lifestyle Sports Google News Experts alarmed as recipes for homemade hand sanitizer proliferate online | CBC News Posted on March 26
column2: 2020 by admin Recipes for homemade hand sanitizer concoctions have been multiplying online but experts are warning that many of the DIY solutions are ineffective — even harmful.“You don’t want anyone making up their homemade hand sanitizers that might have a component that’s going to lead to some kind of toxic reaction on their hands
column3: ” said Dr. Alyson Kelvin
column4: an assistant professor at Dalhousie University in Halifax and a member of the Canadian Centre for Vaccinology.“We don’t need any more people in the hospitals right now.” Shortages of hand sanitizer have prompted some Canadian distilleries to make their own.(CBC/Sophia Harris) Commercial hand sanitizing liquid has been hard to find in recent weeks as news of the spread of the COVID-19 virus has prompted Canadians to empty store shelves.Health Canada — which considers alcohol-based hand sanitizers to be natural health products — authorizes the products that can be sold in Canada and assigns each one an eight-digit Natural Product Number
column5: displayed on the product’s label.But faced with the shortage of hand sanitizing solutions and other equipment needed to fight the COVID-19 virus
column6: such as masks
column7: gowns and swabs
column8: Health Canada decided earlier this month to temporarily allow for sale some products that don’t meet some requirements
column9: such as licensing and bilingual labelling."

column8: 2020 / 03:41 PM MST / Updated: Mar 5
column9: 2020 / 03:41 PM MST (CNN) — The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is arming consumers with a list of disinfectants that people can use to protect themselves from the novel coronavirus.The federal agency released a five-page list of chemicals and products Thursday that it says are strong enough to ward off “harder-to-kill” viruses than SARS-CoV-2
column10: the virus that’s responsible for the disease.You can read the full list of disinfectants here.“Using the correct disinfectant is an important part of preventing and reducing the spread of illnesses along with other critical aspects such as hand washing
column11: ” EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler said in a statement.“There is no higher priority for the Trump Administration than protecting the health and safety of Americans.EPA is providing this important information in a public and transparent manner on disinfectant products to help reduce the spread of COVID-19
column12: ” he said."

column8: Titos DIY Hand Sanitizer Does Not Kill Coronavirus Skip navigation!DISCOVERWATCHSHOPMORESwitch ToukdefrcaNow ReadingTitos DIY Hand Sanitizer Does Not Kill CoronavirusStory from Health NewsPlease
column9: Do Not Use Titos Vodka To Make DIY Hand SanitizerBritni de la CretazAmid the coronavirus outbreak ensuing widespread panic across the United States
column10: many big (and small) city residents are stocking up on supplies like food
column11: alcohol wipes
column12: and hand sanitizer.The reaction and prep tactics are already causing shortages in major cities
column13: with even Amazon raising the price of Purell packs to as much as $350.As a result
column14: people are looking to DIY solutions for getting what they need to protect themselves.But MacGyvering healthcare is not always the best idea
column15: and it’s led to a vodka company having to put out warnings to the public over trying to create sanitizing supplies at home.AdvertisementAfter a number of viral blogs and tutorials found people sharing recipes to create hand sanitizer out of alcohol
column16: Tito’s Vodka suddenly became a sought-after ingredient.There’s just one problem: Tito’s isn’t actually potent enough to use to sanitize your hands.As a result
column17: the company has had to put out a statement on social media and whoever runs their Twitter account is doing something they probably never thought would be part of their job description — telling Twitter users not to use Tito’s to stop the spread of coronavirus.“Per the CDC
column18: hand sanitizer needs to contain at least 60% alcohol
column19: ” Tito’s statement reads."

column1: 47 ddb759cc-3e91-4d37-a112-66685d060875 "Coronavirus hand sanitizer shortages: Bath & Body Works has some leftHow to get 🎫 refunds Health or paycheck?Cities seeing less 🚗 Why it's not like 2008SUBSCRIBE NOWAs low as $4.99 per monthNews Sports Entertainment Life Money Tech Travel OpinionSubscribeMONEYNeed hand sanitizer?Here's how to find out if your local Bath & Body Works has any leftKelly TykoUSA TODAYWhile hand sanitizer is currently sold out on the Bath & Body Works website
column2: some physical stores still have limited supplies left.The easy way to find out if your local store has any left before leaving the house?Call stores and check.Bath & Body Works stores have set up automated messages that say if there are any available with some stores' messages stating any limits and if there is hand soap in stock.The items cannot be held for a customer so keep in mind that the store may run out quickly.Along with face masks and sanitizing wipes
column3: hand sanitizer has been one of the most in-demand items as coronavirus fears have sparked panic buying that has left store shelves bare.Preparing for the coronavirus:Shoppers are finding empty shelves
column4: long lines at stores nationwideCan't find hand sanitizer?"

column5: 2020 at 8:36 a.m.It’s easy to forget about the new normal for a moment as you go about your day: You return from a quick trip to the grocery store and drop your reusable bags on the kitchen countertop
column6: or your dog’s leash goes from resting on a bench at the park to resting on your dining table or the back of a chair.Yep
column7: you can bring germs into your home
column8: no matter how much social distance you are maintaining during the novel coronavirus outbreak.And while you are hyper-aware that you need to wash your hands often
column9: you also need to kick up your overall germ-killing game."

column4: Tito’s Vodka is taking to the corporate Twitter web page to strongly urge American prospects in opposition to utilizing its product in handmade sanitizers
column5: as it’s not thought of an efficient alternative for Purell
column6: in accordance with the Facilities For Illness Management.Over the previous 24 hours
column7: Tito’s Vodka has been steady placing an finish to the widespread rumors on social media that its vodka can be utilized as a disinfectant rather than precise hand sanitizer

column1: 47 e95e519f-152c-4c08-a56e-2bf1a24ec977 "Experts alarm as homemade hand sanitizer recipes proliferate online Thursday
column2: March 26
column3: 2020 Search Search Go Menu CanadaLatest HeadlinesOlympicsPoliticsEntertainmentHealthDMCAAbout UsContact UsPrivacy PolicyCategoriesCanadaLatest HeadlinesOlympicsPoliticsEntertainmentHealthPagesDMCAAbout UsContact UsPrivacy PolicyCanadaExperts alarm as homemade hand sanitizer recipes proliferate online David Smith — March 26
column4: 2020 0 comment Recipes for concoctions of homemade hand sanitizers are increasing online
column5: but experts warn that many DIY solutions are ineffective or even harmful.“You don’t want someone making their homemade hand sanitizers that might have a component that would cause some sort of toxic reaction on their hands
column6: ” said Dr. Alyson Kelvin
column7: assistant professor at Dalhousie University in Halifax and member of the Canadian Center for Vaccinology.“We don’t need people in hospitals anymore.”Shortages of hand sanitizer have prompted some Canadian distilleries to make their own.(CBC / Sophia Harris)Commercial hand sanitizer has been hard to come by in recent weeks as news of the spread of the COVID-19 virus prompted Canadians to clear store shelves.Health Canada – which considers alcohol-based hand sanitizers as natural health products – authorizes products that may be sold in Canada and assigns each an eight-digit natural product number
column8: which is displayed on the label of the product.But faced with the shortage of hand sanitizing solutions and other equipment needed to fight the COVID-19 virus
column9: such as masks
column10: gowns and tampons
column11: Health Canada decided to temporarily allow earlier this month the sale of certain products that do not meet certain requirements
column12: such as licensing and bilingual labeling.“The ministry is authorizing the sale of certain products in Canada that may not fully meet all the requirements of this interim measure
column13: ” the ministry said in a statement
column14: noting that it maintains a list of products on its website that benefit from ‘a temporary approval.Dr.Alyson Kelvin is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Microbiology and Immunology at Dalhousie University.(Craig Paisley / CBC)To date
column15: 14 hand sanitizers or disinfectant wipes have received temporary authorization.Some of them are imported.The list currently does not include the many distilleries and breweries across the country that have announced plans to transform their skills into the production of hand sanitizers.Many Canadians turn to social media for information on how to create their own – and some of this information is very misleading.A YouTube video touting a concoction of witch hazel
column16: tea tree oil and aloe vera has been viewed 1.8 million times.Another YouTube video
column17: viewed 747
column18: 000 times in the past two weeks
column19: recommends isopropyl rubbing alcohol at concentrations as low as 70% – a level that when mixed with other ingredients would not be enough to kill the virus.Posts on sites like Facebook and Reddit have advised using things like vodka and tea tree oil to make your own hand sanitizer.Many home remedies don’t workThe World Health Organization website has legitimate instructions to make a hand sanitizer that recommends using 96% ethanol or 99.8% isopropyl alcohol.Experts say the best way to kill COVID 19 virus on your hands is to wash them properly with soap and water."

column1: 47 f9e73183-09db-48af-b815-b1c5d598f934 "Hand sanitizer shortage: Coronavirus leads some to make own sanitizerBeware of scammers Meet car sounds guru How big is my refund?Defining 'what is poor'SUBSCRIBE NOWAs low as $4.99 per monthNews Sports Entertainment Life Money Tech Travel OpinionSubscribeCan't find Purell or other hand sanitizers?Here's how to make it at home with vodka or rubbing alcoholKelly TykoUSA TODAYIf you're not prepared to fork over big bucks for a small bottle of hand sanitizer
column2: there's an alternative option beyond good old-fashioned hand washing with soap and water.Along with face masks and Clorox wipes
column3: the alcohol-based gel has been one of the most in-demand items as coronavirus fears have sparked panic buying that has left store shelves bare.This had brought complaints of price gouging with a two-pack of Purell 12-ounce bottles selling for a marked-up $149.For a price comparison
column4: during back-to-school shopping this summer
column5: eight-ounce bottles of Purell
column6: a popular item on teachers' wish lists
column7: cost less than $2 between sales and coupons.Now
column8: shoppers are going the Do-It-Yourself route and making batches of homemade hand sanitizer with items widely available in most households.How to prepare for coronavirus:The shopping list for your own home quarantine kitThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says hand washing with soap and water is the best ways to clean your hands
column9: but when that's not an option recommends using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.The CDC says hand sanitizers may not be as effective when hands are visibly dirty or greasy.Do-It-Yourself hand sanitizer recipes: Vodka or rubbing alcoholThere are multiple ways to make your own sanitizer and one recipe posted on ThoughtCo.com by chemistry expert Anne Marie Helmenstine
column10: requires two ingredients: isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) and aloe vera gel.The ThoughtCo recipe calls for two-thirds of a cup of the rubbing alcohol or ethanol and a third-cup of aloe vera gel."

column5: there are only two ways to ­protect ­ourselves – slowing the spread of the virus with regular hand-washing and social distancing
column6: and strengthening our immune systems to minimise symptoms and complications if it does hit.Myths and misinformation about the new virus are spreading rapidly
column7: but there are some simple evidence-based steps we can take to protect ourselves.Our immune system works on two levels – innate immunity
column8: which is like the walls of a fortress and the troops which defend against all threats; and ­adaptive immunity
column9: which consists of the commandos and special forces we deploy to counter a specific attack.Professor Adrian Martineau
column10: an expert in respiratory medicine and immunology at Queen Mary University of London
column11: explains: “Innate immunity is basically a package of measures we are born with
column12: that work against all bacteria and viruses in a generic way.At its most basic
column13: our skin is part of this innate immune system because it stops bugs getting inside us.” Coronavirus (Image: Getty Images/Image Source) Read More Related Articles Coronavirus: Madrid ice skating rink to be turned into temporary morgue Read More Related Articles Coronavirus: Distraught paramedic unable to buy food for family because of huge queues This in-born immunity also works at a cellular level
column14: triggering the release of infection-fighting chemicals and other responses to counter the threat."

column4: COVID-19

column9: told UPI.""That means taking your medications as directed
column10: exercising and eating well.If you have high blood pressure
column11: for example

column15: diabetes and heart disease were more likely to have severe disease

column4: how our world has changed Annette Jordan Saturday Apr 4
column5: 2020 at 12:01 AM I have never sung “Happy birthday” so many times in my life.Per CDC instructions
column6: humming that song twice from beginning to end while washing your hands should be enough to remove coronavirus pathogens
column7: a happy ditty now inextricably linked to disease and death — oh
column8: how our world has changed!But that is our reality now.When Darrell returns from a weekly jaunt to the grocery store
column9: I spray his shoes with Lysol and leave them outside in the sun to kill any stray germs.When we go walking
column10: most often at Oaklawn Cemetery
column11: we give a wide berth to other walkers.We wave.We smile.We joke about staying 6 feet apart.But we keep even more than the required social distance away — and take note which direction the wind is blowing.If you wonder why
column12: think of the theater scene in “Outbreak” and how far a single droplet can travel.I feel both strangely disconnected from the world
column13: and strangely connected
column14: all at the same time.Disconnected because I’m working from home.Connected because I find myself reaching out to others more than ever before.Now that I can’t visit in person
column15: I call more."

column4: clematic or star of Bethlehem extracts help cure or stem coronavirus we’re in luck
column5: as “health” chain Holland & Barrett is refusing to close amid the high street lockdown
column6: because it believes some people are reliant upon the niche foods and homeopathic placebo potions distilled out of weeds it sells.Staff are not happy about the decision
column7: mind
column8: and have set up a well-trafficked petition to ask managers to close the chain and free them from facing shoppers so desperate for bread flour they’re even considering the 250g bags of the gluten free ranges.Holland & Barrett’s bosses make the valid case that some of its customers have legitimate dietary needs and aren’t only going in there for a cheeky flapjack and an apple juice
column9: although the workers themselves say the shop’s range is not what they’d describe as essential – not unless H&B’s £25 bundle of garlic powder and echinacea can genuinely step up and assist the immune system as it claims.Holland & Barrett says the government is behind the decision for it to remain open
column10: as it does indeed stock some supplements that aren’t entirely pretend or promising ancient magic; although staff counter this by saying they actually see customers coming in for “flapjacks and sticks of liquorice” alone.The case continues.[BBC] Related Posts Starwatch: the moon at its closest and brightest Global coronavirus infections top 1.3M Wales is Banning Single Use Plastics Starting Next Year Post navigation Forest fire in China’s Sichuan put outGermany’s short-time work fix offers Europe a crisis model Leave a Reply Cancel replyYour email address will not be published."

column5: there are evidence-based things you can do to help yourself Contact author @gidmk Tue 3 Mar 2020 11.30 EST Last modified on Tue 3 Mar 2020 11.46 EST Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email ‘Wash your hands more often
column6: and practice not touching your face.Yes
column7: it seems boring
column8: but often the best advice is precisely that.’ Photograph: Tetra Images/Alamy Stock Photo The novel coronavirus
column9: called Sars-CoV-2
column10: and the disease it causes
column11: Covid-19
column12: are sweeping the globe.With thousands of deaths already
column13: and many tens of thousands of people infected across the world
column14: it’s safe to say that the coronavirus has become one of the biggest events of the 21st century.It may only be a matter of time until we see outbreaks everywhere
column15: with public health authorities warning that the disease will probably soon start spreading locally regardless of where you are on the planet.If nothing else
column16: the coronavirus is scary."

column7: April 27
column8: 2020timer2 min.readOTTAWA—The dicey claims are not just from a U.S. president musing about bleach injections as a possible cure for the coronavirus.There are dozens and dozens of peddlers of all kinds of snake oil in our midst.Health Canada has published a list of 101 products for which dubious or possibly dangerous claims have been made.Everything from echinacea and oregano oil
column9: vitamins and other so-called natural remedies to “boost the immune system “during the threat of COVID-19
column10: ” to “ozone lamp bulbs” to ultraviolet disinfecting lamps
column11: washable reusable dust masks
column12: bottle sprayers and power washers billed as “COVID-19 virus prevention” able to “dispense alcohol for disinfection COVID-19 Virus Prevention.”There were residential air purifiers listed on Kijiji with the claim “Save yourself and family from coronavirus!”Face shields.Laboratory safety glasses sold as “adjustable for home office COVID-19 virus protection.”Carbon water filter systems: “Since the coronavirus
column13: we have to protect ourselves from drinking water and air we breathe and drink.”Sometimes the fraudulent claims are not made by the actual product manufacturers or distributors
column14: but by second-hand vendors or resellers pitching them on Amazon
column15: Facebook or Kijiji.Selling or advertising health products that make false or misleading claims is illegal
column16: and Health Canada makes clear: there is no cure
column17: or treatment
column18: for COVID-19.Tim Caulfield
column19: who holds the Canada Research Chair in health law and policy and teaches at the University of Alberta’s law faculty and school of public health
column20: said he is encouraged by the pushback now against “COVID-19 claptrap.” But he says regulators won’t be able to catch all the bad actors
column21: especially those which use “wiggly phrases” in their marketing.In an article on the scourge of fakes and pseudo-science in Nature magazine published Monday
column22: Caulfield said he hopes “one of the legacies of this crisis will be the recognition that tolerating pseudo-science can cause real harm.” Caulfield said in an interview with the Star that scientists
column23: universities and health-care institutions have to speak out
column24: and “stop tolerating and legitimizing health pseudo-science” not just by their silence but by allowing unproven therapies within their own settings.Caulfield
column25: who wrote the book “Is Gwyneth Paltrow Wrong About Everything
column26: ” said if respected institutions
column27: such as the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio
column28: offer “a science-free practice” like reiki treatments
column29: it’s no wonder people are fooled."

column2: 2020 Categories: News A Scientific Look at Botanical Plants and Supplements Against Coronavirus Health Impact News – by Richard Gale and Gary Null PhD In recent weeks
column3: the coronavirus pandemic has dominated the news at the expense of everything else that is critical and urgent in our lives.As panic increases and more cases are reported daily
column4: health-minded people are eager or even desperate to know whether there are ways to strengthen the body’s immune system to offer some protection from this specific upper respiratory infection.There are six known strains of coronavirus
column5: four which are associated with the common cold or moderate respiratory infections.Everyone has likely had a coronavirus infection at some time in their lives.However
column6: two strains — Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome or SARS and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) — are more severe."

column2: how our world has changed - Opinion - The Dispatch - Lexington
column3: NC Sections NewsSportsEntertainmentLifeObituariesCarsJobsHomes Subscribe Log in Subscribe Now Oh
column4: how our world has changed Annette Jordan Saturday Apr 4
column5: 2020 at 12:01 AM I have never sung “Happy birthday” so many times in my life.Per CDC instructions
column6: humming that song twice from beginning to end while washing your hands should be enough to remove coronavirus pathogens
column7: a happy ditty now inextricably linked to disease and death — oh
column8: how our world has changed!But that is our reality now.When Darrell returns from a weekly jaunt to the grocery store
column9: I spray his shoes with Lysol and leave them outside in the sun to kill any stray germs.When we go walking
column10: most often at Oaklawn Cemetery
column11: we give a wide berth to other walkers.We wave.We smile.We joke about staying 6 feet apart.But we keep even more than the required social distance away — and take note which direction the wind is blowing.If you wonder why
column12: think of the theater scene in “Outbreak” and how far a single droplet can travel.I feel both strangely disconnected from the world
column13: and strangely connected
column14: all at the same time.Disconnected because I’m working from home.Connected because I find myself reaching out to others more than ever before.Now that I can’t visit in person
column15: I call more."

column1: 49 5b1c286e-1204-4fe7-9c21-ac2779984f6a "RECIPE FOR A BASIC ANTI-VIRUS PUNCH – Glossy News Satire Skip to content Menu HomeAdvertise with Glossy NewsSubmit Your Satire Here!Terms of Use × Search for: Posted in Health RECIPE FOR A BASIC ANTI-VIRUS PUNCH Author: rfreed  Published Date: April 19
column2: 2020  Leave a Comment on RECIPE FOR A BASIC ANTI-VIRUS PUNCH NOTE- This recipe should only be used as a preventative if you do not have COVID-19 already.The herbs
column3: juices and fruits contained in this drink have been used for ages against many types of flu’s
column4: colds and viruses.Maybe
column5: just maybe
column6: it will work against this new plague we have at the moment.Mix ½ gallon non-sweetened fruit juice
column7: preferably with 100% concentration
column8: with tea made from a half gallon of the following: 1 teaspoon dried elderberries or 1 teaspoon fresh elderberries (Fresh elderberries MUST be cooked otherwise they can make you ill.They are for prevention.)½ teaspoon thyme (for the lungs)."

column4: 2020 0 0 With the onslaught of the societal disrupting influence of “the virus” altering our lives for the worse
column5: it is comforting to know that there are ages-old healing remedies right here in Eagle County that have been used by various societies throughout the ages to battle colds
column6: flu and viruses.Rather than wait the year that pharmaceutical authorities say it will take to develop a vaccine
column7: there are herbs
column8: minerals and vitamins right here in our midst that can help conquer this modern plague.Vitamin C
column9: elderberry
column10: astragalus
column11: garlic
column12: cayenne
column13: zinc
column14: yarrow
column15: juniper berry
column16: echinacea
column17: ginger and goldenseal are all items that can be made into teas or added to our foods to theoretically help prevent or help overcome COVID-19 and are available at our local stores.They have worked for other viruses throughout time; why not this one too?For the respiratory system
column18: there is wild cherry bark
column19: pine sprigs
column20: osha root
column21: horehound
column22: and mullein which can be found in tinctures
column23: herbal capsules and in a dried form.These are available at our local grocery stores and in packaged form in the local Mexican stores as well.And for the cough afflicted
column24: pine trees offer up their needles and sprigs for a vitamin-C enhanced
column25: lung-healing hot tea throughout the year."

column1: 49 71fd265a-32a0-4c9a-9f9e-7af3c99800b5 "False claim: 12 herbs and spices can prevent or treat different viruses - Reuters Discover Thomson ReutersFinancialGovernment SolutionsLegalReuters News AgencyRisk Management SolutionsTax & AccountingBlog: Answers OnInnovation @ Thomson ReutersDirectory of sitesLoginContactSupportBusinessMarketsWorldPoliticsTVMoreUnited States Reuters Fact CheckApril 27
column2: 2020 / 2:45 PM / Updated 2 hours agoFalse claim: 12 herbs and spices can prevent or treat different viruses12 Min ReadA post shared 1.8 thousand times on Facebook falsely claims that 12 herbs and spices can prevent or treat a variety of illnesses.The photograph shows a list of herbs and is titled “anti viral herbs” (here).While some of these herbs may have homeopathic properties
column3: to claim they are “anti-viral” and prevent COVID-19 is misleading and potentially dangerous.On its website
column4: the National Institutes of Health (NIH) says: “The media has reported that some people are seeking “alternative” remedies to prevent infection with the new coronavirus or to treat COVID-19.Some of these purported remedies include herbal therapies and teas.There is no scientific evidence that any of these alternative remedies can prevent or cure COVID-19.” (here)    Oregano    The post claims that oregano has been “found to reduce the activity of murine norovirus (MNV)
column5: rotavirus and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).”     According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): “there is currently no vaccine to prevent norovirus” (here)."

column5: 2020 at 12:01 AM I have never sung “Happy birthday” so many times in my life.Per CDC instructions

column7: a happy ditty now inextricably linked to disease and death — oh
column8: how our world has changed!But that is our reality now.When Darrell returns from a weekly jaunt to the grocery store
column9: I spray his shoes with Lysol and leave them outside in the sun to kill any stray germs.When we go walking
column10: most often at Oaklawn Cemetery
column11: we give a wide berth to other walkers.We wave.We smile.We joke about staying 6 feet apart.But we keep even more than the required social distance away — and take note which direction the wind is blowing.If you wonder why
column12: think of the theater scene in “Outbreak” and how far a single droplet can travel.I feel both strangely disconnected from the world
column13: and strangely connected
column14: all at the same time.Disconnected because I’m working from home.Connected because I find myself reaching out to others more than ever before.Now that I can’t visit in person
column15: I call more."

column1: 49 90e362c0-e92c-4866-9c94-8bf2cd27564e "Don’t Rely on Supplements to Treat or Prevent COVID-19 SubscribeHealth NewsFact CheckedDon’t Rely on Supplements to Treat or Prevent COVID-19 Written by Kristen Fischer on April 7
column2: 2020 - Fact checked by Dana K. Cassell New Share on PinterestExperts say don’t count on supplements as a way to stop COVID-19.Getty ImagesDoctors warn that relying on supplements — and taking too much of them — may do more harm than good.Many vitamins and minerals can impact overall immunity but no single one can solely influence immunity.Want to add a new supplement?Talk about it with your doctor.All data and statistics are based on publicly available data at the time of publication.Some information may be out of date.Visit our coronavirus hub and follow our live updates page for the most recent information on the COVID-19 outbreak.Experts continue to encourage people to eat well and exercise during the COVID-19 pandemic.Meanwhile
column3: reports claiming that supplements can prevent or treat COVID-19 have emerged."

column16: oregano

column28: can shorten the duration of colds.” He also adds

column2: there are lots of natural ways to make sure you're fighting fit By Anna Magee 8 March 2020 • 4:00pm Premium Make sure your immune system is strong by living healthily ‘This is a serious infection and no amount of lifestyle intervention will make you invincible

column4: an immunologist at the University of Sussex
column5: whose timely new book Immunity: the science of staying well is out on April 16th.‘But there are plenty of small things you can do that may strengthen your immune system.’ 1.Follow the advice … whatever your age This is not the time to ignore public health messages

column7: a viral immunologist currently developing vaccines for flu.While the elderly are indeed more at risk
column8: your immune system actually started to decline years ago.‘Your thymus gland is where the body’s T cells [white blood cells that fight infection] are produced

column10: ’ says Dr Walton.‘But that’s only one reason everyone should be taking these measures

column12: relatively young people have a responsibility to stay well so they can avoid spreading an infection that could kill someone more vulnerable’."

column13: New York.(Photo by Bruce Bennett/Getty Images) (WJW) — Walgreens is introducing drive-thru shopping so you won’t have to leave your car during the coronavirus pandemic.Here’s how it works

column1: 49 ad3d3151-bdfa-4ff5-8805-00554cae6785 "False claim over vitamin C to cure COVID-19 – Afternoon Voice Food & Lifestyle Tech Viral Sci-Tech Interview Photos Videos Contact Us Top News City News Nation World Business Sports Entertainment Editorial Opinion Column Diary Letters Epaper No Result View All Result Top News City News Nation World Business Sports Entertainment Editorial Opinion Column Diary Letters Epaper No Result View All Result No Result View All Result Home Lifestyle Health False claim over vitamin C to cure COVID-19 by Afternoon Voice March 23
column2: 2020 in Health
column3: Lifestyle 0 0 SHARES 11 VIEWS Share on FacebookShare on Twitter Can vitamin C have the ability to kill the COVID-19 infection?This is the theory which is getting viral since the dissemination of infection started
column4: but the answer is false.There is no such evidence which could claim that vitamin C can contain the virus.However
column5: Vitamin C is still good option to boost the immune system in the body to prevent the virus but still no proof that it can heal a patient fully.RelatedPosts In step towards gender equilibrium in Tech institutions
column6: IITs grant 20 pc quota for women students Turn MBA into your forte by including these questions in your checklist Body produces “oxidative stress
column7: ” when fighting against an infection
column8: a process were inflammation in cell tissue can experience.Vitamin C not only helps to fight body against oxidative stress but also helps in detoxification process and helps to mount an immune system by cleaning up the cellular mess."

column1: 49 b33bc691-d157-4c7c-b6b6-e42035b9cdae "Don’t Fall For These Myths About Coronavirus - NYT ParentingFor the best experience
column2: please enable JavaScript.ParentingSkip to contentStagesLife as a ParentAll TopicsAdviceYour child’s development and more evidence-based guidance.GuidesMilestonesGet the NYT Parenting NewsletterEnter your emailSign UpFollow NYT ParentingEditors’ PicksStagesLife as a ParentAll TopicsGuidesMilestonesGet the NewsletterWhat to Know About CoronavirusDon’t Fall for These Myths About CoronavirusMisconceptions about what can protect you are becoming just as contagious as the virus.By Dani BlumMarch 2
column3: 2020Share on FacebookCopy the linkEmail this articleImageCreditLisk FengAs coronavirus continues to spread across the globe
column4: we’re working to answer the questions on many parents’ minds.For the latest updates
column5: read the New York Times’s live coronavirus coverage here.As the coronavirus continues to spread across the globe
column6: confusion and misconceptions about what can protect you are becoming as contagious as the virus.We spoke to doctors and experts in infectious diseases about whether there’s any truth to these common claims.Purell can help protect you.Maybe.Hand sanitizers with over 60 percent alcohol are effective in killing viruses like the coronavirus
column7: Dr. William Schaffner
column8: M.D.
column9: a professor of preventive medicine and infectious diseases at Vanderbilt University Medical Center said.But no one knows for sure if they will work on the current virus."

column2: how our world has changed - Opinion - The Daily News - Jacksonville
column3: NC Sections NewsSportsEntertainmentLifeObituariese-EditionJobsHomesCarsClassifiedsMember Rewards Subscribe Log in Subscribe Now Oh
column4: how our world has changed Annette Jordan Saturday Apr 4
column5: 2020 at 12:01 AM I have never sung “Happy birthday” so many times in my life.Per CDC instructions
column6: humming that song twice from beginning to end while washing your hands should be enough to remove coronavirus pathogens
column7: a happy ditty now inextricably linked to disease and death — oh
column8: how our world has changed!But that is our reality now.When Darrell returns from a weekly jaunt to the grocery store
column9: I spray his shoes with Lysol and leave them outside in the sun to kill any stray germs.When we go walking
column10: most often at Oaklawn Cemetery
column11: we give a wide berth to other walkers.We wave.We smile.We joke about staying 6 feet apart.But we keep even more than the required social distance away — and take note which direction the wind is blowing.If you wonder why
column12: think of the theater scene in “Outbreak” and how far a single droplet can travel.I feel both strangely disconnected from the world
column13: and strangely connected
column14: all at the same time.Disconnected because I’m working from home.Connected because I find myself reaching out to others more than ever before.Now that I can’t visit in person
column15: I call more."

column1: 49 b9d674cd-7f98-4328-97e1-5575a1a10f78 "Homeopaths promise coronavirus prevention and cures
column2: as health officials criticise 'misinformation' Jump to navigation Homeopaths promise coronavirus prevention and cures
column3: as health officials criticise 'misinformation' Homeopaths who are promoting ""remedies"" to prevent or treat coronavirus have been accused of exploiting public anxiety by health officials.By Sophie Barnes
column4: Investigations Reporter 2 March 2020 • 9:36am Premium Health officials accused homeopaths who are recommending alternative medicine as a way of keeping coronavirus at bay of exploiting public anxiety through “misinformation” Homeopaths who are promoting ""remedies"" to prevent or treat coronavirus have been accused of exploiting public anxiety by health officials.A Telegraph investigation can reveal that a number of homeopaths in the UK are claiming there are homeopathic “remedies” that can prevent or treat coronavirus.These remedies include colloidal silver to “boost the immune system” which
column5: if taken in excessive quantities
column6: has possible side effects that include turning the skin a bluish grey colour which can be permanent
column7: and kidney damage.They are also recommending a remedy supposedly made from the coronavirus itself.The Advertising Standards Authority
column8: which has previously cracked down on homeopaths who claim to be able to treat autism
column9: said in response to the Telegraph’s findings it would be taking “swift action” with its enforcement partners."

column2: 2020 By Roisin Henderson r.henderson@fermanaghherald.com SHARE emailPinterestLinkedinTwitterFacebook EATING healthy
column3: drinking plenty of water
column4: and exercising are the best ways to help prepare yourself for any potential coronavirus pandemic.That’s the advice from a Fermanagh pharmacist
column5: who also recommended developing good habits now in using hand sanitiser and taking a good multivitamin or immune-boosting herbal supplement such as echinacea.Paul Hughes of Hughes Pharmacy in Enniskillen said while the virus was not currently in the area there was “a lot of panic” locally.“There are an awful lot of people looking for masks
column6: and an awful lot of people looking for hand sanitiser gel
column7: ” said Mr Hughes
column8: pictured below
column9: who said his business was facing the same shortages being seen across the country.“We did have some hand sanitiser
column10: but it’s gone.We’ve been told now we might have some next week
column11: but even with that we wanted to order a lot and they have only let us order something like 30 bottles."

column3: says Health Canada.Donald Trump isn’t the only one promoting COVID-19 ‘cures’ News 06:48 PM by Tonda MacCharles Ottawa Bureau OTTAWA—The dicey claims are not just from a U.S. president musing about bleach injections as a possible cure for the coronavirus.There are dozens and dozens of peddlers of all kinds of snake oil in our midst.Health Canada has published a list of 101 products for which dubious or possibly dangerous claims have been made.Everything from echinacea and oregano oil
column4: vitamins and other so-called natural remedies to “boost the immune system “during the threat of COVID-19
column5: ” to “ozone lamp bulbs” to ultraviolet disinfecting lamps

column7: bottle sprayers and power washers billed as “COVID-19 virus prevention” able to “dispense alcohol for disinfection COVID-19 Virus Prevention.” There were residential air purifiers listed on Kijiji with the claim “Save yourself and family from coronavirus!” Face shields."

column3: 2020 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Jetson
column4: creators of the world’s only seasonal probiotic
column5: today announced its commitment to provide front-line
column6: essential workers with Immunity
column7: an immunity-supporting probiotic formula
column8: originally developed specifically to support optimal gut health for winter’s cold and flu season.With the spread of COVID-19
column9: Jetson is extending the availability of Immunity
column10: offering it as a one-time purchase.This probiotic formula is designed to support upper respiratory health and also contains three key ingredients shown to provide immune support: zinc
column11: echinacea
column12: and vitamin C. Starting today
column13: first-time buyers of any Jetson product will receive a free bottle of Immunity to send to a front-line worker.Additionally
column14: anyone can email goto@wearejetson.com with a brief description of him/herself or someone else who qualifies as a front-line
column15: essential worker.Submissions should include name

column4: including Coronavirus Covid 19.If you are taking dietary supplements
column5: be careful.The National Agency for Food
column6: Environmental and Occupational Health Safety ( ANSES ) alerted
column7: Monday 20th April 2020
column8: to the potential risks that some of them may cause.It turns out that certain food supplements can disrupt our immune defences
column9: and therefore become very dangerous in the current context of the coronavirus epidemic.Read also: Back to school by class
column10: number of students… Jean-Michel Blanquer details the back-to-school tracks Plants with anti-inflammatory properties In a press release
column11: joint with the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of Nouvelle-Aquitaine
column12: it is explained that certain food supplements “can interfere with the inflammatory defence mechanisms useful to fight against infections (in this case
column13: against coronavirus) “.These are plants containing salicylic acid derivatives (analogues of aspirin)
column14: such as willow
column15: meadowsweet
column16: birch
column17: poplar
column18: goldenrod
column19: polygalas but also plants containing other plant anti-inflammatory drugs
column20: such as harpagophytum
column21: echinacea
column22: turmeric
column23: cat’s claw (also called Peruvian creeper)
column24: plants of the genera Boswellia and Commiphora (known for their gum oleoresins called respectively ” frankincense “and” myrrh “)."

column2: 2020 5:17:51 PMVitamin C is a crucial micronutrient for humans
column3: with multiple roles for the immunity in human beings.Experts have also said that except Vitamin C has some antagonistic effects on human’s body as well.The number of Coronavirus in India is increasing and so is the rumours surrounding its cure and prevention.Among a majority of fake news and misinformation floating the public domain and social media is that Vitamin C can help in the prevention and cure of the Coronavirus.The claims of Vitamin C’s role in direct prevention and cure of the Coronavirus is false and based on unsubstantiated facts.However

column9: trying to make a profit

Healthy / YouTube / CBC)A Facebook post and a video with a robotic voiceover cite expert advice from Chinese researcher Jiao Shenme Minzi.The first clue is its name

False: Different Types Of Tea Can Act As A Cure For COVID-19Caffeine in tea is known to reduce drowsiness and fatigue but there is no scientific evidence about its impact on COVID-19BannedfortalkinBy - Shachi SutariaLoading...  |  3 April 2020 10:14 AM GMTViral messages claiming that tea prepared with different ingredients is a tested cure for COVID-19
column2: the deadly disease caused by the Coronavirus
column3: are false.The World Health Organization has stated that there has been no treatment approved nor any medical prevention protocol to tackle the COVID-19
column4: so far.The two messages making the claim are as follows: 1.Tea made with lemon and bicarbonate (baking soda) alkalize the immune system as it becomes acidic in the night and that Israel has no deaths as Israelis regularly drink this concoction.The claim is false on two counts as there is no scientific evidence of this concoction changing the PH levels in the body and Israel has over 7
column5: 000 confirmed cases and 36 deaths (so far) due to COVID-19 as reported by Johns Hopkins University.2."

column1: 50 2492de47-deea-462b-9e21-0f21da24c35d "Surveillance Cameras in China is the New Normal for Everyone | HNGN - Headlines & Global News Wednesday
column2: April 29
column3: 2020 HEADLINES & GLOBAL NEWS HEADLINES TECH SCIENCE/HEALTH ENTERTAINMENT SPORTS CORONAVIRUS DONALD TRUMP Surveillance Cameras in China is the New Normal for Everyone By  Staff Reporter Apr 29
column4: 2020 05:10 PM EDT China's obsession with monitoring its citizens with surveillance cameras has reached a new high as cameras are installed at the front door or in the home itself.Returning from a trip to southern China
column5: Ian Lahiffe went back to discover a surveillance camera that was getting mounted right outside his apartment when he was starting two-week home isolation that was mandatory and enforced by Beijing officials.This was a means to stop the spread of the coronavirus.He noted that the camera was pointed at him and gave the message like a big brother is watching.The camera pointing at him was a stern reminder to him.The camera was there
column6: getting mounted to know what he was doing
column7: but he thought the reason might be more ominous than imagined."

column23: an infectious disease specialist at Baylor College
column24: consuming alcohol will not protect against infectious diseases like COVID-19.“Alcohol consumption has long been touted as a means to prevent infection with a variety of pathogens

column26: the evidence is often the opposite – that alcohol consumption is associated with increased risk of infection

Baking Soda Can Kill Coronavirus Is Fake Aditi ChattopadhyayIndia   | Published : 7 April 2020 9:55 AM GMTImage credit: Pixabay

Image credit: Pixabay

The logical Indian fact check team investigates the claim that lemon and baking soda can kill coronavirus.A viral WhatsApp forward claiming that a simple way to kill the novel coronavirus has come up from Israel
column4: has been doing the rounds.""In Israel no death from C-19
column5: reads the title of the viral forward.It then goes onto state that there's a cure for the novel coronavirus.The message then goes further into details of an apparent cure for COVID-19 – a combination of lemon
column6: water
column7: and bicarbonate (baking soda) since the concoction 'alkalizes the immune system' and alleges that's why 'people of Israel are relaxed about this virus'.Several of our community members sent us the forward asking us to verify the information.The claim has also been shared on social media platforms."

column10: 2020.Anatoly Moskvin was a self-proclaimed expert on cemeteries and dubbed himself a ""necropolyst.""Too bad he took this expertise to unhealthy levels.The historian was arrested after 29 girls' corpses from the ages of 3 to 25 were discovered to be mummified in his apartment in the central Russian city of Nizhny Novgorod.The bodysnatcher dressed the corpses in knee-high boots with lipstick for his collection.He would hold tea parties with his dolls."

column5: an anti-viral nasal spray might cure the coronavirus that is based on their research.The study was done by Pneumagen at the university to investigate the coronavirus in three separate lab-based studies to see the efficacy of the cure.The objective of the studies conducted was run through a series of tests
column6: to check the veracity of the results before going into full trials.At this point
column7: many drugs have failed to yield results

column11: with GlycoTarge technology."

column6: never DRY."

column2: most of the claims mentioned in the message are not backed by scientific evidence.Social media is abuzz with this message and it is being shared globally.The message has eight claims surrounding the prevention of COVID-19.It also states that adhering to these steps would be sufficient to protect oneself from the virus."

column3: there have been 51 COVID-19-related deaths and 8

column1: 50 7392ffd5-4606-4e4b-b4fd-d4fef3068a22 "FACT CHECK: Does Hot Water With Lemon Kill Coronavirus?8:24 PM 03/26/2020 Brad Sylvester | Fact Check Reporter share on facebook tweet this show comments A Facebook post claims that drinking hot water with sliced lemon can kill the new coronavirus.﻿ Verdict: False There is no scientific evidence to support the claim.Fact Check: Social media has become replete with posts touting fake coronavirus cures ranging from marijuana and cocaine to saunas and colloidal silver.Now
column2: a March 21 Facebook post is claiming hot water with lemon slices can “kill the proliferation of the virus in our bodies.” However
column3: as with other bogus remedies circulating online
column4: no proof could be found to support the post’s claim.The World Health Organization (WHO) notes on its website that while some home remedies may alleviate COVID-19 symptoms
column5: there is no evidence they can prevent or cure the disease caused by the new virus."

column2: 2020 / 3:56 PM / Updated an hour agoFalse claim: bicarbonate soda and lemon juice can help prevent coronavirus infection5 Min ReadA post on social media suggests that drinking bicarbonate sodium and lemon juice reduces the acidity of the body and the risk of getting infected with COVID-19.The post
column3: which also claims “Coronavirus mutates and multiplies in the body through acid cells”
column4: has over 34 shares on Facebook as of March 6

column3: which also claims “Coronavirus mutates and multiplies in the body through acid cells”

column7: even though they were shared widely on social media.The Associated Press checked them out.Here are the facts: ___ CLAIM: Eating alkaline foods will stave off the novel coronavirus
column8: which has a pH level of 5.5 to 8.5.THE FACTS: A false post circulating on social media claims that COVID-19 has a pH level between 5.5 to 8.5

column1: 50 935504d1-90cc-4768-b89b-23fffc71f33b "5 Covid-19 food myths5 Covid-19 food mythsThere is currently no evidence that eating certain foods can protect you from Covid-19.Danijela Maksimovic/ShutterstockTaibat Ibitoye4 hours agoSince the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2)
column2: there have been widespread claims on social media that certain foods and supplements can prevent or cure Covid-19.Even though the World Health Organization (WHO) has tried to dispel such myths surrounding “miracle” foods and coronavirus
column3: misinformation continues to circulate.Though we all want to protect ourselves against Covid-19
column4: there is currently no evidence that eating certain foods or following certain diets will protect you against coronavirus.Here are some of the most common myths debunked:Myth 1: garlicThere is some evidence showing that garlic has antibacterial effects
column5: with existing studies indicating the active compounds of garlic (including allicin
column6: allyl alcohol
column7: and diallyl disulfide) are protective against some types of bacteria like salmonella and staphylococcus aureus.However
column8: research investigating garlic’s antiviral properties is limited.Though garlic is considered to be healthy food
column9: there’s no evidence showing that eating it can prevent or cure Covid-19.Myth 2: lemonsOne viral Facebook video claimed that drinking warm water with lemon slices could combat novel coronavirus.However
column10: there’s no scientific evidence that lemon can cure the disease.Lemon is a good source of vitamin C
column11: which is important for helping immune cells work properly.However
column12: many other citrus fruits and vegetables contain vitamin C.Myth 3: vitamin CAs previously stated
column13: Vitamin C is known to play a role in supporting the normal functioning of the immune system."

column1: 50 94613b04-1815-4cf5-b313-dde5b3d8b80e "Boost Your Metabolism And Immune System With Lemon Ginger Water - close menu Subscribe Now Trending Celebrity Gossip Celebrity Trivia Trending Property Relationship Entertainment Celebrity Talk Health Expert Advice LIFESTYLE Travel Vaccine COVID-19 E-magazine January Issue March Issue Healthify Search for: Subscribe Now Trending Entertainment Health LIFESTYLE Vaccine COVID-19 E-magazine Healthify navigation log in or register Subscribe Now Trending Celebrity Gossip Celebrity Trivia Trending Property Relationship Entertainment Celebrity Talk Health Expert Advice LIFESTYLE Travel Vaccine COVID-19 E-magazine January Issue March Issue Healthify Browse: Health Boost Your Metabolism And Immune System With Lemon Ginger Water RSS SubscribeBoost Your Metabolism And Immune System With Lemon Ginger WaterHealthApril 7
column2: 2020 Hailey Hailey 0 Your hydration directly effects your metabolism.If you want to rev up your metabolism
column3: then you should be drinking an optimal amount of water every day.Water is involved in pretty much every function in the body
column4: so if you’re dehydrated
column5: it’s no wonder your metabolism is going to be effected.Almost 80% of your muscle consists of water
column6: so if you’re dehydrated
column7: your muscles ability to burn calories slows down.If that wasn’t enough
column8: when you’re dehydrated your body’s ability to mobilize fat as a fuel source decreases!So the bottom line
column9: if you want to rev up your metabolism
column10: you must must must be drinking adequate water!"

column3: lemon in hot water is not a 'cure' for COVID-19 This content is not available in your regionThe CubeDebunked: No
column4: lemon in hot water is not a 'cure' for COVID-19 Comments By Seana Davis  &bullet  last updated: 01/04/2020 - 19:32 Copyright Misinformation about lemon as a 'cure' for coronavirus Share this articleShareTweetSharesendShareTweetSharesendMoreHideShareSendShareShareShareSendShareShareText size Aa Aa “We’re not just fighting an epidemic; we’re fighting an infodemic
column5: ” the director-general of the World Health Organization (WHO)
column6: Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
column7: said in February.Since then
column8: the coronavirus has evolved into a global pandemic
column9: and the wave of disinformation has grown.One such method of misinformation is the copy-and-paste of posts from anonymous or misidentified experts.An example of this is a false claim suggesting a 'cure' for SARS-COV-2 was found in Israel.What is the claim?The post
column10: which we have found not only in English
column11: but also in Spanish and Russian
column12: begins by saying that there are ""no cases"" of coronavirus in Israel.This in itself is untrue
column13: with Israel reporting more than 5
column14: 000 confirmed cases of the virus as of 1 April.It then suggests mixing lemon and baking soda with hot tea to ""immediately kill"" the virus
column15: adding that this ""alkalizes the immune system"".The false claimThere are also numerous variations of this post.One such post found on Facebook calls on people to ""have your daily dose of lemon water
column16: or add baking powder instead"" because the virus is ""pH sensitive"".Why is this false?We reached out to numerous virologists for their comment.Professor Michael Kann
column17: professor of clinical virology at the University of Gothenburg
column18: Sweden
column19: pointed to a study released earlier this year.Although not yet peer reviewed
column20: the Chin."

column2: or Anywhere Else - FactCheck.org FactCheck.org® A Project of The Annenberg Public Policy Center Skip to content FactCheck.org® Home Articles Featured Posts FactCheck Posts SciCheck Debunking False Stories 2020 Election Ask a Question Ask FactCheck Ask SciCheck Donate Archives President Trump Joe Biden Bernie Sanders Coronavirus climate change Ukraine Russia investigation View All About Us Our Mission Our Process Our Funding Our Staff Undergraduate Fellows Awards Request a Correction Contact Us Search More Viral Claims FactCheck On the Air Subscribe Mailbag Quiz Archive Party Lines 2018 Election Debunking False Stories Lemon Juice Tea Does Not Cure COVID-19 in Israel
column3: or Anywhere Else By Sydney SchaedelPosted on April 2
column4: 2020 Quick Take A post circulating on social media falsely claims that a blend of sodium bicarbonate and lemon juice will “eliminate” the novel coronavirus.The post also claims this “cure” has prevented any COVID-19 deaths in Israel — but more than 30 people have died of the disease there.Full Story As COVID-19
column5: the disease caused by the novel coronavirus
column6: spreads around the world
column7: numerous false and misleading claims of “cures” for the virus are spreading on social media.A recent claim is from a post titled “In Israel No Death from COVID 19.”  It falsely states that the “cure” for COVID-19
column8: “or the way to eliminate it
column9: ” has been discovered
column10: and that it comes from Israel
column11: where it says the virus “did not cause any death.” In reality
column12: as of April 2
column13: more than 6
column14: 800 people in Israel have tested positive for COVID-19
column15: and 36 have died.Over 100 people were in serious condition and 83 were on life support.The post also claims that this “cure” is the reason that the “People of Israel is relaxed” about COVID-19."

column2: April 4
column3: 2020 A roundup of some of the most popular but completely untrue stories and visuals of the week.None of these are legit
column4: even though they were shared widely on social media.The Associated Press checked them out.Here are the facts: **** CLAIM: Eating alkaline foods will stave off the novel coronavirus
column5: which has a pH level of 5.5 to 8.5.THE FACTS: A false post circulating on social media claims that COVID-19 has a pH level between 5.5 to 8.5
column6: and in order to fend off the virus people must consume alkaline foods.Both points are false."

column4: 2020 in Commentaries
column5: Comments
column6: News Update
column7: Opinion 0 By Wole Elegbede More than three months after the first reported case of coronavirus in China
column8: Nigeria and the rest of the world continue to grapple with how to tackle the disease.The challenge is not limited to saving people from death and stopping the spread of the disease
column9: but dealing with fallouts
column10: one of which is the spread of fake contents and misinformation about the disease
column11: especially in the social media.In my searches across the social media channels during the period
column12: I found out that the misinformation appears more on Facebook and WhatsApp.These fake contents border on the unimaginable to the ridiculous
column13: myths and misconceptions.Some fake stories may indeed be amusing to the reader
column14: but the danger that they pose to health and society could be enormous; they could be counterproductive and result in more deaths.In Nigeria
column15: the fake news definitely are out of place with the press releases and the information on the websites of local and international organisations charged with the responsibilities of controlling the disease and providing credible information on its outbreak."

column1: 50 ab2e7f3c-d0a6-46f6-bf55-ccdf8ed8e4d1 "There are no miracle foods or diets that can prevent or cure COVID-19.– Infosurhoy Skip to content Infosurhoy Latest Science News and Reports Main Navigation News News Summary Top Stories Technology Economy Entertainment Health Science Sports There are no miracle foods or diets that can prevent or cure COVID-19.By Denis Bedoya  On April 21
column2: 2020 In News Summary Leave a comment facebook tweet google+ Since the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2)
column3: there have been widespread claims on social media that certain foods and supplements can prevent or cure COVID-19.Even though the World Health Organization (WHO) has tried to dispel such myths surrounding “miracle” foods and coronavirus
column4: misinformation continues to circulate.Though we all want to protect ourselves against COVID-19
column5: there is currently no evidence that eating certain foods or following certain diets will protect you against coronavirus.Here are some of the most common myths debunked: Myth 1: garlic There is some evidence showing that garlic has antibacterial effects
column6: with existing studies indicating the active compounds of garlic (including allicin
column7: allyl alcohol and diallyl disulfide) are protective against some types of bacteria like salmonella and staphylococcus aureus."

column12: April 3
column14: The Associated Press reported on stories circulating online incorrectly asserting that drinking alcoholic beverages can prevent coronavirus.According to Dr. Robert Legare Atmar
column15: an infectious disease specialist at Baylor College
column16: consuming alcohol will not protect against infectious diseases like COVID-19.“Alcohol consumption has long been touted as a means to prevent infection with a variety of pathogens
column17: but there is no evidence that such alcohol consumption protects against any infection.In fact
column18: the evidence is often the opposite – that alcohol consumption is associated with increased risk of infection
column19: ” Dr. Atmar told the AP in an email."

column1: 50 ac6dae5d-7b1a-4653-9aa6-c1f5e2012856 "Will Eating Papaya Salad Prevent COVID-19 Infection?A Fact Check TopTop LoginSupportFake News +Mob LynchingCoronavirusWorld +CoronavirusFact FileHealthFast CheckMultimedia +Boom ReportsFact FileFact Vs FictionPodcast LoginSupportHomeFake News-Mob LynchingCoronavirusWorld-CoronavirusFact FileHealthFast CheckMultimedia-Boom ReportsFact FileFact Vs FictionPodcastFake NewsCoronavirusWorldFact FileHealthFast CheckMultimediaHome   »World » Will Eating Papaya... Will Eating Papaya Salad Prevent COVID-19 Infection?A Fact CheckHealth experts have said there is no evidence that papaya salad can prevent people from contracting the Coronavirus.By - AFPLoading...  |  30 April 2020 12:21 PM GMTA video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook
column2: Twitter and YouTube which claims that eating papaya salad can help to prevent infection from the novel coronavirus
column3: which causes the disease COVID-19.The claim is false; as of April 2020
column4: health experts have said there is no evidence that papaya salad can prevent people from catching the virus; the World Health Organization (WHO) maintains that wearing masks
column5: social distancing and washing hands regularly are the most effective methods of preventing infection.The video was published on Facebook here on April 11
column6: 2020.It has been viewed more than 331
column7: 000 times and shared more than 8
column8: 700 times."

column3: 2020 / 01:15 PM EDT A roundup of some of the most popular but completely untrue stories and visuals of the week.None of these are legit
column4: even though they were shared widely on social media.The Associated Press checked them out.Here are the facts: CLAIM: Eating alkaline foods will stave off the novel coronavirus
column5: which has a pH level of 5.5 to 8.5.THE FACTS: A false post circulating on social media claims that COVID-19 has a pH level between 5.5 to 8.5

column2: journalistic flair COVID-19 Arts + Culture Economy + Business Education Environment + Energy Ethics + Religion Health Politics + Society Science + Technology Coronavirus: there are no miracle foods or diets that can prevent or cure COVID-19 April 21
column3: 2020 5.41am EDT Taibat Ibitoye
column4: University of Reading Author Taibat Ibitoye Registered Dietitian and Doctoral Researcher
column5: University of Reading Disclosure statement Taibat Ibitoye is a Registered Dietitian and a full member of the British Dietetic Association (BDA).Partners University of Reading provides funding as a member of The Conversation UK.View all partners Fake news spread on social media claims “super foods” can cure COVID-19.Danijela Maksimovic/ Shutterstock Email Twitter Facebook LinkedIn WhatsApp Messenger Since the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2)
column6: there have been widespread claims on social media that certain foods and supplements can prevent or cure COVID-19.Even though the World Health Organization (WHO) has tried to dispel such myths surrounding “miracle” foods and coronavirus
column7: misinformation continues to circulate.Though we all want to protect ourselves against COVID-19
column8: there is currently no evidence that eating certain foods or following certain diets will protect you against coronavirus."

column1: 50 c85e8617-203e-4cb2-afad-cd9686141e27 "10 Of The Biggest WhatsApp Myths On Coronavirus Busted For You TRENDING VIDEOS STORIES QUIZZES MEMES SPOTLIGHT Sign In Categories News Entertainment Humor Opinion Food Travel Women LGBTQIA Animals Sex & Relationships Culture Sports Tech Men Our channels View all About Us Contact Us Advertise With Us Careers Privacy policy Terms and conditions Advertisement NEWS Apr 04
column2: 2020 at 19:01 We Have Busted 10 Of The Biggest WhatsApp Myths Around Coronavirus For You Smrutisnat Jena 11 shares | 2733 views India's fake news problem has multiplied ever since the coronavirus pandemic started.WhatsApp forwards from quacks have been circulating with myths about the virus and its cures.So
column3: we decide to help you out with a few common myths
column4: that you might have been led to believe.1.Eating garlic or lemon or any other food that's used as home remedies for common cold can prevent coronavirus infection.Reality: Garlic has some anti-microbial properties.And vitamin C can support the immune system."

column1: 50 cf0db588-a76e-487c-b5cb-2836311164b3 "Myth Debunking: Foods and Remedies that Will Not Directly Cure or Prevent COVID-19 | Egyptian Streets Politics and Society News International Feature Photo Essays Opinion Arts & Culture Technology Travel Buzz Politics and Society News International Feature Photo Essays Opinion Arts & Culture Technology Travel Buzz Facebook Twitter Instagram YouTube RSS Share this on WhatsApp Myth Debunking Myth Debunking: Foods and Remedies that Will Not Directly Cure or Prevent COVID-19 Mary Aravanis April 6
column2: 2020 Myth Debunking: Foods and Remedies that Will Not Directly Cure or Prevent COVID-19 As soon as news of the outbreak spread
column3: various information starting emerging and spreading like wildfire
column4: making it difficult to distinguish the real from the fake.A lot of the information that has been getting shared revolves around methods on how to prevent of the novel COVID-19 virus.Naturally
column5: human beings always look for ways to re-assure themselves under stressful situations
column6: and so reading about how certain foods or remedies or rituals can prevent COVID-19 may be comforting and therefore susceptible to immediate belief.However
column7: it is important to note that the way information is structured and shared makes all the difference.There have been certain pieces of misinformation circulating that certain foods or remedies can help prevent or cure COVID-19
column8: which is not entirely true.While most of the following foods and remedies mentioned certainly have general nutritional and health benefits as stand alone items
column9: as of now there is no scientific evidence that any types of foods or remedies can directly prevent or cure the virus."
